Balance among the voices always seems perfect, the soloists are agreeable to listen to, but above all I have been given one thing I particularly yearned for, namely a fine black-velvet basso-profundo `Volga-boatman' bass timbre.  It all takes place in a superbly calculated acoustic too, resonant in a suitably ecclesiastical way without compromising distinctness in the words or introducing unwanted echoes.The artists here are Russian (or at least Russian-based) of course, and I can't imagine that did any harm. However I do not propose to stray into ethnic assessments beyond saying that to me they sound born to perform this music, my own ideas of the matter being no doubt the kind of western stereotypes that I referred to above. There is a brief liner note attributed only to Decca, and for once I would have liked rather more of it because it is tantalisingly suggestive of having genuine thought put into it. I have never visited Russia and I have no experience of Orthodox rites, but after all these years I like to think I must be able to recognise good music well performed when I hear it, and that is what I think I am hearing, to a quite exceptional degree, in this set.

When Tchaikovsky produced his Liturgy of St John Chrysostom in 1878, despite a legal challenge from the Imperial Chapel whose permission he and his publisher had neglected to obtain, the Tsar remarked to him that he was surprised Tchaikovsky had not done more church music. Tchaikovsky no doubt knew which hints were worth taking, and he turned out a number of other items in 1884-5 and 1887, 10 of which are on this disc.The 'Liturgy' equates more or less to the Catholic Mass. Like the Mass it comes in a 'standard' version and a number of others for special occasions, the St John Chrysostom version being the standard one. The 10 choral numbers from it are given here, with the solos for the celebrant and deacon, and the litanies sung antiphonally by celebrant and choir, being omitted. Preceding these on the record you will find the other 10 items mentioned above, mostly isolated items from the Chrysostom Liturgy in fresh settings. These are slightly more elaborate and more solemn in tone than the main setting, with a little more polyphony and a little more word-repetition, but in general Tchaikovsky's a capella music is easy to grasp and much less severe in style than the unaccompanied motets of Bach and Brahms. There are no fugues or anything of that kind, and the longer sequences such as the Creed and the Lord's Prayer are despatched very briskly indeed. The Orthodox Liturgy is a lengthy affair, and I dare say that even the most devout congregation would have thanked the composer for restraining his muse to some extent.I would very much have liked to give this disc 5 stars, but I find I can't quite make myself do it. The articulation is very clear, and some of the singing is very good indeed, particularly sustained bass notes although even here I found myself yearning slightly for some 'real' Russian bass timbre. The recording may be part of the problem, and it could be that the intention was to provide a churchy acoustic, but the overall result is a certain dullness in the tone. I found it helped to boost the volume a little, but what I couldn't edit out was some very indifferent soprano sound on the higher notes, which are not even all that high. I refer to the choral sound. In the item with three soprano soloists these perform reasonably well, although I could not say I thought their voices were wonderful.The liner note provides a very good little introduction to the music, and the Russian is very sensibly given in Roman script with English translation. Nothing at all is said about the performers, the introduction is also translated into French and German but the texts are not, at least in the version of the note issued in England and, I can only suppose, in America

When I say that I recommend this set cordially, you will of course understand that I am not exhorting anyone to pay any old price for it. Keeping that aspect of the deal within reason, it is still an issue that would grace any musical collection. Robert Kings way of handling ancient music is one that I like greatly. It has some body and warmth to it, he does not try to set speed records, he does not restrict himself to one voice per part, but at the same time he uses proper period instruments and is careful about allowing vibrato into the solo vocal lines.So far as I know, the performing version that King uses here is faithful to Monteverdis own original arrangement from 1610, except that of course the composer would not have given both settings of the Magnificat during one and the same performance of the Vespers. King provides another of his agreeably-written notes on his own idea of such a performing version, and it is almost a pity that he didnt write the main part of the liner essay, as he often does, (meaning no disrespect to the sound and informative contribution of John Whenham). I know his liner notes mainly from his work on Handel, and I suppose that the subjects treated by that master provide more human interest, but Robert Kings humane and winning approach extends not only to music more than a century older than Handel but also to academic commentary on it.Each of the numbers is provided with a synopsis by John Whenham, although as you would expect the text of the Mass calls for less explanation than the various numbers constituting the Vespers do. This Missa in Illo Tempore is in fact a cappella, i.e. in a contrapuntal style like Palestrinas, the voices unaccompanied although the bass is supported discreetly by the organ. Monteverdis idiom is probably rather more grandiose than Palestrinas, and King and his chorus do a splendid job of maintaining and building a magnificent tone without fatiguing the listener. Elsewhere the idiom is more varied, calling for no fewer than nine vocal soloists together with special choral effects of echo and distance. I am entirely pleased with the way it is all handled, and that is of course a compliment to the technical personnel as well as to the artists. After several listenings I have yet to spot any lapses by either singers or instrumentalists, so I can now take off my fault-finding Beckmesser garb and refocus on not only enjoyment but also study and instruction.The liner material is given in French and German as well as English in the usual EU manner, the Latin texts being accompanied by English translations only. I compliment the production on the accuracy of the Latin, where there is all of one superfluous comma (after tuos in the Dixit Dominus.) In the texts there are a handful of minor quirks, which I shall list here. They have no effect on understanding the relationship of the music to the words, but we might as well get them right:. Dixit Dominus: ex utero...te. The meaning is simpler than the translation gives. Take it as I have begotten you out of the womb before the dawn.. Dixit Dominus: confregit. This is past tense smote. If the translator thought that this verb should be in the future tense like the three verbs following that could well be right, but in that case change the Latin to confringet.. Laudate pueri: humilia respicit means looks on the things that are lowly.. Laetatus sum: The line beginning cuius does not make sense. If the text can be trusted as far as eius the intended sense seems to be along the lines of whoso has a share in Jerusalem also partakes of <?>. However the corruption may go deeper, and any translation is guesswork.. Laetatus sum: The line beginning testimonium would be better translated as the testimony of Israel bearing witness to the name of the Lord.. Laetatus sum: loquebar pacem de te means I spoke peace regarding you.. Nisi Dominus: substitute a comma for the colon after filii/sons. They are the first noun of a little series of three nouns.One great bonus is the provision of both Monteverdis settings of the Magnificat, the second being the simpler 6-part effort, which Whenham suggests (quite plausibly) may have been the basis for the more elaborate 7-parter. Altogether there is little or nothing to find fault with in this production, and I didnt pay a lot for it.

Frederic Tellier directed this superb chronicle of tracking in search of this infamous murderer.The picture focuses its attention(with Paris as huge frame)around the internal in and outs inside the criminal brigade. Their different opinions, struggling ambiance, clash of visions; and meanwhile the succesive murderers happen during the investigation, dare us to understand the enormous responsability of these inspectors facing every new sexual attack while the time is running.The sequences in the Court are hovered of dazzling realism.Wonderful cast and the always talented Nathalie Baye (despite her supporting role) steals the show all the way through.Watch it without restrictions. You'll love it. A treat!

Werner Keller present us an impressive account of facts and evidences that carve in relief the process of intelectual vampirazing and illegal looting (since the Vikings times)from Russia State.Supported on an impressive amount of photographs, you will realize how the building process of architecture (the Kremlim, churches), jewelry, guns, boats  have been adressed by the first-rate minds of the Western hemisphere, Italians masters, British designers. Once they were invited for Russia State and gave all what they could, were deceived and sent to his native countries.Particularly interesting is the chapter in which Keller describes how the Krupp empire contributed to found the huge web of pipes system during the second half of the XIX Century.Since I got it in 1984, has become one of my referential books at the moment to question the supposed process of industrialzation of that country.The book was finished in 1951. nevertheless its reading is extremely engaging and captivating. Please, try to get this admirable essay, no matter you have to pay for it. It well deserves it.

Issay Dobrowen performed this sublime version with the Philharmonia Orchestra in 1953. He focuses around the pictorial poem; plenty of thoughtful process, Dobrowen displays and shows us a magisterial musical painting, establishing a subtle diference respect the most of conductors who regard this is a pyrothecnic exercise of powerful expressiveness and orchestral muscle.Boris Christoph is the soloist in Mussorgsky with superb results.I knew about this recording since 1970 in those times of LP format, and since then became my referential parameter, not surpassed until this date. I acquired it in 2007 in CD.Don't miss it. You've got my word.

Bertrand Botello gives a terrific acting as the famous French designer. This biopic show us the minimum facets of this man trapped between the fame and the unhappiness.Magnificent cast, artistic direction and custom design will captivate you from start to finish.A treat!

For no one is a secret Ernest Ansermet occupies an enviable place among the greatest conductors of an era that probably will never see. His persuasive intelligence for shaping and sculpting every work he performed reveal the arduous process of study and revision of the score.This album captures even the most distrusted listener. You may argue his Prokoviev lacks of the sinister attacks one should expect after listening the lecture of Antal Dorati or Sergei Koussevitzky, for instance. But he manages to show us details of orchestration and intimate voices hidden beneath the score.That's why I buy his smart approach of the Classical Symphony. Recorded twice one can perceive the eleven years between the mono and the stereo versions, the first one is notable even if lacks some of the brilliant opulence of the second one reading.I'm less swayed with Proko's Fifth. The First movement sounded me extremely fast, losing his energetic punch, vital element for this Symphony. Nevertheless, the superb phrasing and committed spirit in which is involved deserves my whole respect.Proko's Sixth is probably much more propulsive and demolishing, it matches with the other two versions I remind: Ormandy Philadelphia and more recently the always well esteemed reading of Walter Weller with the L.S.O.In sum, this double pack is a real musical document to have, for the ages to come. No doubt and purchase it without hesitation.PD. You should never forget Ansermet recorded with Ruggiero Ricci in 1958 both Proko violin concerts with amazing results of performance and critics around the world by then.

Two Mexican loosers are walking without realizing they are in private land. Suddenly a web of events will make its appearance that will trigger the existence of three families.Compelling and absorbing. Well cast and credible plot. Watch it!

George Miller directed this remake. Who can deny the fiercenes and the level of narrative intensity all the way through?.For the new generation of movie-buffs, it would be advisable to watch the initial Mad in order to understand what's goin' on.Because if you don't, you will be like Richard III in the middle of a chaotic battlefield of road-warriors.There are few alusions respect the state of things of this somber situation. A post- apocalyptic world in which there's no water, gasoline or lack of devices to live into more or less acceptable living conditions.Pitifully, Charlize Theron's amazing talent as actress is wasted in this film.The main virtues resides around the countless action sequences and wonderful camera handle.PD. Do you really buy the sequence in which Charlize has to hold the ankle of Mad with just one arm (Tom Hardy weights at least 180 pounds)? Sorry but I don't.

St Petersburg Quartet was founded in 1985; since that year has become one the great voices of DSHO. Their approach is at the same time, incisively astringent and demolishing expressive. They have achieved to convey the listener the structural symphonic cohesion these works demand.Go for this album. You'll be always rewarded

During the very beginnigs of the cinema, Hollywood has always paid tribute and even has felt a visible fascination respect to the figure of anti-hero, outsider or renegade of the system. Let's take a ride about it:Ray Milland in "Lost Weekend", Marlon Brando "On the waterfront", Paul Newman in "Cool hand Luke" and Jon Voight "Midnight cowboy" (the only two of all them who were not awarded, ironically in one of the hardest decades of the century: the sixties), Al Pacino "Serpico", (Just nominated), Jack Nicholson in "Someone flew over", Peter Finch "Network", F. Murray Abraham "Amadeus",  Nicolas Cage "Leaving las Vegas", Jeff Bridges "Crazy heart" and now Michael Keaton "Birdman".But there's still more. I found clever reminiscences with "All about Eve", "Sunset Boulevard" and "Who's afraid of Virginia Wolf", in which the backstage is used as cathartic device to explore the dark side of the moon.On the other hand, there's a blink respect Keaton himself "Birdman" is a cynical reference respect "Batman"; as well as the reiterative image of "The phantom of the opera" (despite I think Keaton is a superb actor who like Woody Harrelson and William Hurt have been underrated by the industry for reasons absolutely unexplainable to me) .In terms of sinister metaphores, there's a lot of them, the critic respect to action films and special effects without nothing more to say, the acidic reviewers of the recent past (Pauline Kael maybe?).Riggan is a dismissed actor who just has much more past than future, he is well aware about it and the way he has to deal with his inner demons works out as need to escape, forget his limit, participate better in this world. After all, to escape to find again.  Need to be more self in order to escape into self.How could we ignore the subtle handle of the music as crucial key to understand even better his undermined spirit?. Mahler's Ninth symbolizes the process of disolving oneself in the universe' wholeness, without forgetting Rach's Second Symphony op. 27 that reflects the bitter taste of exile from the extinct U.R.S.S. and Tchaikovsky's nostalgic second movement of his Fifth Symphony.And finally, there's a subtle homage to "Fight club" using Edward Norton as the alter ego of Keaton and starring the role of Brad Pitt respect himself.All this intense portrait told under the sign of black comedy, is a splendid device to tell the truth without the bitter taste included in the package.Watch a film whose main virtue is to say in loud voice many, many unsaid aspects of the real world backstage.

Based on an self-biographical book of Fernando Gabeira, "Four days" presents us the portrait around the kidnapping of the Noth-American Ambassador (Alan Arkin) in September 1969. Four young idealistic people decide to undertake this terrorist action in order to protest against the state of things in Brazil duriong those years.Loyalty, doubts, uncertainess tinge this superb drama from start to finish.Don't miss it:

Nicolas Winding Refn has found his place in the reduced elite of creative filmmakers in this kaleidoscopic legion of directors.He has a style that blends some of Kaurismaki's narrative lexicon, some of  Lars Von Triers' visuals,  Kubrick's travellings, and claustrophobic ambiances that made me remind Peter Brook's Marat Sade spiced with surrealistic sequences of Alexander Jodorowski and Peter Greenaway, caustic humor of Terry Gilliam and memorable close ups via Ken Russell.)Tom Hardy displays a terrific performance (with a tongue in the cheek to Alexander from The clockwise orange)in this singular and minimalist film.The musical language is another invisible actor: Bruckner and Wagner, which meant a smart device in order to avoid any reference with Beethoven's Ninth from the Clockwise.My personal advise: Watch first the Pusher's Trilogy, Drive, in order to get acquainted with Refn and then go for this one.Not for all tastes.

The novel's opening sequence is the prelude for this classical story, of infidelity amnd boredom (In the same mood of Madame Bovary, Tess and Effie Briest).The theatrical ambiance is a feast for the eye. The marevlous travellings, outdoor locations (The railroad station, the snowy forest, the glamorous opera theater or the fabulous skating park sequence are exquisite).Tamara Samoilova (The crane of flies) was probably the greatest Russian actress of her generation: to watch her is to admire her and to fall in love with her, her perfect face keeps narrow resmblance with Ava Gardner's one.The rest of the cast is impeccable, as well as the artistic direction and handle camera. In sum a sumptuous masterpiece that you shouldn't be missed.

There have been many historical recitals but this is specially superb among all of them. Sofronitzky's approach respect Scriabin runs parallel to Schnabel with Beethoven (obviously, keeping distance).Once you listen it, you will agree. Sofro had enraptured lyrical flight, melodic inventive, first -rate technique and amazing musicianship.In a nutshell, a priceless musical gem!!!

A gripping story that deals with historical events along six generations (1944- 2014) through the time, that will include Nazi officers, a besieged Norway, a missing daughter, an impatient mother.In sum, a puzzle of facts that will develop through your eyes until the very end. You will be amazed due this sinister web of control over the individual liberty, the Big Eye announced by Orwell will make its implacable presence destroying dreams, hopes and illusions.Brilliant, shocking and arresting from start to end. Liv Ullman fabulous as always in this smartly directed film.Another brilliant German filmic gem. Not to be missed.

Through all these years the Leizpig string quartet has progessively climbed an enviable among the greatest ensemble quartets of this era.Despite there are two unreachable peaks along the history The incredible reading made by The Italian quartet and the always well reminded Paolo Borciani and the excel performances of Grumiaux ensemble, if you listen to Lezipig you will be more than satisfied with the final balance. Their artistic integrity surpasses by the limits of a good lecture.Go for this one!

Jean Martinon at the front of the LPO confers them an inspirational bath of French mood.These pages are extremely light, but are played with such intensity and self-convincing attachment to the gay spirit and irresistible panache which were composed that will make you to engage from the first track.Don't miss it...

The seventh album relased by this hyper-creative band doesn't cease to amaze me. Eegee Beegee should be included among the twenty striking themes of this year. Rhytmic pulsation plus a fascinating blend of beats make it so engaging. Into the wind and Positraction are formidable tracks too.In case you're a -hard to die- fan of Four80, it's useless to recommend it. And for all those who still have no chance to know this ensemble, it's time for you to purchase it.PD. Four 80east recorded in 2007 probably the best track of Smooth Jazz genre of that year: Noodle soup.

Faith Arkin develops an absorbing film, building a dramatic chain of events that link six lives.The movie centers around two cities Bremen and Istanbul, the crude portrait of Turkish inmigration ( Fassbinder had paid tribute in his memorable film Ali: Fear eats the soul)and the way each one of these human beings play hard for what they consider their goal in this puzzled multi-cultural universe of ideologies and ways of living.Hanna Shygulla - the most relevant iconic actress of Fassbinder (in a small role) ignites the screen an captivates the audience through the second half of the film.The agile script, well handled direction and fabulous cast make of this story a motive of serious reflection about what is right and what is wrong in this unsuspected web of facts.I won't tell what's going on with the story. Get it and please watch it with a circle of friends in order to comment it after.Don't miss under no pretext. One of the filmic gems of 2007.

Arthur Honegger has always been one of the most original composers in French music. And these quartets are by themselves, one of the most unbeatable evidences.Harmonic modulations, supported by an articulated melodic flow and certain disonant twists make the rest.I'm absolutely agree with the previous review of Melvyn. Go for this album and you'll be amazed and rewarded at the same time. You won't regret it.Be my guest.

Nelson Rangell's versatility is simply amazing. In this opportunity he plays the flute with admirable results. He dared to perform two pieces of Ravel's repertoire: Pavane for a dead princess and La Tomb de Couperin. The transcriptions are admirable all the way through. But there's still more: Dizzy is a fabulous piece as well as the rest of the CD. Give yourself a try with this one and I swear you : you won't get dissapointed.Excellent purchase. Get it and make an original gift.

Antal Dorati always knew to keep a vibrant recording around practiaccly all the repertoire as long my memory may remember.In this sense, Dorati captures the energy,sensuality and drive the Gayne requests. The LSO as always giving the best of his well known performance high level.Skrowaczewski at the front of the MSO gives a well thought, impressive and amazingly expressive reading of Shos's Fifth.If you like the race-horse performance of Bernstein New York Philharmonic from 1958, definitively this version is far from being from your taste.But if you regard this work as an introspective living, where the solemnity hides the perversion, in which the Scherzo is depicted as a true dance with the devil,where the opressive Stalin's iron fist hovers the Third Movement (to my mind the gravity center of the Symphony). Finally the last movement doesn't begin as a triumphant March (a vision I don't share), but a devilish masquerade where the final won't leave you smiling, this recording is for you. Skrowac accents the percussion (generating a fabulous ritard in the last bars of the Symphony) making the finale extremely authoritative.(In fact, it's one my three best choices of Shostakovich's Fifth) If you recall Reiner's performance of  D.SH' s Sixth at the front of the Pittsburgh, the treaTment is similar.In these times, most of conductors are not well aware about the meaning of this somber feature of the work and many of them remark the crescendos as it were fireworks. I think it's not a wise choice, because the spirit in which the Op. was composed is completely divorved the audience perceives.An album that must be part of your collection. No doubt it!!!

Kontarsky brothers meant a true legend for this genre. Their contribution in this CD goes far beyond  than superlative, indeed is memorable. Among other virtues I should cite his attatchment to the spirit of the work, distinctive, elegant, propulsive, lyrical and subtle.PD. There have been another notable duos: Badura Skoda and Demus, Robert and Gaby Casadesus, Eden and Tamir, Walter and Beatriz Klien, Labecque sisters, Ferrante and Teicher. Each one of them adressed their peculiar approach to enrich the sublime beauty of this genre.An album for collectors. No doubt it!!!

Calderazzo decided to make a personal journey to the basic roots of the jazz genre. His previous experiences with the unforgettable Michael Brecker (I had the chance to watch him with Joey in the piano in Caracas 2001)and Branford Marsalis have permeated, nutrured and wrought a personal style. In the variegated scene of diverse stars of the genre, Joey has always kept a low profile, far form the crowding world if you may.This backward glance to the essence of the jazz captures him in a very intimate mood. Don't leave it aside.

The track 3 "Heartfelt" justifies by itself the purchase of this peculair album. It would seem Beasly had written an intimate journey-notebook. Loaded of intimate mood, it fits perfect for a perfect dinner for two lovers.Go for it. You won't be dissapointed.

Allan Hewitt made an impressive project that hardly may be labeled inside a genre. It's muisc in its most kaleidsocopic essence. You will be conveyed to a new dimension  where the eloquence and originality will knwock you from the very first track.Supreme is the most accurate word to qualify it. Once you listen, you'll be engaged with it. Don't doubt it.

The whole reading of these Nocturnes in hands of such prestigious interpreter couldn't be better received. His approach induces and even conveys the listener into the very core of these emblematic works, that easily could be regarded as the most intimate and revelatory among the impressive Chopin's pianistic repertoire. The elegiac feature, the elusive expression, the recondite modulations, wonderful thrills and majestic lyricism embrace literally the fundamental set of livings, memories, feelings and unsaid emotions that have wrought the human soul; Wasowski displays them with intimate delicacy, aristocratic noblesse, incorporeal poetry and illuminating phrasing.A legendary album. No doubt it!!!

Andrej Wasowski's aristocratic vein may be felt from the very first piece. His authoritative playing emanates from a inner conviction. His refinement as pianist and expression is years-light from any other pianist I have heard before.From start to finish you will be conveyed to another level of musicality. Don't doubt it and go for this extraordinary gem.To my mind the best compilation of Chopin's Mazurcas ever made!!!

Tchaikovsky Fifth Simphony by Markevitch is delusional, his phrasing and overflowing momentum. Only mercurial emotions exceeds the unsurpassed version of Koussevitzky in front of the Boston Symphony.As for the Sixth worth mentioning the extraordinary collective virtuosity of the LSO.Excellent album that should not leave out in his impressive collection.

Andre Previn built a solemn and austere performance of these well known piece. The RPO -as always-demonstrating their monumental level of execution. Limpid phrasing, astonishing articulation and penetrating sense of the most idiomatic reading I've ever heard before.Give it a try and preserve this gem for the years to come. A document of transcendental importance.

The French Minister (a ravishing Thierry  Lhermitte's performance) and his bureaucratic train, show us a crude glance around the backstage of how the speeches are prepared; of course the cinicism and smart humor are not for all tastes. But as soon you engage into the mechanism of the relentless plot whose in and outs will make you laughing.Bertrand Tavernier is a sacred monster of the French Cinema. That's why you shouldn't surprise yourself of being before such original and caustic film. The script is agile and magnificently written. The cast is another main ingredient.In sum, one of these brilliant French gems you shouldn't leave it aside.Absolutely recommended.

Alfredo Campoli was one of the first fiedler players I knew in my early youth (over the middle seventies). His playing, extremely compelling, persuasive and expressive allowed the charm and magic of the music by itself.His intonation is extremely close to Yehudi Menuhin. Go for this recording in which you will enjoy of lovable version of Mendelssohn as well a set of miniatures for violin worthy to have in order to share with your most intimate colleagues.Don't miss it.

Siglind Bruhn made a very distinguished reading of Ludus Tonalis. she plays this work keeping into account the individual significance of each variation; that's the way she achieves the key to show us the minimum facets of this clever Op. (With Bach as guide).Edward Aldwell and in minor level Robin Mc Cabe are the most essential performers of this work that it should be much more played and widely known around the musical universe.Unmissable!!!

Mijail Rudy is a prodigious piano player. His concerns include classical repertoire (I reviewed a very flaming Liszt released by Caliope label years ago) as well as modern piano literature.Pavan for a dead princess lacks of the imaginative flight of Samson Francois (The most enraptured version I know), but his performance of La valse is dynamic with sharp contrasts.Mirrors finds Rudy playing with incorporeal pianism. Ondine's reading is clear and crystalline.An album that well deserves its purchase. Once you listen it, you'll love it.No doubt it!

Dotsero has adressed a fabulous compilation of rhtyhms of diverse genre. From the Americana St. Mack's day, the well deserved homage to classic jazz with 52nd street Bliss, the jam with Steppin' outta th' Boat, you will find echoes of country music in Angel from Montgomery; you'll enjoy the funky Heart boplitation.To my view, Rubicon crosssing, Angel from Montgomery, To you my friend, Thoughts of you and Deja Vrai are my first choices, but believe me: there's no minor track and I'm willing to assert we are in presence of one of the most imaginative and original albums of the year and it shoud be among the five great albums of this year.Kudos for this sensational band. Highly inspirational.

Anatoly Vedernikov is part of the poker of aces of distinguished Soviet pianists ( the others would be to my view, Sviatoslav Richter, Tatiana Nikolayeva and Vladimir Sofronitzky.)In this opportunity Vedernikov gives us a stunning reading of the Four Temperaments; his remarkable style makes of this recording an absolute revelation.On the other hand, his performance of Hindemith's Sonata 1 is absolutely amazing and remains (with Glenn Gould and Paul Badura Skoda)as one of the most brilliant versions I remind.Finally, Vedernikov and Natalie Gutman play an irresistible and -one of its kind-version of the Cello Sonata.I wouldn't hesitate to qualify as one of the most extraordinary releases of this prestigious label.Don't miss it...

Robert Schumann personified (without leaving aside Chopin) the Romantic mood of the first half on the 19th century. He wrought unique pieces of the piano literature with a sense of feathery poetry and nocturnal lyricism.This album presents Stanislav Bunin in one of his big achievements. Childhood scenes, Aus Wien Op. 26 and Arabeske Op.18.S.B. gives the accurate balance between introspection and sublime mystery, creating the necessary atmosphere of backward nostalgia that invites us to be part of this ambiance.Peerless choice. I found it absolutely intersting. Don't miss it...

I had the chance to download (a week ago) this curious performance and I remained speechless after listening it. Ormandy's elan for Bruckner is plenty of that enraptured cosmical vision Bruckner demands. The Philadelphians as always, playing with amazing results. Subtle phrasing and superb crescendos, expressive musicality and fierceness in the most expresive moments.I still wonder why this recording dated from 1969 has not been exhumated from the vaults to make the next step: digital format.I really hope in the next two years someone proceeds to make this dream come true. For the sake of the great music.Kudos!!!

After having listened this curious gem, it's a real pity Eliane Elias had just made a simple recording around the classical universe. She has nerve and sense of the expression around every composer. Her Bach's French Suite is a blessing. And her Villalobos is loaded of Brazilian ambiance.Another acoustic pearl in her succesful artistic trajectory. Kudos by her!!!Don't leave it aside.

Around the complex and enormous universe of sax players, there's a selected and reduced list of soloists who have impressed his instrument his peculiar signature (Stan Getz, Dave Sanborn, Groove Washngton Jr, Gerald Albright, Gato Barbieri, Dave Koz, Euge Groove, Michael Lington, Warren Hill, Jack Beckstein, Jeff Kashiwa, Kim Waters, Kirk Whalum, Steve Cole, Marion Meadows and obviously Nelson Rangell).You know what I mean. You can distinguish them from the very first bars,it's to say they have wrought his singular sound.Nelson Rangell recorded this album with his well known style, Some next grace is my first-rate choice, indeed but Point of departure, Matters of the heart, Somewhere in the world and Another way are great themes.You should consider we are in the third part of the year, but even so, I would dare  to include this album as one of twenty best smooth jazz albums of the year.PD. I have not listened yet his other album Blue. Once I do it, I will let you know.Go for this one...

During the eighties there was a very succesful meeting between Uto Ughi and Wolfgang Sawalisch. Both recorded memorable versions of distin guished violin concertos, but in particular, this Schumann violin Concerto might be the cherry on the cake.Let's go by parts. Perhaps, most of you agree with the fact the supreme version of this Op 120 belongs to Szeryng Dorati. It's dynamic, powerful and incisive.But the team Ugi-Sawallisch addresses it a very fluid musicianship, loaded of vigorous commitment and deep introspection. the Bavarian Orchestra is as always convincing and shining all the way through. Musicality and overwhelming display of Romantic mood without being schmaltz.Uto Ughi is an admirable soloist. His artistic integrity and majestic intonation have become him a radiant musician.Go for this one.PD In case you get Schumann's Violin Sonatas 1 and 2 by Ughi- Sawallisch, don't think it over and purchase it. It's the best the money can buy. (It's my desert island choice)

Really a COMPLETE kit with the lithium-ion battery powered clipper (with integral hair vacuum/collection bin), 11 various length guide combs, scissors, blade oil, charger, travel pouch, cleaning brush, and hair clip.  I cut my own hair, so I'll have to supply my own mirrors.  If I may add a little as to my hair-cutting do-it-yourself credentials:  I learned in the submarine service by necessity.  Since then, I've dabbled with a few barber/salon haircuts, but mostly I've been cutting my own hair for decades.  Not for money reasons, but because I can get exactly what I want and if I don't there is no one else to blame or resent.  Over time I've became very good.  Really very good.  So I've used many home clippers over the years.  Some features of this set:The lithium-ion battery is a plus for reduction in size/weight, and battery life.  You should get at least an hour of hair cutting time per charge.  An LED indicates charge status during charging.I thought the vacuum feature might be a little gimmicky, but in fact it works pretty well.  The exception is when long hair is being cut (on top for instance), and will fall away or must be cleared away.  Ditto for scissor work, of course.  So maybe the vacuum might be a needless distraction for major hair restyling involving big length reduction - but it will probably be appreciated for regular touch-up haircuts and trimming. The vacuum adds some weight, so this clipper is heavier than other home units I've used, but not objectionably so.  And one can certainly hear the vacuum feature, but again, it's tolerable and a reasonable trade-off.Titanium-coated blades to extend blade life.  Very sharp out of the box.  Easy to pop off for cleaning.We'll have to see how long it holds up, but for now this seems like a nice complete set for any level of home use.

Part of the territory that comes with being over 60 . . . occasional indigestion and GI/colon health concerns.  I prefer homeopathic and dietary supplement options to medical or invasive options and my reading research indicated that taking a probiotic supplement was an excellent choice for me. I had been procrastinating making a purchase choice, but when this Viva Labs Advanced Bioactive Probiotics product became available (via a promotional product evaluation program), this was a no brainer choice.To be honest, supplements such as this  probiotics are not medicine and results are not immediate.  I'm only a few days into this, but my reading suggests that there is absolutely benefit to be had here (GI tract health) and Viva Labs is a trusted name that I have long experience with.  The Viva proprietary blend contains 25 billion CFU per dose (1 capsule).  The blend contains 6 friendly bacteria strains targeted to colonize the GI tract.  Also contains Viva "BioXtend" technology to help protect the product in the stomach and ensure that more is delivered safely to the lower GI tract.  I look forward to great positive results here and have no reason to expect otherwise (but will edit my review accordingly as appropriate over time).A dose consists of one or two capsules (they are small) daily, with or without a meal.  I should mention - I take a wide array of supplements (to which I credit to my excellent health for a senior), however, I don't always take every supplement every day.  But that is not my routine with the probiotic.  The bacteria colonization is progressive and cumulative and should be supported by regular daily supplement intake.  My Viva Probiotics bottle resides on my computer desk to make sure I never miss  a day.  As I said, I'm looking forward to positive observable results.

I'm over 60 and have zero joint pain issues - including complete surgery free recovery from a nasty heel/ankle fracture sustained a few years ago (I fell off a roof). I am a years long Glucosamine and Chondroitin user. 'Nuff said.But to add some thoughts Glucosamine and Chondroitin are widely, widely believed to contribute to joint health, as well as nail an hair health (I still have a full head of hair). This Vita Labs product provides 750 mg of Glucosamine Sulfate and 600 my of Chondroitin Sulfate in each 2 capsule dose. The dose also contains 500 mg of Methlsulfonlmethane (MSM) - a sulphur based agent which supports the effectiveness of the Glucosamine and Chondroitin. Labeled dosage is 2 capsules twice daily with or without food. No side effects. Made in USA.Nice combination here from a highly reputable brand name. Easy to recommend as a regular supplement.

I'm over 60 and have zero joint pain issues - including complete surgery free recovery from a nasty heel/ankle fracture sustained a few years ago (I fell off a roof).  I am a years long Glucosamine and Chondroitin user.  'Nuff said.But to add some thoughts Glucosamine and Chondroitin are widely, widely believed to contribute to joint health, as well as nail an hair health (I still have a full head of hair).  This Vita Labs product provides 750 mg of Glucosamine Sulfate and 600 my of Chondroitin Sulfate in each 2 capsule dose.  The dose also contains 500 mg of Methlsulfonlmethane (MSM) - a sulphur based agent which supports the effectiveness of the Glucosamine and Chondroitin.  Labeled dosage is 2 capsules twice daily with or without food.  No side effects.  Made in USA.Nice combination here from a highly reputable brand name.  Easy to recommend as a regular supplement.

CoQ10 is presently quite trendy (and justifiably so) as an antioxidant and agent for, cardiovascular support via cholesterol control.  This Viva Labs offering contains a proprietary black pepper fruit extract ("BioPerine") which contributes to more efficient absorption.  Packaged as a small black softgel - goes down exceedingly easily with no aftereffects.  Recommended one per day with a meal.  A very good version of a very effective supplement - and from a known reputable source.

These PROFOOT Dura-Soles are as comfortable as any insole I've ever tried.  Noticeable padding at heel and toe.  Nice, but not too much, arch support. All USA made, which I like.  Claims to "meet all military guidelines".  A couple of reservations . . . .These are claimed to fit  sizes 8 through 14.  I'm not sure they will go that big. I'm size 11 to 11 1/2.  Right out of the package each insole is right at 12" long.  I trimmed some off the toe (nearly an inch?), but I'd be surprised if this insole would have filled up a size 14.  Also, if one is at either end of the range (at size 8 or at size 14), wouldn't the arch support be possibly out of place?  I'm just speculating that for a buyer with feet at either end of the range, maybe he might also consider buying a brand offering a more targeted size range.Also, these seem to be rather wide (well over 3" at the arch).  Works very nicely in the steel toed work boots I'm using them for, but appears a bit wide for a dress shoe (there's always the trimming option).  All applications and user needs differ.  In some cases these would be a nice addition on top of the original insole, in others they could replace a worn out or inferior original, in others they may simply help take up some space in a boot that fits too big.As with all aftermarket insoles, don't be in a hurry when trimming for the initial sizing.  Test it in the shoe or boot well, and be willing to make several small adjustments rather than just relying on the sizing guide and accidentally trimming off too much.In summary, as I said, these are as comfortable as any add-on insole I've tried.  Thin but effective.  American made.  Rather wide (but comfortable), and maybe slightly too "one-size-fits-all".

Excellent pair of dress trousers.  My 36x32 pair is a perfect fit.  The navy color is very dark - near black.  100% Polyester material is lightweight and cool.  Very comfortable and would be exceptionally comfortable for hot weather wear.100% poly is also fairly easy-care.  Machine wash cold, tumble dry at low temp.  These came out looking super.  This material also travels well in a suitcase or travel bag.Finally, these pants are nicely done.  Flat front (which I prefer) and non-cuffed (which I prefer).  Buttons are tight, no loose threads, beautiful hemming (near invisible).I can't find one negative with these -- they've likely become may new favorite pair of dress / semi-dress slacks.

These did not go over all that well.  One of our two dogs wouldn't eat it.  The other did, but without usual treat gusto.  So I even tried a little piece (as I usually do with these product evaluations).  Dog biscuits never really taste "good" (to a human), but these are exceptionally bland. Not a future purchase choice in our home.  Some data . . .Each tan-colored biscuit is about 2.5"x1".  Hard and crunchy - several in the package were broken.  The first five ingredients listed are:  Wheat Flour.  Chicken by-product.  Dried beet pulp.  Chicken fat.  Natural chicken flavor.  Shelf life appears to be a little more than a year.  Not sure where this is manufactured at.  I found one certification/endorsement listed on the bag:  ". . . formulated to meet the nutritional levels established by the AAFCO Dog Food Nutrient Profiles for Maintenance."  Package says, 35 kcal per treat.

An absolutely delicious snack (except I had difficulty stopping).  Each "cluster" is about the size of a cherry.  It's freeze dried, and therefore light and airy and crunchy.  But not hard and not dangerous to the teeth.  Flavor is full and tart, but not sour.  Delicious.Packaged in a foil bag containing 1.25 ounces of the snack clusters (freeze-drying makes them very light in weight).  Estimated as  "3 servings" (was 2 servings in my case).  120 calories in the whole bag.  Ingredients listed are: Fuji apples, Raspberries, fruit pectin, and apple juice concentrate.  Date stamp indicates about a one year use-by date.  A whole gaggle of certifications:  gluten free, peanut free, kosher, non-GMO, HACCP, OHSAS 18001, ISO 9001, SGS, CIQ.  Product of USA, Chile, China, and/or Mexico.  Would I buy this? . . . YES.

Personally, I support "green", but not at the cost of reduced product quality or increased product cost  (I know this is not a popular position, but it's my choice).  Where do these Energizer EcoAdvanced batteries fit in? . . .The advertised shelf storage life is 12 years.  That is excellent (if true), and is important to me and a real plus.  They are made from about 4% recycled battery material - another plus.  These are priced higher than traditional alkalines - a negative for me.  And finally, how do they perform?Seems to be inferior.  I burned through a couple in my digital camera noticeably faster than even bargain brand alkaline AAA's that I've tried.  I relegate the rest of this EcoAdvanced package to low drain tasks like remote controls.  Maybe another good place would be the little emergency flashlight in my glove box, due to the long shelf life.In summary, I just don't see me paying more for a battery that delivers less service life (the 4% recycled content is not that important to me).  So, I don't plan on purchasing these.

Not cheap, but a good long term investment.  LED not likely to burn out with use, or fail if dropped (the original bulb will almost always break if dropped when lit . . . and they are not cheap either.  Produces a nice even bright white.  Three brightness settings (just click the switch button to cycle through).  GREATLY extends battery charge life -- will run for hours on the lowest setting.  Easy to install.  For a person willing to buy a hundred dollar Magcharger flashlight, this is a logical follow-up purchase.
Too small.  Split open when I tried to make it fit. Will only buy the OEM from now on.

Very nice looking shirt.  Accurate fit (mine is a 15.5 34/35), although proportioned on the slim side.  (I'm not quite an athletic build any more, but I'm not overweight either, and appreciate the trim cut).  Although slim, it's not short on length, with sleeves and tail cut  generously.  The 60/40 cotton/poly blend is light and soft, but still presents a crisp wrinkle-free appearance.  All buttons firmly attached, with sturdy gusseting around button-holes.  Nice finishing at collar and sleeve openings.  The spread collar is a new experience for me, but it invites a "no tie" day.  No stray threads.  Machine wash cold. This shirt does not have a breast pocket, which I'll miss.  Made in Bangladesh.  In all -- a very nice looking, nice feeling, and well finished shirt.

Was able to put this bottle to use on a 3 year old grandson (the dosage label covers age ranges from 6 months through 3 years -- younger than that consult a physician).  He just has something coming on in the early stages with noticeable coughing.  This reduced the frequency of coughing and he "said he felt better".  Maybe.  Although I've personally used their Hyland's 4 Kids Cold and Cough Relief Liquid on myself and clearly received relief. My results were observable and excellent.There is a great little dosing syringe included in the box, marked in 1/2 mL increments from 1.0 through 5.0.  Very handy.  This stuff tastes great, with no unpleasant taste or alcohol burn (it's less than 0.1% alcohol). No taste complaints or sour faces at all from my 3 year old.  Hyland's has a loyal following and an excellent reputation. Repeating, my own experience with their cough and cold syrup was totally satisfactory, and this Hyland's Baby Cough Syrup is yielding fine results on the 3 year old.Some labeling observations:  Dye free. Free of artificial colors/flavors. Homeopathic.  Just trace alcohol content (LT 0.01%). Made in USA.

Received this bottle and went on the lookout for a cold in the family . . . with no success (thankfully).  However, a couple of weeks ago, I did a review on Hyland's 4 Kids Cold and Cough Relief Liquid with a family member suffering from a classic cold (runny nose, sore throat/ears, runny nose).  The victim was me, an adult.  But the Hyland's children's products also include an adult dose in the instructions.  The adult dose for this Childrens Cold n' Mucus formula is the same as for their 4 Kids Cold and Cough Relief Liquid, 15 mL.  My results were observable and excellent. I expect no less from this Cold n' Mucus syrup.There is a handy measuring cup on top clearly marked in divisions of teaspoons and milliliters. I tried a 15 ML dose. This stuff tastes great, with no unpleasant taste or alcohol burn (it's less than 0.1% alcohol).  Hyland's has a loyal following and an excellent reputation.  Repeating, my experience with their cough and cold syrup was totally satisfactory.Some labeling observations: Sugar free. Dye free.  Free of artificial colors/flavors. Homeopathic. Stimulant effect free. Just trace alcohol content (LT 0.01%).  Made in USA.

An interesting new technology.  My prior humidifier experience has been with traditional steam or traditional cold mist type devices.  Both of those can leave a wet area in the vicinity of the humidifier as the moisture condenses or simply falls after leaving the unit.  Not the case here, as this unit operates on the principle of an internal wick, which becomes saturated with water supplied by the refillable water reservoir.  A circulating fan forces air past this wick, and the moisture evaporates into the passing air and leaves the unit.  Thus the moist air is not oversaturated after exiting, and does not condense and leave a damp mess in the area.  Additionally . . .The wick also acts as a filter, cleaning out impurities as the air passes.  And, unlike the steam or cold mist units, this one is inherently self-regulating . . . as humidity in the room increases, the evaporative action will decrease.  Conversely as ambient air becomes drier, evaporation speeds up and humidifier output naturally increases.  A neat idea.Maintenance issues:  #1, like all humidifiers, the reservoir will become slimy and nasty if not periodically cleaned (simple enough).  And, #2, the wick/filter here will slowly accumulate dust it has filtered and will also accumulate impurities in the water left after evaporation.  That will cause the filter to become hard and ineffective.  It will eventually have to be replaced.  I checked, and these replacements are readily available on Amazon (series WF2 and I've already ordered one).  Replacement filter prices start at about $10.  Both OEM and aftermarket brands are available.Finally, about operating the filter.  Easy to fill:  The reservoir lifts off and has a screw on cap.  Easy to change the wick/filter:  the body of the filter (which contains the fan mechanism) lifts easily off the base, exposing the wick.  Fan is 2-speed - and the low speed is so quiet that it's nearly inaudible.

I received these at no cost as part of a product evaluation program - so I'm not complaining.  But . . . these are the lightest, most cheaply made, smallest, thinnest, and least absorbent new dishtowel I've ever handled.  We've got old frayed worn out towels in the kitchen drawer that are more substantial than these.The purple/white color scheme is quite attractive.  But, unless you need a small 12"x12" set of dishtowels for display in the kitchen, I just can't recommend these.  At all.

Nice moisturizing action.  A very delicate cream consistency, rubs and absorbs in quickly, leaving no oily sensation behind - just softness.  Made in USA.  Neutral odor.  Paraben free.  Gluten free.  Non-GMO.  Vegan friendly and no animal testing.

I like Hefty kitchen trash bags and am a long time user.  This is my first experience with this new "Renew 65% Recycled Plastic" bag.  How does it work?  Well, I really can't tell the difference from a traditional bag (i.e. this one works great).Visually, this Renew bag is gray in color with a blue tie handle.  I am 100% OK with that (it's a garbage bag).  No "odor-control" feature.  I'm OK with that, since,  #1 we have and use a garbage disposal unit for most foodstuffs, and,  #2 once the bag is tied shut any odor issue disappears.Regarding the recycled plastic factor . . . I like it, but personally, I will not pay a price premium on the purchase of a recycled plastic TRASH BAG (the bag itself represents very little actual bulk, but it's a good use for crude gray-colored recycled plastic).  Right now, the price offered on this box is 28 cents higher than a 45-count box of Hefty Tall Kitchen Odor Block bags.  I buy by price/performance, so I'd purchase the Odor Blocker over these.  And a final recycling note - I checked, and the paperboard box the bags come in is made from 100% recycled paperboard.  Good.In any case, no surprises here.  No bag blowouts, or tie handles that break off. Each bag comes off the roll individually, with no need to tear it off at perforations. Good quality bag at a (usually) fair price.

An interesting configuration for a dog treat . . . each Nutri Dent treat is a 3-pronged shape that can easily be broken up into two or three pieces.  This works well in the case of my two small dogs, where I give them a 1/3 section each, per serving.  This is a rather pricey treat, so dividing it up for smaller dogs will help stretch out the life of a package (as well as avoiding excessive treat feeding).I won't rewrite all the ingredients, as the reader can find it elsewhere in these reviews.  It's enough to point out: Made in USA.  No artificial preservatives, etc.  Bears the "Veterinarian Recommended" seal.  Purports to promote dental and breath condition.  And finally, how do the dogs like them??Both of my treat spoiled dogs (6 year old Pekanese mix, 12 year old Jack Russell mix) absolutely love them.  Love them.  They initially explored the strange texture/odor, then tore in with genuine gusto.  This treat is a real hit.

This is a 7.8 oz package (slightly under half a pound) containing 17 meat sticks, each about 4 1/2" long and the diameter of a pinky finger.  The sticks do indeed appear to be "deli-style", with outer skins tied off at each end and a friendly beef-stick aroma not unlike what you'll find in the people food variety.A few labeling proclamations:  No corn or wheat or soy.  All natural and grain free.  Premium USA beef.  Free of fillers, rich in protein.  No animal by-products.  No artificial colors, flavors, preservatives.  Made in the USA.The ingredients list:  Beef, salt, sugar, citric acid, cultured dextrose, paprika, black pepper, garlic powder.Sounds good enough to eat, huh?  So I did.  I selected a stick and bit the end off.  Mmmm.  I did it again.  My impressions:  Less sodium than the typical "people food" beef stick.  High fat content (you can feel it lingering on your tongue).  I can taste a wee bit of that black pepper (pleasant sensation).  In all, and considering that this is a dog treat, unbelievably good.  These could easily serve as snack food (for me).  But that sounds kind of sick and I'd be cheating my two small elderly dogs - so they're getting the rest.  By the way, the package does prescribe consuming or refrigerating within 3 days of open (for freshness).  I'll do that.And of course, how do my dogs like it?  Well, for the first time in a dog food/treat review, I'm going to go ahead and post the review before ever giving the treat to my dogs.  I know them and I know that they're going to absolutely love these (especially if they see/smell that I've been there first).

This is my 3rd version of the review on this product -- each time I keep subtracting a star.  Now, after a few uses, my latest opinion . . . .When I opened the shipping box, the fragrance hit me.  I thought;  #1 this is sun tanning lotion (it's not, it's the NUXE Prodigieax Shower Oil), and, #2 this must have spilled open during shipment (it didn't, it was still completely sealed).Out of the tube, this is a rather thick amber gel infused with micro-size gold metallic "shimmer" particles.  The gold disappears under the shower as the gel diffuses (with very little lather).  Initially a brief pleasant fragrance as I do my face.  As I spread down away from my face the odor mysteriously transforms to what I can best compare to tire rubber.  Old tire rubber.  It's not a good scent.  I did not find the product on the skin to be at all "oily", and rinsing was easy and complete, with no residue sensation.After drying my skin felt clean, and reasonably soft and moisturized.  The very light residual scent was simply a soap-like fragrance that smelled clean and was not unpleasant.  It lingers for a few hours.  There was also a residual softness.  I realize that means that some moisturizing agent, along with a fragrance agent, was left behind on my skin after rinsing.  I'm OK with all that.I guess my main complaint is that horrible in shower smell.  But it goes away.An acceptable product in my opinion.  I'm not raving about it and will probably use it intermittently, for a change of pace.

Yes, surprisingly good.  The packaging cleverly incorporates a lift out cup for pouring on the marinara sauce after heating, while keeping the pasta section enclosed so that it steams while heating.  Although I found the marinara a little too tart for my taste (just a matter of preference), I was really pleasantly surprised by the penne pasta.  It was like just boiled.  In fact it was better than my usual pasta preparation efforts.  Next time I may even dress it up a little cheese.  This stuff is very, very good for an instant, no refrigeration, microwave entree'.  And 100% natural with no preservatives.

About the artwork:  I have been a many-time visitor to Israel and can never get enough of the wonder of Jerusalem.  Thus, my past Hebrew calendar purchases have generally leaned toward photographic art from Jerusalem and Eretz Israel.  This time,  I've tried this "The Jewish Eye" paintings artwork calendar and I'm not disappointed.  In fact I'm delighted!  Beautiful artist renderings of scenes from The City, and The Land, many of which I specifically recognize.  An added treat is the artist's commentary provided in a paragraph below each painting.  This will be a great source of enjoyment and meaningful reflection during the coming year.About the calendar part:  EXACTLY what I want!  Not too much, but in addition to Hebrew dates, it does include candle lighting/Havdalah times (based on sunset times),  Rosh Chodesh (new moon), Biblical Feast days and so forth.  Also included (and I want these), are the traditional American holidays such as Labor Day and Thanksgiving, AND Daylight Savings Time  dates.  Things I use.The perfect calendar for me this year!!!

Men, don't be scared away by the name.  I'm a senior aged male, and actually, Vitamin World does offer an Ultra Man variety (and targeting my demographic more specifically - an Ultra Man Fifty Plus).  But there's nothing in Ultra Woman that is contraindicated for men.  Now, getting on with Ultra Woman . . . .An outstanding comprehensive profile of vitamins and minerals.  Outstanding.  Too extensive to list here, but I can summarize that it's generally a full daily value of all essential vitamins and minerals, with a little heavier allotment of Vitamin C (333%), Vitamin D (500%), and mega-doses of the various B-Vitamins.  Everything that I can think of and in generally in full dosage (only a few minerals are less than 100%).Recommended serving is 2 caplets daily, preferably with a meal.  These caplets are largish (bordering on "horse pill" size), but coated.  With a big gulp of water, they'll go down.  Barely.Timed release.  NO: artificial colors, preservatives, sugar, gluten, wheat yeast, fish.  It does contain a little milk product. Expiration date on the package I received is over 2 1/2 years away.I feel great when taking these (but I usually feel great as I am a lifetime vitamin supplement user).  These are a great premium multi-supplement (even for men).

These reviews seen to be "crossing over" between teams.  Sorry for any confusion . . . not my fault . . . but all these cup are the same except for the school art so . . . .  I received the University of Oklahoma, Oklahoma Sooners plastic cup, by Reynolds/Hefty.  Very importantly right off the bat:  The colors are right on . . . a correct rendition of Sooners crimson.  The white cup color is an authorized substitute for cream.  This is an Officially Licensed Collegiate Product.Other pluses:  The opaque white cup provides some drink privacy.  Two-sided (Sooners logo on one side, "OU" on the other).  Decent sturdy strength (Hefty style).  Made in USA.  Cups and the bag they come in all recyclable (packaged in bag of 28 stacked cups - my shipment contained three bags for a total of 84 cups).If the price is OK with you, then I can find nothing negative to report on here.  Nice looking quality cups will add some fun and spirit to tailgating or Saturday afternoon TV football.

My Tile is on my key ring.  No more lost keys . . . or lost phone. Tile (Gen 2) can be activated from my phone to sound off and help me locate lost keys - or - pressing the hidden button on Tile will cause my phone (in Bluetooth range) to sound off.  As simple as that.  Works the same for a wallet, purse, wandering favorite stuffed animal, remote control, etc.  The Tile has a hole for putting it on a key ring.  I suppose you could attach it to about anything else using a small zip-tie.  For a remote, you could use double-sided tape.  The double-sided tape method would also work on a can of beer.Set up is easy:  Download the App on your iPhone (or Android) and follow the step-by-step.  Non-replaceable battery is guaranteed for one year.  Internal speaker is loud enough to hear from within the same room.  Acceptably compact at 1 7/16" x 1 7/16" x 7/16".  Water resistant.I'll probably buy a couple of more of these as a creative gift idea that is useful to about anyone.  I haven't misplaced my keys yet since hooking on the Tile, but I can't wait!

This is just perfect as an age 2 birthday gift for our youngest grandson.  Smaller than other Power Wheels type toys we've had in the past -- but is properly tailored for the target ages 1 through 3.  Rides low, so is easy to mount/dismount with a low center of gravity to prevent tip overs.  Simple push-the-button operation to make it go (let up to stop).  A 2 year old can catch on pretty quickly.  Steering is via handlebars rather than a steering wheel, which seems to be more intuitive for a little one to learn (a skill already learned on his tricycle).  Speed is a slow/safe advertised 2 mph with plenty of power and good battery life (charge for at least 18 hours prior to presenting).  Assembly is easy and mostly snap together.  And all the aesthetic flash of PAW Patrol!In all, this Fisher-Price Power Wheels PAW Patrol Lil' Quad(tm) lives up to the standards we've enjoyed over the years from Fisher-Price, raising both our two kids and now enjoying our six grandsons.  As far as this toy goes . . . No disappointments, I think.

This has turned out to be a wonderful APP-driven RC toy car set.  Goal is to destroy the opponent car.  The "opponent" can be either Player 2, or, the AI (artificial intelligence) computer opponent.  Works on any reasonable surface in the house, garage floor, patio, etc.  The APP is free.  You'll need an IPhone or Android with Bluetooth enabled.  Pairing could not be easier (just hold the phone over the car).  Each car powered by 4 AA batteries.  Loading the batteries will require a Phillips screwdriver for the cover.  Battery life seems excellent (still on the first set after hours).  You'll probably have to recharge your iPhone before replacing the batteries.  With all that technical stuff out of the way, let me get on to the highlight, which is the play action . . . .SUPER!  Control is very quick and sensitive but kids will catch on fast.  Expect dads (and moms) to probably get hooked too.  The AI opponent is very smart and effective, so this is a wonderful play alone toy.  And this is not the kind of toy that the kids are likely to tire of and set aside - it's actually the converse; play will breed more interest and play.Box is labeled for ages 8+.  And they'll need a smartphone with the APP download.  I want to let my grandsons log some more play time with these, and I'll be back with any needed comments on breakage, problems, quirks, etc.  For now, a great and very popular toy.

Simple lightweight plastic construction.  With the plastic stopper in the end (soft foam orange-colored tip), the "shooter" simply strokes back on the barrel slide and the stopper ejects with a distinct POP.A real improvement here over the models from my ancient childhood is the reloading process.  The stopper lanyard is threaded down the barrel - so after shooting, when the barrel is re-extended, the slack in the lanyard is taken up and the stopper is drawn right back into the "loaded" position.  The shooter can fire this literally in rapid-fire style without ever having to touch the stopper.Fun and inexpensive.  Guaranteed to get some playing time.  Recommended for ages 4 and up.
Sure, there's some sugar here, but I add sugar anyway, to ANY cereal.  No cholesterol.  No fat.  No gluten issues.  Famous wonderful taste.  5 stars.

Cottonelle is a favorite in our house.  Strength + Softness + Fair Price (usually).  And this Aloe and Vitamin E version adds an extra dimension of comfort (and health?).  It's our favorite.  Only criticism -- these are standard size small rolls and this Amazon purchase was not the usual bargain price I'm used to for Cottonelle.  Better bargains elsewhere.
A venerable trusted name.  It works.  Great price.
I've used many, many of these.  They last as long as ANY alkaline AA out there and are the best value I've found.  Highly recommended.

I've loved this stuff for decades.  There are competing brands (including one from a "Chef . . .") but they taste like dog food.  Ravioios has a nice tangy sauce and is reasonably meaty.It's canned convenience food, but very good for what it is.  Serving suggestion:  Add several ounces of browned ground beef before heating - fantastic!
Quite simply, for the money you can't beat this.  There a some cheaper options, but they don't taste good.  This Folgers is a great combination of taste and price.

I'm very impressed.  If the manufacturer/labeling here are telling the truth (and I have no reason to doubt their honesty at this point), this is a true premium dry dog food.  To be clear, I'm reviewing the "Wellness CORE Large Breed Original Formula Grain Free" product.  The information on the bag overflows with various commendable claims.  More that I can reproduce here, but among them . . . .Protein rich deboned chicken and chicken/turkey meal.  No meat by-products or fillers.  Optimum fat/calories.  Gluten and grain free.  Contains; antioxidants, Omegas, glucosamine, probiotics.  Added vitamins & minerals.  No artificial colors, preservatives, etc.  Made in USA.The ingredients list is also very long.  Lots of good stuff.  No red flags.  I'll list the first 5 ingredients: Deboned chicken, chicken meal, turkey meal, potatoes, and peas.Opening the bag - you'll need a pair of scissors.  But once you've got it open there is a nice resealing closure strip.  The odor?  OK, dry dog food-like and not at all offensive or repugnant.  This product is targeted for "large breed" dogs, but that has to do with the formulation of the product, not the kibble size - which are rather triangular shaped and about 1/2" in diameter (not remarkably large).  As is my practice (as long as as the ingredients do not contain anything prohibited by my own biblically-compliant diet), I selected a few morsels and ate them . . . .Very good in reference to the dry dog food arena.  Meaty with a remote suggestion of fish.  No bland cardboard-like flavor as often experienced in dry foods. As a dry dog food, this is rather tasty and I can see where dogs would like this.  I tried it out on my two senior mixed breeds.  They are a bit smaller than the 50 pound entry level suggestion on the bag, but their usual diet has such wide variety, I have no personal reservation in trying them on this Wellness CORE Larger Breed.  How did they like it?I first presented a kibble to each dog "treat style".  They regarded it like a treat and asked for more.  In the food dish, I mixed in the Wellness with their usual dry food.  As I expected, they are fishing out the Wellness and leaving the other (which is a premium food also).  I expect the new will eventually wear off, but for now, they are hooked.Great dry food has it all - taste, wholesome ingredients, added nutrients.  It's not cheap, but this seems to represent the "get what you pay for" principle.

Name says it all . . . Lancaster Vanilla and Caramel Soft Crmes Candy.  Delicious, creamy, and soft.  Chew 'em or let 'em melt in your mouth.  No dental work concerns (I have crowns and was not at all in peril with these).Individually wrapped (but not sealed, the wrap comes off easily).  Around 17 pieces per 4 ounce bag.  Around 25 calories per piece.  Made by The Hershey Company, in Canada.  Best by date is about a year.

So how do you improve a blow dryer?  (it's just a hand held hot air gun).  Really, there's not much left, but Remington has went all in on this D8700 T/Studio PROtect - and there are a few things here that are "new".The aquamarine tinted body looks great and the soft touch button controls feel great.  It's 1875 watts, which is the absolute maximum wattage you'll find in a blow dryer.  Three heat levels and two fan speeds (enough).  Easy to use Cold Shot button.  This one uses an ionic ceramic heating technology which mitigates local peak temperatures at the outlet and reduces that burning effect.This is kind of gimmicky, but there is a removable/replaceable "exclusive conditioning ring" which "releases micro-conditioners" (macadamia nut oils) as you dry.  Sounds ok.  I think it works, but I'm not sure, as I use good shampoo and conditioning products and am usually happy with after drying results with ANY dryer.  The kit includes a couple of different shaped concentrating/diffusing heads (I prefer the open dryer nozzle), and the box includes a nice conditioning hairbrush (labeled a $10 value).  There's a soft hanging loop (there's a new idea).*** The one improvement that I really do like is the removable rear grill.  Now, when the air intact starts to become blocked with dust and hair, I can slip off this grill, wash it clean, and reinstall easily.  This is a really important improvement that helps keep air flow up, and thus outlet temperature down (no burning), and greatly increases dryer life.Nice dryer.  Blows hot air with the best of 'em.  Looks and feels nice.  Not too heavy.  A few improvements (some real, some maybe).  This one can last longer that your old one if you keep that removable screen clean.  I received this one complimentary as part of a product evaluation program, and there is currently no offer price posted on Amazon, so I'll have to let the future potential buyer weight that decision.

This is a pretty good muesli.  Mostly toasted oats, sugar added, and then a variety of various seeds/nuts/fruits.  This is marketed as the"Blueberry" variety, but don't expect to be overwhelmed by the blueberry flavor.  Again - this is mostly toasted oats - but the mix of other ingredients does make for a pretty tasty product.A few other thoughts:  I only eat mine cold and with milk and a little added sugar, so I base my favorable comment on that serving choice.  This 11 ounce bag is EXPENSIVE.  Fortunately, this is a very compact and filling type of cereal, so you don't need a full to overflowing bowl as you might with, say, a puffed rice type cereal containing lot s of air and low density material.  This type of product also lends itself to adding more or other ingredients yourself, right into the bag or your bowl (nuts, fruits, etc.)This is indeed one of the better muesli products - not the best I've eaten, but it is highest priced.  Sorry for the drumbeat about price, but it is, unfortunately, going to prevent future purchases by our household (we're too frugal).  Maybe if you are a real muesli fiend, it may be worth it?  A personal choice.

Great price.  Great "grilled chicken" smell.  Our dogs both love 'em.  Not the most nutritious thing out there, but USA made and safe enough for regular inclusion into the treat mix.  And again, the price - this is probably the best value we've found for a safe treat that they actually REALLY LIKE!

Our spoiled elderly dogs get a wide variety of treats and foods - whatever they desire (within reasonable limits).  However, these Meaty Bones have a special place in their routine.  It's their "good morning" breakfast treat, EVERY morning.  We have to be careful and keep these on hand as they are a bit disconcerted when they do not get their morning Meaty Bone.Made in USA.  Priced reasonably.  Not a substitute for quality dog food, but we've been using it for years as a morning treat with no health issues whatsoever.

Hey, it's Windex!  Can't beat it for windows, and I use it widely on appliances, sinks, automobiles, in the bathroom and so forth.  Ammonia free, so it smells pleasant and is not harsh. Speaking of "smell", this Crystal Rain variety is indeed a nice scent.All good.  No bad.

I'm not going to wax on for paragraphs about a can of dog food, but I'll make 3 points:1.  Opening the can, I was not offended by the smell - which is not unlike that of canned beef stew, and such other people foods.2.  The ingredients list is too long to reproduce here, but I'll list the first 5 items:  chicken broth, chicken, chicken liver, beef liver, ground rice.  Thus, one can see this is heavy on the meat and light on the corn and wheat.  In fact, it contains no corn or wheat - but it does contain a wide array of vitamin supplements.3.  My two spoiled dogs absolutely loved it.  LOVED IT!A premium dog food.  Nothing scary here, and (apparently) the taste is sublime.

I've owned one OtterBox Defender previously, installed on an earlier iPhone 4.  This current design for the Galaxy S6 Active is fundamentally the same yet upgraded to be more stylish and sleeker.  That is . . . stylish and sleeker compared to earlier OtterBox cases . . . this  heavy duty case is necessarily rather bulky and heavy compared to light slimline cases.Acknowledging the Defender trade-off adding bulk/weight, the only other design feature I don't like is the high rim surrounding the screen, which can get in the way of touch screen access near the edges.  The model doesn't seem as bad as my memory of the earlier one on my iPhone, however.If you are familiar with the Defender line, you know it gives great protection, with a soft rubbery inner slip-on, a rigid outer case,  and its own built-in screen/lens protection.  And, of course, the floating buttons all function great.  As usual, installation is not as quick as lesser cases, ESPECIALLY if you are unfamiliar with the Defender.Comes with a belt clip.  Assembled in China.  Mine's a nice neutral medium gray with white accents - attractive case.

I love this stuff in the shower.  Tis is a bar soap with a bold clean fragrance that reminds me something of Irish Spring.  Creamy, but there are distinct scrubbing granules throughout.  The granules are widely dispersed and I don't find them at all harsh like a Lava type hand soap or a women's exfoliating bar.  Stimulates and cleans without beating up your skin.  A very pleasant sensation -- leaves you feeling clean and smelling great.  No exaggeration here to say that this is probably the best soap product I've used for everyday showering.If I may add . . . lately I've tried and reviewed several products from the new Dove Men + Care line.  The Dove folks really did their homework on this product line. Without fail, I've been remarkably impressed by the product every time.  This Body and Face Bar continues the excellent experience.

These seem to be true to size at a boy's 12 Husky.  This is a lightweight denim fabric.  By look and touch, I thought it was the stretch denim material common to women's jeans, but it's not.  This is a 82/18% cotton polyester blend.  This light cool fabric lends itself well to hot weather comfort.  It does not stretch, although there are built-in elastic stretch tabs in the waistband that function to provide a little stretch in the waist.The color is a very dark indigo, with just a bit of light distress fading built into the front thigh area.  The length is just right (in my opinion), extending down 11 inches from the crotch intersection (I don't care for "shorts" that extend down to the calves). Traditional jeans button style front waist closure, and a sturdy brass zipper fly.Very nice looking, well-made shorts at a cost savings over some of the other popular denim brands.

I received the 3 lb (48 oz) package as advertised.  My two spoiled, senior-age dogs absolutely love these.  We've been buying these for a couple of years now, they each get one at bedtime and it's still the highlight of their day.  The dog's love 'em and they have remained in fine health while enjoying these.  These are one of the less expensive chicken jerky options and are American made, thus: 5 stars from us.

The clocks on my old school room walls were in steel cases, had glass bezels, and electromechanical movements.  And they audibly ticked.  This Tempus Contemporary Commercial Wall Clock is all plastic and has a battery powered quartz movement.  But it does audibly tick.  And it does have that same imposing "all business" look of those old school clocks.You can't tell from the photo, but it's also "thick" - the face is probably standing out a couple inches from the wall.  Mine is on the wall in the family gym.  It keeps perfect time, has a great look, and at this price . . . no complaints.

A nice light-bodied, mildly-scented conditioner.  Fragrance is citrus?  I'm male with longish hair, light natural wave, and thinning a bit from age.  Application of this Tresemme Perfectly unDone left my hair soft and slippery (avoid extended warm water rinsing).  Combing and air drying did indeed result in more natural wave that I normally see.  The great result only stays around for a day or so, but that's typical for me.  One of the better conditioners I've used, and priced very economically.

STROKE OF MIDNIGHT was a stroke of PNR genius! If you are looking for a GO-TO author in this genre, Lara Adrian is your woman!
