Michelle knows her will need her all her her skills whether they be medical, intellectual, or sexual.  Slater writes the hottest, most explicit literotica on the market.  Slater writes so well.  His characters are multifaceted, his story lines are filled with just as much excitement and suspense as they are with sex.  "Intensive Care" is amazing.

A carefree quasi-hippie girl goes on a blind date arranged through a dating site and ends up hooking up with a masculine Navy Seal.  The morning after is a bit awkward, but neither one can deny or resist the strong attraction they feel for each other.  Unfortunately, the Seal gets sent to Afghanistan.  When he returns to Germany, he informs the girl that he must move back to the US permanently and wants her to return with him.  The story itself doesn't have a lot of twists and turns, there's no doubt in the reader's mind what will happen, but the story earns the 5 star rating by delivering some of the hottest, paint peeling sex ever committed to a story.  It is vividly described and very arousing.  If you like military romances filled with hot, hot, hot sex, this is definitely for you.

Tirza Schaefer writes literotica like no one else.  She doesn't write like she uses a template for stories where everything is the same except the character's names.  All of her stories are different from the other and stand out in the field by putting her characters in extraordinary situations.  In "Birthday Present," the female protagonist is Chahna.  She is a beautiful, more mature German woman who heads out to a nightclub for a night of music and dancing.  Chahna feels out of place at the club because the clientele all look so much younger than her.  By chance she stumbles upon a United States Marine named Hunter who is out celebrating his birthday with other members of his unit.  Hunter too feels out of place, even his unit members are younger than him.  When he meets Chahna, sparks fly and soon than later their clothes go flying too.  The storyline is romantic and fun and the sex is so very hot and steamy.  This is a great story.

Carry is a sexy young woman who after almost being assaulted and raped on a date decides to grab whatever she can and leave town.  Her date was a very wealthy and very slimy lawyer who threatened to ruin her name if she didn't comply with his wishes.  Unfortunately for Carry, her car breaks down just 100 miles away and she knows the lawyer is hot on her tail.  Along comes Dan, a very large and very buff biker who offers her a ride and instead ends up dispatching the nasty lawyer with just one punch.  Carry rides off with Dan and head first into wild and comical adventures spiced with steamy toe curling sex.  "Born To Be Wild" is part comedy, part suspenseful thriller, and part erotic romp.  I had a great time reading this book and I am sure you will too.

"Her Unchained Heart" tells a great story about looking for something better when all you really need is right under your own nose all of the time.  I have been through a similar situation myself and I know what it means to pour so much time into providing for your family that you begin to drift away from them.  Chase has great storytelling skills and they really shine in this short but well written erotic romance.

I really want to get a mortgage, but I have no idea how the process works. I don't want to go in undereducated and end up getting taken advantage of.  I want to know as much as possible.  This is a brave book that exposes the intricacies of mortgage lending in a clear and gripping form. Required reading for all mortgage seekers.

I don't feel that there is anything deceptive about this book at all.  The cover says it is about all different types of vaping and that's exact;y what it is about.  The book looks at everything from basic e-cigs to more sophisticated vaping methods.  It does mention the use of cannabis and cannabid derivatives, but it does not in anyway promote illegal activities of any kind.  The book is very informative and very well written.  I know I'll never take up smoking actual tobacco cigarettes again, but I may just consider vaping now that I've read this.

"Make Me" is easily one of Lee Child's best books.  It is a multifaceted mystery that leads Reacher and his companion on a state to state investigation that leads to a horrifying revelation.  My mother-in-law is coming to town and she REALLY loves the Jack Reacher series.  She can recall every little detail and talk about it for a long time.  Even though I read the actual novel, I knew that I didn't retain enough to hold a conversation with her.  This Summary & Analysis from the Book*Sense folks is a fantastic way to get everything out of the novel that you paid for.  The review at the beginning was spot on and even touched on the one glaring fault that through me off a bit too. I really like railroads and their history, so there was no way it would slip by me.  After the review there is a list of all the major characters and then the always excellent chapter by chapter summary come next.  After reading this Summary & Analysis, I am ready for my other-in-law.  :)

"A Twin's Redemption" is a unique reading experience.  It is written from the point of view of two 4 year old twin girls who have telepathic abilities.  I will give full props to Yassy F for taking on such a daunting task.  It is quite a different use of the unreliable narrator and I have not seen it used this way before.  The book's characters are very well developed and it really does seem like you are looking at life through the eyes of Pre-K children.  I really enjoyed reading this book.  I have read other Yassy F novels and I can honestly say she just keeps getting better all the time.

Unchecked anger is a horrible problem.  It can ruin relationships, destroy families and careers, and even cause critical illnesses.  We live in a society where living under pressure is considered part of the norm and all of the stress can easy boil over into anger issues.  "Anger Management" by Luis O Moreta is a well written and concise guide to getting to the root of what is causing your anger, how to take back control of your emotions and your lives, and to mend and sustain your relationships.  It is a great book and should be read by anyone who is looking for assistance in getting their anger under control.

"Dead Nolte" is not an easy book to categorize because to do so would somehow reduce the effectiveness of Wilder's unique storytelling style.  It is at times hysterical, revolting, scary, surreal, and exciting.  At times it manages to be all at once.  It's one of those books that make you wonder just what you may have gotten yourself into at the beginning and then by the end you wish there was still more to read because you don't want it to be over.  The story is great, the character, especially Nolte, are fantastic.  This is easily one of my favorite books I've read this year.

This DSLR messenger bag by Manfrotto ranks, for me, as an almost, not quite. Meaning that, while are some very good to excellent features there are also a few where it falls horribly flat. Fortunately, I was able to purchase this for far below the list (and even Amazon Prime) price. That helps.There are definitely some very good points about this bag. I can fit my D7100 with 24-70 lens attached, along with my D7000 with 70-200 f4 attached (laying at an angle), as well as my 18-105 in its cloth bag, all in the main compartment. That to me is huge - lenses attached on both bodies and ready to go with quick access via a quick-access top zipper. There is a zippered bottom compartment that perfectly stores my two SB-600 Speedlight flash units in their original soft cases, and I do mean perfectly. The zippered organizer pocket inside, also accessible through the top zippered opening, holds all manner of smaller items from phones to batteries to business cards, etc., etc.  A full-length narrow pocket (with Velcro hold-down strap) exists at the back that, due to the overall size of the bag, allows me to carry my 17" MacBook Pro, along with the camera gear, though that does make for a pretty hefty load.Where the bag falls short lies in some design flaws. There is only one carry handle meaning that if you lift by that method the bag leans away from you, so you really cannot carry it that way at all.  The shoulder strap, while having great adjustable length, is permanently stitched to the bag meaning that if anything happens to the strap your bag becomes fairly worthless.  I am not sure if this is common to the bag but the plastic buckle on mine is, at times, difficult to get fully locked into place (though the Velcro on either side does a good job keeping the flap closed).  However, the biggest disappointment (though I knew this going in) is that there is no way to lock the bag to help protect the contents.  That feature, for me, would be great as I would like to stow this in the overhead bin when flying but, for safety reasons, slide it under the seat in front of me.Normally, with the fall short items I listed I would typically rate this as a 3-star. However, due to the fact that I can easily carry so much gear, as described above, that pushes it closer to a four.

This is a future that could, conceivably, be a heartbeat away. Literally. The tech that is shown in the series for the most part is known to exist and it is not hard to believe that what we don't know about is already out there or being played with in secret. Also, keep in mind this was aired in 2008. I am not a conspiracy theorist, but I do know with certainty that individual freedom is eroding in the name of making us "feel" more safe and secure.In "The Last Enemy," the protagonist, Stephen Ezard (played brilliantly by Benedict Cumberbatch), becomes a sort of unlikely hero. Well, sort of. I am not going to spoil anything for anybody. Suffice it to say this show is full of drama and suspense and is one where you are never really quite sure which side anybody is really on, except for Ezard and his murdered brother's wife/widow, Yasim Anwar (Anamaria Marinca). And, while viewing there are lots of privacy, moral, and social concerns that the Total Information Awareness (TIA) system brings to mind.This is another great BBC production and is one where you need to keep your attention on the show, the characters, what is said, and how it is said. While it is not filled with blow-'em-up action, there was not any time where I was not involved in the show due to the overall plot, and all the intersecting sub-plots. Overall, very good acting by all concerned.

For the price, I don't think you can beat these Wrangler Cargo Twills. They are lighter weight than pure denim cotton which is nice, making these extremely comfortable. The pockets are roomy and plentiful. The fit was as expected. I like the metal button for closure, as opposed to sewn-on buttons, as they always seem to pop off. The rear pockets are patch with no closure, but I am fine with that, I don't need to have them secured. The two main front pockets are fairly deep which is good. The hook and loop closures on the lower front pockets will help keep whatever is stashed fairly secure. As a bonus, above and behind each lower leg pocket is an open small pocket. My iPhone 5c fits perfectly, though, keep in mind, that pocket is not secure. Overall, considering the price these are outstanding.

This product is fabulous. I suffer greatly from allergies, my nose dries out a lot, at times I have severe nasal irritation. Any or all of those together can block passages, cause nose bleeds because of blowing my nose too often, etc. I happened upon Nose Better while searching for natural nasal remedies and I am glad I found it on Amazon as my local stores do not carry it. Just a little dab on my finger, gently dabbed and swirled a bit inside both nostrils brings some immediate relief in moisturizing and clearing the passages.

Ok, yes, I am a Mitch Rapp junkie, and have been since 1999. In April this year I became an official Mitch Rapp Ambassador (via the Vince Flynn website and newsletter) and one perk of this taskforce was being able to receive an Advance Readers Edition of this latest Rapp installment, The Survivor, written by Kyle Mills, for an honest review.As a note, I did re-read The Last Man (Nov 2012), the final Rapp story penned by Vince Flynn before his untimely passing (Jun 2013), as a bit of a comparative. So, upfrontwhile this is not Flynn, may he rest in peaceIMO it is hard to tell the difference as Mills obviously immersed himself in all things Rapp. He did extremely well keeping the style, pacing, flavor and feeling of Rapp in tact for the millions of die-hard fans who have enjoyed Rapps wild and heroic exploits over the years.The Survivor does pick up where The Last Man left off, though you can read this one and not be lost. The CIA must, at all costs, recover classified information that was compromised when Joe Rick Rickman, long-tenured CIA black ops master in Afghanistan, went rogue and staged his own kidnapping and beating. He had really put the information and himself for sale to the Pakistanis. Rapp thought that he had ended the threat when he killed Rickman. Unfortunately, he was wrong. From seemingly beyond the grave, a video from Rickman is delivered and reveals he knew way too much about way too many things he should not have known. As it says on the Vince Flynn website: Now its a deadly race as both the Pakistanis and the Americans search for Rickmans accomplices and the information they are slowly leaking to the world. Uh-oh.If you have been a Flynn/Rapp fan, rest assured, you should not be disappointed with Kyle Mills now writing the adventures. He expertly utilizes some of our favorite series characters in this intricately plotted thriller, including CIA Director Irene Kennedy, Rapps pal and former SEAL Team Six Commander Scott Coleman and Stan Hurley, Rapps trainer. For those new to Rapp, the first published book about the counter-terrorism expert was Transfer of Power (Jul 1999) when I got hooked. After many rousing adventures Flynn gave us two books with some back story, thus becoming the real start of Mitch Rapp and his series. They are American Assassin (Oct 2010) and Kill Shot (Feb 2012). All of the books are stand-alones but if you really like political thrillers and great action, you may want to start at the beginning and enjoy the ride, after you read this one, of course.Keeping everything in context with authors and books this rating is a bit tough. For me, it was not a quite a solid five, but definitely higher than just a four...somewhere in between. Unfortunately, there are no stars between those two numbers. So, I rounded it up. Sit back, read, enjoy.

We have used these Key to Fractions books for over a decade in tutoring programs with tremendous success, particularly with middle and high school students who struggle with math. Rassmussen does an outstanding job guiding the student through the process of working with fractions. The first book is fraction concepts, the second covers multiplication and division of fractions, the third adding and subtracting fractions and, finally, mixed fractions. It is self-paced and easy to see exactly where a student may be experiencing difficulty. Highly recommended (along with Key to Decimals) to get students through their difficulties and caught up.

The Gotham series tells the pre-Batman tale and does so with great style. The primary focus in the series is on rookie cop James Gordon, who sees far too much corruption in the Gotham City Police Department and City Hall at the hands of competing mobsters. It also, however, chronicles the development of young Bruce Wayne (and his ever-present butler Alfred Pennyworth) and shows us the bits and pieces that will drive Bruce to eventually become our beloved hero. Suffice it to say that the entire casting has been great. While the key players around those characters are too numerous some of my faves are: Selina "Cat" Kyle, Edward "The Riddler" Nygma, Fish Mooney and, of course, Oswald "The Penguin" Cobblepot. While Gotham does not necessarily follow all of the various plot lines of the comics, it is highly enjoyable watching the interplay between characters, especially in the settings and circumstances in which they find themselves, knowing that some will be tremendous adversaries in the future.

Blindspot is off to a pretty good start. I do have to say that I love Jaimie Alexander and this role, as the full-body tattooed Jane Doe, allows her to expand her acting abilities, though she is still one kick-*** lady in this series. She is joined by FBI agent Kurt Weller (Sullivan Stapleton) and FBI Director Bethany Mayfair (Marianne Jean-Baptiste) in search of her identity along with why she has all the tats. The acting is solid from all of the cast and the show moves at a good pace. At the end of the first episode there are a couple of mysteries laid out to us regarding what will/may be coming, though we do not know exactly what they mean, nor when we will find out, nor in what context. It is not quite a 5-star, but I think the potential is definitely there. A lot will depend on what direction they take this, and how they get the series there.EPISODE 2: And it continues ... the tattoos provide clues ... people die for some reason yet we do not know why ... there is more backstory, not just for Jane Doe, but also for Weller ... I really want to know who tattooed her and for what reason(s) ...

If you suddenly wake up some day and the company that you work for no longer exists then, hopefully, you are ex-CIA (like Aaron Eckhart aka Ben Logan in Erased) so you might be able to unravel what happened. Of course, while doing all of the, as it turns out, dangerous investigation, it doesn't help that your estranged daughter (Liana Liberato aka Amy Logan) now happens to live with you and that you are finding dead co-workers everywhere and that a colleague, Anna Brandt (Olga Kurylenko), may not be providing you will good intel. As thrillers (not mysteries) go, this is a bit predictable at times but overall there is enough good action and suspense mixed in to the (not overly original) plot and sub-plots to keep one entertained. It is definitely above average (or what is called "okay" at 3), especially with Eckhart and Kurylenko, so I'll round it up to 4.

I was able to find an absolutely mint condition used Nikkor 80-400 FX lens to couple with my Nikon D7000 DX body, which basically converts to a 120-600mm 35mm equivalent range lens. I earlier owned the Sigma 170-500mm and while the range of the Sigma went a bit further, the lower band is definitely better.One of the beautiful aspects with this glass is that it has VR (Vibration Reduction), where the Sigma did not, meaning that I do not have to use a tripod for most shots. When shooting handheld the percentage of in-focus shots, not blurry shots to shake, is nearly 100%.  With fast action shots there may be some blur due to the speed of the object in motion, but certainly not always.  And, some of those look pretty good anyway.There certainly are times when the lens does not focus as fast as my prime 50mm or even my 18-105mm but the difference has not caused me to lose any shots I really wanted.  And, if you don't need the full range there is a "Limit" switch which, when turned on, allows for faster focus.  For me, the primary reason for my purchase is the long range so I really do not use that feature.The colors are crisp and clear with great contrast.  The zoom is smooth throughout, with no stickiness anywhere.  The collar can get in the way when focusing so mine is off most of the time.  Like many lenses, there may be some chromatic aberration (CA) in really high-contrast situations where the background is quite bright and foreground objects are extremely dark.Keep in mind that this is a pretty heavy piece of glass.  That said, I have not suffered any lens creep issues, like I did with the Sigma.This lens does not have the Nikon Silent Wave Motor (i.e., it is not an AF-S version) which means that it will work in both AF and MF mode only with camera bodies that have the motor to drive the lens, such as a D80, D600, D4, D7000, etc.  But, it will only work in manual focus mode on models without the motor, such as the D40, D60, D3100, D5300, etc.I love this lens.  For the money paid, I am ecstatic with my Nikkor 80-400mm and would highly recommend it to anyone who must have greater than a 300mm focal range.  If I had the money to get the 80-400mm AF-S model would I?  Not sure.  This is working perfectly for me, with the caveats as above.

I give some credit to Cleancaf for the 12-year life (and still going strong) of my Zojirushi EC-BD15 Fresh Brew Thermal Carafe Coffee Maker as I have been using it pretty much the entire time. I really don't keep track of how many times I clean my machine and stainless steel carafe a year but it probably averages about every two to three months. I use as my gauge the bottom of my stainless steel carafe...when I start to see too much build-up, it is time. I also use a long handle bristle or sponge brush after the first "brew" with the Cleancaf cleaner to ensure that all residue is removed in the carafe. Definitely works much better than vinegar. Then after running water through another couple of times my carafe looks brand sparkling new. This a really really good product and highly recommended.

Downton Abbey has got to be, IMHO, one of the finest TV series shows ever produced. As you watch, season to season, the characters become more and more real and, for many, much more complex, and everyone I know who watches Downton has their favorites, for a variety of quite different reasons. There are definitely scenes that will make you quite happy, and, conversely, quite sad. The series, at one time or another, touches on about every emotion that a person has. This is one of two TV shows that I own the entire lot on Blu-Ray (the other being Game of Thrones) so that I am able to watch whenever I want, but also so that I may loan to others to enjoy. This four season Blu-Ray package is very highly recommended, great quality visuals and sound.

Great series, Nikita has it all. Though Maggie Q had been in earlier flicks, I fell in love with her in MI3 and Live Free or Die Hard. When this series was first announced I couldn't wait for it to air. Maggie Q is, IMO, fabulous in her role as a trained assassin gone rogue, and on a mission. The other main and supporting actors also do extremely well in creating characters you will either love or hate, or, in some cases, can't make up your mind because you really aren't quite sure whose side they are really on. One of the great features about the series is that most of the episodes are self contained, though all of them build upon each other, including the use of flashbacks, to further develop characters and plots and sub-plots (of which there are several). There is plenty of action to satisfy virtually anyone. Definitely recommended to those who are fans of Maggie Q, action/adventure, espionage and intrigue.

Well, there ended up being tombstones. And Liam certainly walked among them. A good solid crime/suspense thriller offering a very good supporting cast with Neeson as an unlicensed private eye who takes on a job that leads him straight into mayhem and death. Along the way he finds and befriends a teenager who assists him in this assignment, though he almost walks away from it, despite the huge payday offered to him. With his own ghosts haunting him he must find out if he can rise to the occasion. Not as much action as in many of his flicks but still quite enjoyable. This is Neeson as we love him...moody...gritty...badass. Definitely for all Neeson fans and for those who appreciate a good thriller.

Let's face it, if you enjoy Arnold it is probably because of the action and adventure and, lots of times, the campy fun that his flicks tend to deliver. For me, The Last Stand is a bit of a throwback to his 80's movies but with much better Fx. Overall, this is quite fun with Arnold as a long-time cop who saw it all in Southern California and is now enjoying his final working years in peace and quiet as the sheriff of a small Arizona town, near the Mexico border. That all comes to a horrific end with some very bad guys, including a very rich cartel boss, heading his way. There are some great chase scenes and a wild and crazy shoot 'em up. A very good cast (including Forest Whitaker, Jaimie Alexander, Eduardo Noriega, to name a few) adds to Arnold keeping his town ... uh ... sort of safe. A lot of good one liners add to the mix.

I have loved drinking coffee for over 40 years. While I do sample other flavors hazelnut has been my all-time favorite. Over the past decade or so I have gradually been switching my eating and drinking to natural and organic fare. For the most part it has been pretty easy and I do feel better. Then about a year ago I decided that I had to go decaffeinated. Unfortunately finding an organic decaf hazelnut (or almost any flavor for that matter) that is not artificially flavored has been a serious challenge. Thus, when I ran across Latitude 23.5 "utilizing only organic flavors with no PG's, artificial stabilizers or preservatives" I was thrilled and ordered it immediately. Though it was delivered mid-afternoon, I had to try it. Opening the package offered a very nice aroma, as did the brewing process. The coffee has an excellent nutty flavor with no unpleasant after taste. If you want organic dcaf hazelnut -- this is the one. Highly recommended.

I purchased this AmazonBasics case for my WD My Passport Ultra 1 TB Portable HD. Though this case was actually manufactured for the Essential model, the fit is good as one can see in the photo. When travelling I feel safe knowing that this case will protect my drive from pretty much anything. On one side, there is a mesh half-pocket that holds the USB cable in place, along with other small items, like my Transcend USB 3.0 card reader, while on the opposite side there is a strap to hold my Ultra in place. Overall very good, it does its job perfectly, especially for the price paid. I knock a half star off as it might have been nice to have a loop for a carabiner clip. Not sure I would have used it with a clip but might be nice to have the option. Minus half a star so round it back up to five.

****************** UPDATE: Sept 22.Back down to $54.99 as of this morning, Better but still should be in the $40s.****************** UPDATE: Sept 19.While I am glad I pre-ordered this at $54.99, I was hoping that with the low price guarantee that the price would go down, not up...way up. Amazon should be ashamed gouging their customers at $71.99 on the day of release. However, that will not lower my star rating for the series itself, as those 5 stars were earned. Amazon, however, gets 0 stars for extreme price fixing on this "exclusive."****************** ORIGINAL REVIEWSeason 2 definitely takes off where Season 1 ended, with S.H.I.E.L.D. (Strategic Homeland Intervention, Enforcement, and Logistics Division) having collapsed due to extensive infiltration by Hydra. The principal cast, consisting of Clark Gregg (Phil Coulsen), Ming-Na Wen (Melinda May), Brett Dalton Grant Ward), Chloe Bennet (Skye), Iain De Caestecker (Leo Fitz), and Elizabeth Henstridge (Jenna Simmons) are joined by Nick Blood (Lance Hunter) and Adrianne Palicki (Bobbi Morse) and all turn in excellent performances. There is a lot more action and suspense in year two with various sub-plots occurring to keep you on your toes. The very much improved special effects simply adds to the overall value. One of the aspects that makes the Marvel Cinematic Universe so great happens to be the wealth of characters and being able to draw on them. Appearances by Lady Sif (Jaimie Alexander), Timothy "Dum Dum" Dugan (Neal McDonough), Peggy Carter (Hayley Atwell) and Maria Hill (Cobie Smulders), to name a few, along with interweaving story arcs from the movies adds a great deal to the entertainment of the series. Then, let's just add some outstanding Edward James Olmos (as Robert Gonzales) into the mix and see where you peg him. If you followed Season 1 during the building stage of this intricate show then you really need to get Season 2. IMO this is a definite must have for Marvel Cinematic Universe fans. Pre-ordered and waiting. Highly recommended.

After first meeting Hayley Atwell as Agent Peggy Carter in Captain America The First Avenger I definitely wanted to see more of her. Then Marvel announced her own mini-series for TV. While it was only 8 episodes long the plot and sub-plots worked very well. As an agent at the SSR (Strategic Scientific Reserve) Carter finds herself seriously undervalued - and unused - by the other agents, which was definitely par for 1946, despite her accomplishments during the war. When Howard Stark (Dominic Cooper) is accused of high treason it takes all of her wit and wisdom to assist him. During her escapades she is aided by Edwin Jarvis (James DArcy), Stark's butler. The addition of the Howling Commandos during one episode was a great surprise and quite fun. Overall, for me, Agent Carter offers great characters and is a nice addition to the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Pre-ordered and waiting!******************** UPDATE SEPT 21My 5 star rating stands as that is for the series itself. That said, I was truly hoping the pre-release price I paid would have gone down into the low-to-mid $20's because a 2-disc set (8 episodes, 6 hours) is just not worth $36, especially as the only extras are a few minutes of bloopers. And, there is no iTunes Digital Copy nor any UltraViolet HD for VuDu or Flixster. Disney and Marvel need to seriously examine how to keep their fans happy.

This one is probably my favorite of all the wild and crazy Die Hard movies. Though 12 long years passed since the previous installment, this flick is fully updated, except that John McClane (Bruce Willis) really isn't, and that is why it works so well. Teamed with a young hacker, Matt Farrell (Justin Long), that he ends up having to protect from cyber terrorists, McClane simply does his thing. As with all the Die Hard movies, as well as most anything nowadays, don't look for a whole lot of realism. This is all out, over the top, fun. There are lots of explosions, some great chases and all-around fantastic action, making for pure a adrenaline rush. Timothy Olyphant and Maggie Q make for a dangerously bad duo. Have fun !!!

I enjoy pretty much anything related to the legend of King Arthur and Merlin, the key word being legend. The Last Legion is, once again, a different take on the tale and an enjoyable one at that, adding a lot more Roman lore into the story than others I have watched, and with a few twists of its own. It is certainly not the best and far from the worst Arthurian-based film. Colin Firth, Ben Kingsley and the beautiful (and deadly) Aishwarya Rai headline a cast protecting a young and newly crowned emperor Romulus Augustulus (Thomas Sangster). Kingsley is great as Merlin/Ambrosinus and Firth does a very good depiction of Aurelius. Rai is superb as the Keralite warrior, Mira. There are some good action scenes, the pace moved along well and there were ample battles (not overly bloody), many of which Rai flat out steals the scene. My biggest quibble would be the final battle, not bad but not as good as it could have been. Still, The Last Legion was an overall entertaining Arthurian-based movie.

As long as your DSLR is UHS-compatible this SD card is a great deal for price and performance. The 94mb listed is, of course, for read speed. The write speed is about half of that, but is a great deal nonetheless, especially for the price Amazon sells these for, and an even better deal if you catch a lighting deal. I had used Sandisk Ultra for many years and decided to give the Sony a try during a lightning deal and I am more than pleased with the results. For most people this card should perform very well. This one is in my Nikon D7100. Do keep in mind those speeds are while in the camera. On a computer both will be slower on USB 2.0, but should be near the same with USB 3.0. Giving it five stars based on price and performance and the fact that it has never let me down.

The first thing you notice with B+W filters is the weight. The rings are constructed of brass, not aluminum, making them more sturdy and they will not bind as aluminum filters may do. I have also found that threading the filter on my Nikkor 70-200 f/4 is easy and smooth. The next thing is that this UV Haze filter is actually clear, there is absolutely no sign of slight tinting that I have noticed with other UV filters I have used in the past. This, of course, means that the optical quality of images remains true. The Multi-Resistant Coating (MRC) on B+W is amazing. To me they seem much easier to clean than other brands I have used. I typically use just a microfiber cloth which does the job just fine. Having a lens filter also makes sense to protect your front element from scratches or even breakage because, well, it is much less expensive to replace a filter than the lens. In terms of my pinch-style lens cap, no issue, the cap stays on and fits perfectly. I am sold on B+W, they are pure quality, and have them mounted on all of my lenses. Highly recommended.

With Pierce Brosnan as the bad guy assassin (codename The Watchmaker) and Milla Jovovich the heroine (security expert Kate Abbott), you are set for an entertaining game of cat-and-mouse espionage. Abbott is at the top of her game in security within the US State Department and gets transferred to the Embassy in London. Unfortunately for her, she steps into the middle of intricate plans already in play by terrorists and she ends up not knowing whom she can trust. I am not going to nit-pick the plot or what shoulda coulda woulda been done in real life, as even the best of flicks suffer in some way with the same, but suffice it to say I was engaged. Survivor does not have the volume of blow-em-up sequences as a Bond or a Bourne, but has some good sequences of suspense and action. As the end neared I was wondering how Abbott was going to stop the attack. Jovovich delivers a strong performance and while Brosnan takes getting used to as a cold-blooded villain he pulls it off well. Other notable performances by Dylan McDermott, Angela Bassett, Robert Forster and James D'Arcy. Not a five star but I definitely enjoyed it.

The Amazon production of Bosch does credit to Michael Connelly's character, Hieronymus (Harry) Bosch. I read about 7 or 8 of the novel series years ago and enjoyed them and the TV series captured the essence of Bosch, especially what makes him tick and what gets him ticked off, very well. I found the casting to be very good, overall, and the pace moved well. His friends (like his partner and the Lieutenant), his lover (a female rookie cop), his biggest enemy (the Captain) and his sometimes ally when it suits him (the Deputy Chief) add great dimension and, at times, tension to the show. Don't worry if you haven't read the books, you will see Bosch the way Connelly created him, and if you have read any of the books you will most likely appreciate how true the storyline of this series is. This is ten shows. As with a captivating book, be prepared to continue, though other things call for your attention.

While I will not give away any of the basics that make it so, be prepared going in that this 10-part series is unlike any other cinematic version in the Arthurian legend category. Despite that major difference (this is "Hollywood" after all), the lone season was entertaining although incomplete. There is no Season Two, due to schedule conflicts with major members of the cast. Even though many modern historians debate/dispute the actual existence of King Arthur, as most of the details concerning Arthur, during the late 5th and early 6th centuries, come from folklore, the legend continues and, if nothing else, provides wonderful entertainment. IMO Eva Green, as Morgan, absolutely stole the show in Camelot. She was completely captivating and convincing as the conniving sorceress daughter of Uther Pendragon. Claire Forlani was beautifully cast as Arthur's biological mother, Lady Igraine. It was, at first, hard for me to accept this depiction of Merlin, portrayed by Ralph Fiennes, but the character grew on me as the season progressed. In terms of Arthur and his men, I was a bit disappointed with Jamie Campbell Bower as Arthur as he does not fit the "mold" that has been set for this legendary king. That said, the rest were very good to great, especially Clive Standen as Gawain. This series is not on the same scale as Game of Thrones but, overall, the costumes, sets and locations were done very well. If you are looking for something that follows the traditional Arthur storyline, this is not it. If you are looking for a new twist on the tale you may want to explore Camelot. As a note, this is definitely an r-rated version of the beloved story of King Arthur.

TAK3N involves the same main characters as the first two (Liam Neeson, Famke Janssen, Maggie Grace, Leland Orser) and adds a new one (Forest Whitaker) along with a whole lot of gun fights and car chases. It seems Bryan Mills (Liam) just can't catch a break. He is framed for murdering his ex-wife, Lenore Mills-St. John (Famke). He is chased by LAPD Inspector Frank Dotzler (Forest) and his team. All the while, Mills is chasing down leads on Lenore's murderer, with help from his closest covert co-workers and friends, particularly Sam Gilroy (Orser), while trying to keep his daughter Kim (Maggie) out of harm's way. And, of course, then there is the ex-Spetsnaz businessman and his Russian thugs thrown in for good measure. This is not a complicated whodunit, but it is entertaining for those liking action/adventure movies, as well as Neeson fans. Do keep in mind that this is a movie and there are many things that just could not/would not happen in real life. However, that is the case with pretty much anything produced in Hollywood. In terms of the Blu-ray (including both Theatrical and Unrated Extended editions on one disc), the visual and audio are superb quality and the package includes the UV copy.

A good ole Earth vs alien invaders SF theme. Too bad we actually invited them here. LOL You will surely need to stretch your reality but that is pretty much the case with any SF film. Even so, Battleship is a mostly fun ride with powerful, yet vulnerable, aliens and technology, a wide variety of humans and the USS Missouri making a heroic return to action after decades or dormancy. Anyone who has played the game Battleship will recognize the weapons fired by the aliens, a nice touch to tie in the game and movie. The action and fx were pretty good throughout and the diverse crew members, though at times underplayed, worked well together. For me, it is an I like it movie, i.e. four stars.

I had exclusively been using another brand in all of my devices for several years (including CF, SD, SDHC, Micro-SDHC, etc.) and decided to give Sony a try in my DSLRs when there was a very nice sale and seeing that the reviews have been overwhelmingly positive. I have this in my Nikon D7100 and have not been disappointed in the least. It actually reads and writes a bit faster than my earlier, comparable cards. In fact the write speed is right at 19 MB/sec vs about 12 MB/sec, which is great when shooting. Read speed is over 60 MB/sec. I have absolutely no complaints after making the switch in brands, quite the opposite. Definitely recommended. Note: this is an SDHC card, so make sure your device works with it, and not just an SD card.

These tart cherry capsules are, for me, great at alleviating minor discomfort from arthritis, primarily knees but also some in my thumbs and ankles. I take two every morning and the results were noticed within a couple of days. I used to take MSM and Glucosamine Sulfate and these tart cherry's work better. I'd say these also provide a bit higher energy level than not taking them.

I thoroughly enjoy Marvel's Agent Carter and Hayley Atwell plays the part of Peggy perfectly. Her role at SSR is something she has to deal with in a male-dominated workplace, where the men don't care for a female in their midst. Her flashbacks about Captain America keep things in perspective and provide more insight to what goes on in her universe as the season goes on and she earns her place in the boy's club. The other main characters, as well as recurring and guests, add their own unique quirks and twists to the show. The fact that Howard Stark is on the run as a traitor to the US provides a story where you are not quite sure how he will be cleared, assuming that he will be. Having the addition of the 107th (the Howling Commandos from Captain America: The First Avenger) join in was a brilliant play by the writers. Agent Carter is a very entertaining component to the Marvel Universe.

This is another enjoyable Sean Dillon (and Company) caper, the 21st featuring the former Provisional IRA enforcer, turned agent for the British Secret Service. While not my favorite in this long-lasting franchise, it carries most all of the hallmarks that have come to be known throughout. The main difference being, in the last several books, that Dillon, who is now about 62, is not as spry as he was when the series started, though he is still feared and a threat to most. The plot is fairly typical with Dillon and his cohorts (Brig Gen Ferguson, Capt Sarah Gideon, Maj Charles Roper, Billy, and his uncle Harry, Salter) having to "save the day," so to speak, this time from the plans of an Al-Queda man, known only as the Master who is unknown outside the circle of his Council and who has utter control over several assets worldwide. The identity of the Master does add a twist to the story. They are joined in their escapade by none other than former US President Jake Cazalet (who first appeared in the series in the 1997 book "The President's Daughter"). I will admit it is not one of Higgins' best works, with incorrect details such as a non-existent protection detail for an ex-president, but for a Sean Dillon fan, it was an enjoyable read, containing plenty of action with some twists and turns along the way. The main action takes place in Nantucket (Massachusetts, USA), Drumgoole (Ireland), Paris (France) and London (England), with a few other locations thrown in for good measure. I rate this book half way between a 3 (due to a few detail inaccuracies, though many popular authors suffer from this) and a 4 (as I like the characters and the plot with sub-plots), so will round it up. For those interested, the Sean Dillon tales begin with "Eye of the Storm" (1992).

I have added Nutiva Organic Shelled Hempseed to my regular diet as hempseed provides an organic source of Omega-3, along with protein and other needed minerals. They seem to aid in keeping my blood pressure and cholesterol levels in check. Typically, as a light snack, I apply a couple of tablespoons to a 5 oz cup of organic yogurt or 6 oz cup of Quark cheese (great source of protein) to provide a more nutty flavor. As a note, the package does say to refrigerate after opening and to consume within 12 weeks.

I am quite happy I found Lakewood Organic Lemonade. The taste is not sour/tart like a whole lemon would be, nor is it as sweet as those lemonades that use sugar, but for me the taste is quite smooth and pleasant, as the juice includes organic agave (another product I happen to like) and organic white grape juice as sweeteners. I drink this as a means to help with my body's pH balance, I.e., keeping the body more alkalized, and as an additional source of Vitamin C, though there are quite a few other health and nutrition benefits associated with lemons. Prior to drinking at least 8 ounces a day I used to suffer from heartburn (acid indigestion) quite regularly, but that is now a thing of the past. This is a very very good lemonade.

This has done a good job for me with gum inflammation and bleeding. The taste is good, though a bit mild compared to other "mouthwashes," but that is definitely not an issue for me as it is also not overpowering, nor burning. There is no alcohol, no synthetics, no chemicals, thus making it better for body health overall. I use it a couple of times a day and is part of my daily routine.

I have had BasicTalk service for over 1.5 years and it has been great. I first got it in August 2013 when I lived in the Northeast. It was very easy to get connected and start calling and receiving calls. I then moved to Florida a year later. It was a breeze to reconnect and get a new local number. I appreciate the low cost (approx $12/mo including taxes) vs most carriers. While BasicTalk is not as cheap as MagicJack, I had owned that before BasicTalk and it was not nearly as good, in quality and clarity, something to me that needs to be as near to perfect as possible. The only thing I ever experience with BasicTalk is that once in a while, usually after a short outage or power surge, that my Caller ID doesn't work. I discovered that all I have to do is reboot the little black box and it works again. So, 4.5 stars rounded up.

I have owned these for about five months and they have been working pretty much as advertised. I needed to have some illumination in areas where the light switch is located in the dark and there were no outlets nearby to place a night light. Not sure about a three meter (roughly 10 feet) range but for sure within about six or seven feet they do come on. Unless there is continual motion they only stay lit about 20 or 25 seconds, which for me is plenty of time to hit the light switch and is also good for battery life. There are three settings: auto (ie motion sensor), continuous, and off. Mine are set to auto. One is in a higher traffic area and the original batteries (three AAA) are still in. I like that they can be mounted with either screws, by magnet or can be hung by a handle that flips up from the back. I have had no issues with the one using magnet, it has never moved from where I placed it. As a note, when they arrived one was defective but it was rapidly replaced by the company.

This novella by Hubbard is extremely fun and entertaining. And, yes I did say swashbuckling (as in pirates) and fantasy. The story, written in 1940, is quite original and is very much along the lines of tales that are found in, for those who remember, Rod Serling's "The Twilight Zone." The protagonist, a struggling New York pianist named Mike de Wolf, suddenly finds himself on a Caribbean beach as a 17th century villain (Spanish Admiral and Pirate, Miguel de Lobo) in his friend's (Horace Hackett) upcoming but behind-the-deadline high-seas novel, "Blood and Loot." Knowing as he does the fate of the bad guy in virtually anything written by his friend, Mike must use what little free will he finds that he has in order to work out his hoped-for escape from the inevitable. To make matters worse, there are those times when Horace changes his mind and, thus, changes the story, further complicating Mikes plight. Along the way, Mikes encounters in this fictional - yet possibly deadly for him - world are expertly handled. A very enjoyable escape from the every day world and recommended to anyone, especially adventure, fantasy and science fiction readers.

These Puma's fit well and are definitely comfortable, as well as having some great style. The construction seems good, the arch support is nice, and I received them with no loose threads. For me the fit was good. I wear a 13, ordered a 13, and they were slightly snug when I first wore them but loosened up just a bit. They are good for longer walks though not sure how long they would last if done continuously. The only thing I really have a gripe about is that they do not breathe that well. I thought they would be better, though I have a few canvas slip-ons that are much cooler to wear, so I have options, depending upon the weather.

The movie is set in 1991, a couple of years after the fall of the Berlin Wall. In Washington DC, it is the last day working at the CIA for Nathan Muir (Robert Redford) who he is packing things in his office, ready for retirement. Then he learns that his protg, Tom Bishop (Brad Pitt), had been captured and is being held in China. To complicate matters, the US and China are in trade talks. The bureaucratic CIA is, obviously, less than thrilled that the brash and bold young Bishop has threatened the diplomatic goings-on and there are those determined to abandon him. Muir decides to help the task force who are deciding how best to handle the issue but has his own plans, including the possibility of getting Bishop out of captivity. Muir plays a very adept chess game with his counter-parts at Langley, seemingly working with them by providing background etc on Bishop, all the while maneuvering various players in this Spy Game to achieve his goal. Redford and Pitt are perfect for their roles, and there is ample suspense and some good action in this suspenseful tale.

This is an outstanding charger. I have a smaller portable (3200 mAh) but needed to get a charger with more juice, especially when travelling, as I hate having to look for wall outlets. There are four LED lights on the front, each signifying about 25% so with 2 lights there is about 50% remaining. When you connect a device to charge you must push the 'on' button to start the cycle. When charging the RAV, the LED lights flash, otherwise they are solid. A huge benefit is that you can charge two devices simultaneously (ie, two phones, a phone and a tablet). The unit itself arrived charged and first use was with an iPhone 5c (using the Apple cord), which went from 20% to 100% in just under 80 minutes, or about 1% per minute, and the 4 blue LEDs still glowed (though the 4th was weaker). I have charged my phone 5 times and still had one LED glow. To protect the charger, I carry it in a Case Logic QHDC-101 Portable Hard Drive Case...it fits perfectly, along with 2 cords. Any price at two Jackson's (or less) is a bargain for the quality and convenience that this RAVPower charger provides. Highly recommended.

The tires need replacing after only 30,000 miles. I purchased these tires a bit over 4 years ago for a Mitsubishi Outlander (though the warning states it does not fit my vehicle). I am your average driver, and did a good mix of city driving with highway mixed in and then, towards the end, a 1,200 mile move. The alignment and balance were always kept in so I am not sure why they did not last longer. I lived in Pennsylvania and was not too impressed with either snow or heavier wet-road conditions, as there was not much grip. I can state that the tires did ride fairly quiet and on dry road conditions the stability and traction were definitely above average, which is why I am giving a two star rating instead of one. But, overall, I am disappointed in these tires.

This is an outstanding portable charger. And, it is even better when you get it with a great Amazon deal. I own a larger 10,400mAh charger for use when I travel but when I am just going around town and want to be sure I am never out of juice, I carry this Astro Mini with me. I can get two-plus charges on my Apple iPhone 5c (with a non-supplied Apple cable) which, to me, is well above average for a 3200mAh unit. This Anker makes it nice to go anywhere, with no worries about running out of power. It is approx 3.75" long and 1" in width, and comes with a standard mini-USB cable, a handy travel pouch and is even offered in a variety of colors. Highly recommended.

Needed an extra cable to carry with me and my Anker 2nd Gen Astro Mini 3200mAh Portable Charger whenever I am away from home and this is perfect. It is an original Apple OEM cable, just like the one that came with my iPhone 5c.

This Case Army cover for the iPhone 5c is a perfect fit. That it is flexible and clear made it the exact case I was looking for. The openings for the camera, charger port, earphones, etc., are perfect and I have had no problems at all using the buttons with the soft coverings. It has a good feel when holding it. Definitely recommended.

Very good screen, especially for the price. It does what it is supposed to do--block unwanted noise like wind or breath. It fit perfectly on the CAD U1 USB Dynamic Recording Microphone, albeit a little tight.

This is an entry level mic and, as such, cannot really be compared for quality with a high-end pro mic for overall sound quality.That said, it definitely performs above average and is a excellent bargain for the price. The set-up is very quick with its gold-plated USB connection with either PC or Mac. I have both and have tried it on each of them with very good results. For best performance read the instructions because you may first experience background noise but this is easily handled by going to you mic settings and turning the AGC off. However, if you are plugging in to a UPS (uninterrupted power supply) you may not experience the extra noise. The plastic stand works well so that the mic remains stable when in use.

As a casual hybrid bike rider, I find the Green Guru narrow strap to work very well. Mine measures just slightly over 14.25" in length and is 1" wide. On the outside, there is a 4.25" length of Velcro while the Velcro covers the entire inside of the strap. The stitched-on silver piece is reflective but I do not count on that as a life saver at night, as I have spoke lights, as well as front and rear lights that I use for safety precautions. The Velcro holds tight and definitely protects my pant leg from getting anywhere near the gears, which is exactly what it is supposed to do. The outer material might be old tubes, hard to say but I think it will be plenty durable. The stitching seems very good with no loose or dangling threads. Definitely recommended.

This CyberPower 850VA unit is really more than I needed for my home office set-up but I got a great deal here on Amazon and wanted to have total peace of mind as I live in an area with more-than-average power surges and spikes, along with short outages for no apparent reason...and this provides that comfort. I have owned it for a few months and gone through numerous spikes (five within two hours on one day) and two outages so far and this has performed seamlessly. The battery and surge outlets totally protect my iMac, modem, printer, and two phone lines, while the surge-only outlets take care of digital photo frames and some lights. And, it is totally quiet. The size (approx. 4"x9"x10") is great, the gloss and matt black color combo looks good and it certainly seems to be built well. While it claims a runtime of two minutes at full load, I am nowhere near full and know for sure it goes more than five with what I have connected, based on one particular outage. As a bonus it has USB charging ports, though I do not plan to use them. Very good peace of mind for pricey electronic gear.

I have owned this CyberPower home surge protector power strip (with phone line protection) for a few months and it seems to be doing a very good job. I live in an area where I get sudden surges, power flickers, and the like and while I have Uninterrupted Power Supply (UPS) units for my computers and more valuable electronics, I wanted an economical surge protector for my phone, digital photo frame and a couple of lights. I appreciate the right-angle plug where others I have owned come straight out of the outlet, as this makes a difference when the strip is placed behind furniture, allowing items to go almost to the wall. This has worked well and for about ten bucks with 1500 Joules protection is a very good deal.

These C+F packing cubes arrived earlier today, and I have already made good use of them.  I have an upcoming trip to Disney World, so I have been packing most of the day to get ready.  I already have a few packing cubes, which are the eBags brand in the medium size.  These C+F packing cubes are just as nice as the more expensive eBags packing cubes that I have.  I actually like them better, because they are an inch deeper which is convenient when packing bulkier items like pants and sweatshirts.  There is a mesh panel on the front of the cubes, which allows for ventilation and also allows you to see what is packed at the top of each cube.  Each cube has 2 heavy duty YKK zippers.  Two zippers make it easy to close each cubes up, as opposed to only having one zipper and having to pull it all around the cube.  There is a handle on the top of each cube, allowing for easy handling.  The cubes are made from a lightweight but very sturdy nylon.  The attached tag states they can be hand washed and drip dried.  The stitching is even and well done.  My only small complaint is that these do not come in various colors at the present time.  That is a handy feature when packing for multiple family members, because each person can have their own color.  I received this product at a discounted price in exchange for my honest review.

We have 3 cats, and over the last several years I have bought a couple of different litter mats to try and control the mess.  This is my favorite one so far.  The best thing is the size (35" x 23").  It is big enough that the cats usually walk on it when exiting the litter box, instead of just jumping over it like they did with the smaller mats we owned.  The feel of the mat also seems to be pleasing to their paws.  It is soft, but textured to catch the excess litter.  I have walked over it barefoot myself, and it does not hurt my feet like the previous mat we had.  One of my cats likes to nap on it, so I am assuming it is comfortable.  If I had to bring up one small negative, the mat smelled of PVC when it first arrived.  I laid it out on the covered porch for a day, and it did air out quickly.  I typically clean the mat by using the vacuum cleaner hose.  Once every week or two, I carry it outside and give it a good shake to knock out the litter.  I received this product at a discounted price. There was no compensation. The opinions expressed are my own and not influenced in any way.

Due to a change in my financial situation, I have been unable to afford professional pedicures for the last year.  Even though I use a pumice stone bar a couple of times a week while in the shower, my feet started looking bad, especially my heels where I developed horse shoe shaped calluses.  I received this callus remover earlier this week, and finally tried it out last night.  What a difference!  After just a single 10 minute session, most of my calluses and dead skin are gone.  Now I can wear sandals without embarrassment again.  The unit is packaged with a spare file head, a cleaning brush, and a snap on plastic cover for the file head.  I only had to install 2 AA batteries (not included).  Disclaimer:  I received this product for free in exchange for my honest review.  This in no way influenced my opinion of the product.
This sleeve is a perfect fit for my Samsung Galaxy Tab 4 10.1" (2014 edition).  The sleeve is nicely constructed and the Verizon logo is small and unobtrusive.

I'm consistently impressed by LeapFrog products, and this one is no exception.  My 4 year old daughter was very excited to received this LeapReader activity book, and it includes many of her favorite characters from the movies Toy Story, Monsters Inc, Finding Nemo, etc.  You do need a computer to download the audio for the book, so I recommend setting that up before you give it to an excited child that wants to play it instantly.  Besides the Disney/Pixar Write It activity book, there are also 25 sheets of extra writing and drawing paper.

This is a very nice case for the Samsung Galaxy S5 phone.  It goes on fairly easy, but of course installing the screen protector takes a little more time and effort to do correctly.  It is lightweight, and not nearly as bulky as what I expected.  I have the clear case, which is very attractive.  The cutouts for the camera, charger, headphones, and other various ports are perfectly cut out.  I haven't dropped the phone yet, but this case appears to be as protective as the OtterBox cases that I typically use.  Given the current selling price of this case (around a Jackson, I'm even more impressed.

My 4 year old daughter is a big fan of the Doc McStuffins cartoon, and was very excited to get this toy.  She isn't normally a fan of games, but she enjoys playing this with me or her father.  The game is a fun way of teaching kids about going to the doctor, and what the various medical tools are used for.  I'm disappointed in the quality of the pieces though, as they're cheaply made.  My daughter is very careful with her toys, but this definitely wouldn't stand up to carelessness from a younger or rougher child.

I occasionally babysit for an 8 month old baby girl, and she loves this mirror.  She will sit in front of it for an hour or more, giggling and touching her reflection in the mirror.  The mirror is very stable, and it doesn't tip over despite her best efforts.  The toy is recommended for ages 6 to 36 months.  However, I think that most children would get quickly bored with this toy by the time they start walking.

This product has a lot of bad reviews, which makes me wonder if some people are getting counterfeit cables.  It isn't uncommon, and can be an issue when purchasing from certain 3rd party retailers, even through Amazon.  I received my cable from the Amazon Vine Review program, which in turn receives their merchandise directly from the manufacturer.  So, there's no chance of my particular cable being a counterfeit.  Avoid fakes by buying directly through Amazon, and not an Amazon approved seller.I've been using this cable for almost a month, and it is working very well.  I have the 6 inch cable, which is very handy for carrying in my purse along with my portable battery bank.  It's really too short for using at home, but it fits my needs for an extra cable perfectly.  I like the blue color, as it is easy to differentiate from the numerous other cable I have.

These Avery Kids Self-Laminating labels come in a pack of 48, in the colors of orange, purple, green, and pink.  I'm not sure why they're marketed as a kids product, since these can be used in a wide variety of applications.  The labels are smaller than I expected, and I found it necessary to use an ultra-fine point sharpie to write on them.  Unlike a different Avery label that I recently tried, these have survived 3 or 4 trips through the dishwasher so far, applied to various reusable water bottles.  I do think these labels are ridiculously expensive for what they are.  I've bought personalized labels from Dinkleboo and Lovable Labels for a lower cost per label.

I received this Kyocera Ceramic Nonstick Fry Pan from the Amazon Vine Review program.  To be perfectly honest, I wasn't expecting much.  My only prior experience with a ceramic nonstick pan is an "as seen on TV" pan that my parents own.  So I was pleasantly surprised when I received this and saw how nicely it is made.  The pan is a nice weight, and well balanced.  The handle is attached with 3 sturdy rivets.  The ceramic nonstick coating is very smooth.  I tried cooking an egg in the pan with no oil, butter, etc and it didn't stick at all.  The instructions say to not use anything higher than the medium setting on your stove.  I especially like the deepness of this pan (about 4 inches), and I plan on using it the next time I make a stir fry.  My only small disappointment is that a lid isn't included.  Only time will tell how long the ceramic nonstick coating will last, but I'm only using nylon and plastic utensils to protect the finish.  The pan is hand wash only, which is not an issue, since it only needs a quick wipe with a soapy rag or brush to clean.

We use a lot of batteries in my home.  I have camera equipment that uses AA and AAA batteries, and my 4 year old daughter has countless toys that consume batteries at an alarming rate.  This Ambient Weather BC-2000 charges up to 4 batteries at a time.  It can charge both NiCd or NiMH AA or AAA batteries.  I had some very old rechargeable batteries I found in a kitchen drawer that I thought were no good.  I tried refreshing and charging them, and they're still holding up a few days later.

I don't have a brand loyalty for toilet paper.  Depending what is on sale, or what I have a coupon for, I buy Charmin, Quilted Northern, Cottonelle, etc.  One thing that I have noticed, that regardless of whether I buy single ply toilet paper or the expensive thick stuff, my family still uses the same length of paper.  So, we never save money by purchasing the thicker paper, and the thicker paper is more likely to clog the toilet.  (Especially with a 4 year old child who thinks that more is better.)  This Charmin Basic is thicker than most single ply papers, so it's strong enough to handle messy jobs.  The "huge" rolls are indeed big, and I don't have to change the roll quite as often.

I received this Bissell Bolt cordless vacuum cleaner from the Amazon Vine Review program.  The floors in my house are wood and tile.  Other than a couple of small area rugs and carpeted stair treads, we have no carpeting.Setting up the vacuum was very simple.  It consisted of unfolding the handle, snapping on the brush head, and plugging in the charger.  All in all, it took less than 5 minutes, including opening up the box.  I left it on the charger overnight, and it was ready to go the following morning.  The charger plugs directly into the vacuum cleaner.  Unfortunately, the nickel-metal hydride battery is not replaceable.This small vacuum is great for quick pickups.  It runs for around 13-15 minutes, depending on whether the brush roll is being used. I have used it a couple of times of my stairs, which is much less cumbersome than using a full size vacuum cleaner.  I clean up under my kitchen table at least a couple of times a day, and I use it occasionally to pick up scattered cat food, cat litter, etc.  It isn't a replacement for a full-size vacuum, but a very convenient item.  It is light, and fairly easy to maneuver.  My 4 year old daughter uses it after meal times to clean up the mess that she usually makes under the table.The brush roll can be turned on or off, which I appreciate, since I don't want to damage my wood floors.  The unit has a removable hand vacuum, which is convenient for tight areas such as behind the toilet.  The handle of the vacuum folds for more compact storage.  I store mine in the coat closet, and when folded, it is short enough to go under the hanging garments.  The vacuum does tip easily when left standing though because it is so lightweight.  I personally think this problem as well as the maneuverability would be improved if the base of the vacuum cleaner weighed a few more ounces.  I also own a Hoover Linx cordless vacuum cleaner (now discontinued), which has an 18 volt battery, and because of that works much better than this 12 volt Bissell Bolt.  Bissell does make a similar cordless vacuum in an 18 volt version, and I would be interested to see how that compares to the Hoover Linx.  Overall, I rate this as a 5 star item, especially with the current pricing.  Don't expect it to replace your full sized vacuum cleaner, but you'll definitely be pulling out that cumbersome item much less frequently.

I received this Lincoln Logs Little Prairie Farmhouse Building set from the Amazon Vine Review program.  I played with Lincoln Logs when I was a child, and I bought my older child a set for his third birthday.  My daughter is 4 1/2 years old, and had absolutely no interest in her big brother's set of Lincoln Logs that I brought out of storage.  She insisted that it was a toy for boys, and wouldn't even try playing with them.Her attitude changed drastically when the mail truck came last week with this package of Lincoln Logs with pink windows, door, and gate, girly colored ponies, and figurine.  She has played with these for at least an hour per day, and quickly forgot her prior protests about Lincoln Logs being only for boys.My major complaint about the set is that there aren't nearly enough big pieces.  Of the 101 logs in this set, over half are mini logs, which are hard to build houses with.  My daughter was getting frustrated, and lost interest in the toy after the initial 10-15 minutes.  I ended up adding her older brother's traditional set of Lincoln Logs to this, which gave her plenty of larger logs to build with, as well as the old fashioned wooden slats that used to serve as roof pieces.  This could easily be a 5 star product, if only the manufacturer would spend the extra few cents for more larger logs.I can only recommend this Little Prairie Farmhouse Building set if you plan on buying it as an addition to a larger set of Lincoln Logs that contains more of the longer logs.  As a standalone toy, this particular set has very little versatility on its own.  If you want your child to have the Lincoln Log experience that you had as a child, you'll definitely need more logs that what are included in this set.

My 4 year old daughter recently started pre-kindergarten, and all of her new little friends are great at sharing.  By sharing, I mean sharing their germs, as well as toys and classroom supplies.  She came home from school a couple of days ago complaining of a sore throat, and by the following morning she had developed a cold.The recommended dosage is by age, not weight.  A measuring cup comes with this, but we prefer using an oral syringe.  She only complained mildly about the taste of this medicine, but she is old enough to realize that she would rather take a small dose of not-so-great tasting medication, rather than feel sick.  This does contain acetaminophen (also known as Tylenol), so it's important not to accidentally overdose your child and their young liver.  This can be taken 5 times per a 24 hour period, and I've been giving it to my daughter every 5 hours, except when she's sleeping at night.  It is controlling her cold symptoms of a low-grade fever, cough, and stuffy nose very well for about 4 hours.  I like that this doesn't contain dyes like most children's medications, and is clear in color.

I received this book through the Amazon Vine Review program.  My 4 1/2 year old daughter is very headstrong and difficult to effectively discipline, so this book caught my attention.  I was expecting a boring book, but I was surprised that it is fairly easy to read and follow.  There are a lot of examples in the book, along with images.  The approach seems very similar to what is used in daycares and schools, which is to focus on the positive aspects, and redirect the child.

I received this book through the Amazon Vine Review program.  My daughter is almost 4 1/2 years old, so she's much younger than the recommended age group of 8 to 12 years old.  Nevertheless, she enjoys me reading this book to her, and frequently tells me that she loves this story about "big girls".  There are cartoons, doodles, and comic strips interspersed throughout the book, which helps keep her attention.  We've been reading a few pages a night at bedtime, and are nearly finished with the book.  This is a fun read, and I enjoy it myself.  I believe this is supposed to be the first book of a series, so we'll be looking forward to seeing the other books in the future.

I received this book through the Amazon Vine Review program.  I had never heard of this author or series before, and I was pleasantly surprised.  My daughter is almost 4 1/2 years old, so younger than the recommended age group of 6 to 8 years old.  Nevertheless, she enjoys me reading this book to her.  There are illustrations interspersed throughout the book, which helps keep her attention.  We read a few pages a night at bedtime, until we finished the book.Although this book is part of a series, the librarian at my daughter's school told me that the books are written so that they can be read out of order.  Evidently, a lot of the older girls at my daughter's school enjoy the Just Grace books as well.  As my daughter gets older and starts to read on her own, this is definitely a series that I'll remember and either purchase for her, or borrow from the library.

I received this Norton Small Business 5 Device software from the Amazon Vine Review program.  I do not own a business, but I do have several computers and tablets in my home, some of which are primarily used by family members who are negligent at keeping up virus protection.  This Norton product schedules itself to perform PC maintenance, such as clearing of caches and temporary files, and drive optimization.  Unlike some of the Norton products that I used years ago, this doesn't overburden system resources.  As an added note, there are no physical CD's in the package.  There is a small card with a keycode, and you go online to download the software.

I've just had a chance to sample Campbell's Organic Soup, Chicken Noodle flavor.  Pros and cons of this particular soup:Pros:- Certified USDA Organic and certified by California Certified Organic Farmers- Overall a decent tasting chicken soup, but to my taste just a little bit bland- Really like the egg noodles, which hold up and aren't mushy like a lot of noodles in prepared soup.- Low in fat and cholesterol.Cons:- Packaging a bit tricky to open, spilled a bit of soup- Would prefer a can which I can recycle vs. this pouch which I cannot recycle in my area- This soup may be organic, but it's hard to call it "healthy" when one box has 58% of a day's Sodium requirement- Significantly more expensive than competing non-organic products from Campbell's or Progresso.Overall a good chicken noodle soup.  However, I am not be happy with the amount of sodium in this product.  I would be more willing to pay the premium for this soup if it was low sodium as well as organic.

Look elsewhere.  My son had this on his 5c.  Two weeks ago it fell out of his hand when he was bumped by another student, fell perhaps 4 feet onto a carpeted surface, and the screen shattered.  This case looks impressive but the protection isn't that impressive.  Now looking for a replacement from Otterbox or Griffin that will better protect the phone the next time it takes a tumble.

Note that Crenova provided me with this product in exchange for an impartial review.The Crenova High Pressure Garden Hose Nozzle Sprayer is a well built solid basic adjustable hose nozzle sprayer.  It is constructed of metal which is covered in a thick rubber coating, black near the inlet and red closer to the nozzle.  An optional quick-connect adapter is included (I did not test this out as my hoses are not quick-connect).The Crenova Nozzle prayer works like any other nozzle sprayer as it adjusts by turning the outer (red) part of the unit.  However, it is a bit unusual as OFF is the the fully extended position; turning the adjustment backwards gets you a powerful jet / less powerful jet / shower / "flood" setting.  The only disadvantage I see is that the water flow is pretty much at 100% for all of the adjustments; there is no way to get a light shower or mist setting.Overall a solid nozzle sprayer that meets almost all my needs and should last a long time.  Recommended.

My ASUS RT-N66U Dual-Band Wireless-N900 Gigabit Router is in one corner of my basement and is required to supply wireless on both the 2.4 Ghz and 5.0 Ghz bands in my three level home.  Although I think that the Asus does an admirable job doing this, sometimes the wireless strength can be a bit iffy in the far corner of the 2nd floor, esp. with the 2.4 GHz band which is rather crowded due to about 20 other signals I pick up from the neighborhood.  So I was happy to give this set of Linksys High-Gain Antennas a try.So here are the test results I got from using Inssider Home software.  Note that with both sets of three antennas I observed the power vary considerably over time, so below I have listed the best case (highest signal) observed.** RT-N66U using the stock antennas (advertised peak gain 3dBi/ 5dBi) - measures -50db max at 2.4 GHz, -60 dB max at 5.0 GHz (closer to zero is better).** RT-N66U using the Linksys antennas (advertised peak gain 4dBi/ 7dBi) - measures -49 dB max at 2.4 GHz, -50 dB max at 5.0 GHz.So in my house, after tweaking the antenna positions a few times, I ended up with an insignificant 1 dB improvement at 2.4 GHz and a surprising 10 dB improvement at 5.0 GHz.  Now it is possible that my old stock antennas were not in an optimal position, since a 10 dB improvement is way over what I should have expected with this upgrade - however it is clear that these antennas did give me a stronger 5.0 GHz signal in the farthest reaches of my house.I do have two issues with these antennas.  The first is a complete lack of documentation; there is nothing inside the product box other than the antennas themselves.  I would have hoped at least for some information on optimal positioning of the antennas.  The second issue is the high price - I was provided a set of these for review but even with the improvement observed I could not justify spending more than about half the current price on these.  But if you really need that last bit of 5.0 GHz signal strength, and can get these for an acceptable price, then the I would the Linksys High-Gain Antennas a recommended upgrade.

Note that I received a free accessory kit to try out in exchange for this unbiased review.I'm not going to repeat the number of accessories that come with this product - a complete list was included above.  All I can do is know that these accessories are all of a very high-quality. I was particularly impressed that a large number of genuine 3M adhesive patches were included.  The plastics used seem to be of identical quality of the accessories I received with the original GoPro 2.  Overall a great accessory package for a very reasonable price. Highly recommended.

This Dove cleansing soap Is a good product like almost all of the dove products I have tried.  It lathers well, cleanses well, but still leaves some moisturizer on the skin.As for the scent - I've never been a fan of citrus scented products.  But the scent of this Dove product is so subtle that it is almost unnoticeable.  I would call this a five-star product if you like citrus scents, and a four-star product otherwise.

This is a very good chair, made of very solid cast aluminum and I'm expecting it to last a long time.  The hardware to put this together is steel (hopefully stainless steel) - it doesn't match the black painted surface of the aluminum but is only visible in a few spots and IMHO doesn't detract from the overall appearance.Quality was good, with one quality control oversight (a support on one of the chairs was somehow bent and doesn't work correctly).  I received a replacement part directly from Aosom, and now both chairs work as expected.  Also note that this is being sold at a very good price, but does not include cushions - and I never realized how much some of these cushions can go for!  From the dimensions listed a longer than average cushion (at least 74") is needed to cover this end to end.Overall very pleased, and since we were able to get the one issue straightened out I would have no issue buying these again.

Note that a Smart Weigh scale was provided to me free in exchange for this unbiased review.When I was asked to review the Smart Weigh SMS500 Digital Bathroom Scale, I was glad to accept their offer.  My previous scale was a 15 to 20 year old digital scale that used a non-lighted LCD screen and a solar panel for power.
