nice walking shoe, but it feels clunky.  I like walking shoes to give me all the support I wants (Adidas and Sketchers are much better at this), without feeling like Frankenstein boots.  The shoes was very stiff, very unforgiving.  I was not happy camper.  I have worn Reebok Princess style for two decades and love them.  These were just too heavy feeling.

I really hated to see this book come out with all the hyper and noise.  It made me really scared to read the book.  I must say I was pleasantly surprised.  This is a first book for Lee, and all like all new authors, she is finding her voice.  The beginning is pretty rocky, but she finds more assurance as she goes along.  Ignore what you have heard, read the book with understanding it was a first book, also keep in mind today's politically correct mindset, was different then.  A good measure of how we have grown and attitudes have (hopefully) changed.  Just read it for yourself.***** Be warned *****  my view of Go Set A Watchman contains SPOILERS, but I couldnt see how to express my thoughts without touching on a few points (many already discussed in the countless reviews before the book hit the shelves).I finished Go Set a Watchman this morning and have so many thoughts about the novel.  For one, I think the media flap over Atticus being less than a paragon was hardly more than the publisher sending out PR stories to up their sales.  At some point they took a look and saw presales were not hitting the big money mark that they had greedily anticipated, so they set out to create a mountain out of a molehill; with the help of a few reviews of outrage, they fueled the sensationalism-hungry media and social networks, the pursuing flap drove everyone out to buy it to see for themselves.  Well, perhaps there is a lesson there  never truly judge a book by its cover  or rather, we need to pay smaller heed to the fray and just read it for yourself.  You might be surprised.  I was.I went in to buying the book feeling concern for Harper Lee.  Had she been taken advantage of?  Did she even pen the book?  Some of the circumstances of the finding of the novel have been called into question by various sources.  This came on the heels of Lee having to sue to get her rights for To Kill A Mockingbird back from the nephew of her former agent, that she had been duped into signing them away, even an investigation into concerns of abuse of the beloved author, who had trouble seeing and hearing and no champion to protect her.  It was a murky whirlpool of speculation that saw the book making it into print.  I know one thing without a doubt  Go Set A Watchman was penned by Harper Lee.  The book is hers.  Unpolished in places and dealing with a period of growth for the nation, it wasnt a pretty picture she painted, but it was an honest one from her stand point and typical for the era.  But beneath the shaky start to the book, you hear Lees beautiful prose ringing clear, especially when you go through the flashbacks of Jem, Dill and Atticus.There is a tendency to see this book as a sequel to To Kill A Mockingbird.  It begins with a grown up Jean-Louise Finch returning home for her annual visit to Maycomb, Mississippi.  Atticus is now aging, nearly eighty-years-old, and fighting to retain his pride though crippled with rheumatoid arthritis.  He needs Jean-Louise home, but is too proud to ask her.  Instead, his sister (which we met in To Kill A Mockingbird) is there to help him through his everyday life.  Jem is gone, lost to a sudden heart attack  the same thing that had claimed their mother when Jean-Louise was too young to recall.  You have a sense throughout the whole story that Scout hasnt truly grieved over the loss of her hero brother, hasnt been able to let him go.  It gives you a sense that he is still alive for her, as long as she keeps him locked in the cocoon of childhood memories.  Dill is spoken of, but never plays a role in the book outside of flashbacks.  You sense a detachment from her beloved childhood friend, which mirrors Harper Lees own estrangement from Truman Capote (the model for Charles Baker Harris).  And beloved Calpurnia, who served as mother to Jean-Louise, is now retired.  Their reunion is bittersweet and tears at the heart.  Other characters from To Kill A Mockingbird are scattered about, lending an instant familiarity, but their roles are changed in various ways.  Walter Cunningham, who got her in trouble with that dumb lady teacher, is no longer that poor little boy who pours molasses all over his plate, the son of the man who works off his entailment by bringing nuts to the Finch house early in the morn  the only form of payment he can afford.  Instead, Walter owns the Maycomb ice cream parlor, built on the land where Scouts old home once stood.In the first few chapters you hear a young writer struggling to find her voice.  The first three have a flat, detached feel to them, almost another voice, almost like Lee was trying to sound like an author rather than be one.  The harder she tried the farther she got away from her own natural magic.  Other times, shes dead on target and straight from her heart.  As the book progresses you are treated to remembrances of Jem, Dill and Atticus.  Oddly enough, there is no mention of Boo Radley.  There is a mention of a trial, an echo of Tom Robinsons, but this young black man, accused of rape by a white woman, lost his arm to the sawmill instead of the cotton gin, and this time Atticus saw him acquitted.  Seeds planted that would come full force and be the center of Atticus great journey in To Kill a Mockingbird.  All these changes see Watchman a sequel, and yet not truly a sequel.You quickly sense there are two voices struggling within the character  Jean-Louise in the present, but also Scout who never truly went away.  She has moved to New York, tried to be worldlier.  Instead, she just put a veneer over the shy, tomboy that never quite fit in.  Its that duality of the book, which took a few chapters for Harper Lee to master.  Through the unfolding of the story, we learn Jean-Louise is really just Scout in an adults skin.  Its the battle between who she thinks she is, and who she truly is that causes most of her misery.  She still sees the town and Atticus through Scouts eyes.  Following Scouts recollections as she grew we learn, while horribly bright and encouraged to read about everything, she is quite backward about life in general  terrified she is dying when her first period comes, which evolved later into nearly nine months of wretchedness after she mistakenly thinks shes pregnant from French kissing Walter Cunningham.  Currently, she loves Henry, the boy next door, but shes not in love with him.  In many ways the young man, best friend to Jem, has stepped into Jems shoes for Atticus.  What to do?  She hates the town she grew up in with a passion, yet loves it and wants to cling to the past with equal measure.  Shes horrified Atticus could have ever attended a KKK meeting, but in Jean-Louises simplified view of life, there are no grays.  It never occurs to her Atticus was a man who moved through Maycomb, handled legal matters, dealt with judges, lawyers, politicians and businessmen, and it was vital for him to know which ones hid behind a mask.  Scotland has a saying, you hold your friends close, and your enemies closer.  Atticus was merely following that sage adage.  However, Jean-Louise cannot see beyond the surface, only that Atticus had done something that went against everything she believed he was.As we grow our perceptions of the world changes.  We learn, accept, reject and are changed by the various trials and tribulations.  Jean-Louise didnt change.  She was still Scout inside, still clinging to her childish views of life, her hometown and the people she loved.  Much like Lee herself.Go Set a Watchman is a worthy companion to the later To Kill a Mockingbird.  Its different in many ways.  Its a first book of an author, and showcases the shining talent of that writer finding her way, of becoming a wordsmith that would go on to turn out a masterpiece.  I think its an example, showing any author how to take their novel and go back and do second, third or fourth drafts to take a good story and make it something special.  Some of the writing, where Jean-Louise is examining the views on race relations of the period, Lee wanders between a Joan of Arc mentality to mounting a very preachy soapbox.  Much can and will likely be made of her simplistic views of the period, of good and evil, of the towns resistance to the coming end to segregation.  For those too young to recall the ugly face of history, you will probably judge the book harsher than those of you who lived through the upheavals and changes and understand the complexities first hand.Frankly, I was scared to read the book after all the hoopla in the media.  I so loved To Kill a Mockingbird that I feared this book would destroy that love somehow.  She says Maycomb had once been told it had nothing to fear but fear itself.  I supposed I should have recalled that line.  In the end, I laughed, I cried, and I was sad when the book ended.  And extremely sad such a wonderful, wonderful writer never penned more books for the world to enjoy.  I loved this book almost as much as I do To Kill A Mockingbird.  Harper Lee has said she is Boo.  The summer we started so long ago has ended and Boo has finally come out.  When considering this book one needs to recall what Lee wrote about Atticus saying never judge someone until youve climbed into his shoes and walked around in them.  That is good advice about reading Go Set a Watchman.

I use these to keep stretching my tendons after injury.  I like them because they keep the foot flexed to keep stretching without really pulling on muscles.  I often sleep in them.Be sure to order to your size.  I got ones a bit larger and I need to wear two pairs of socks to keep my foot in place.  It's really do what I need.Three straps hold you in place - over the middle of the foot, the ankle and below the knee.  There are angled side straps.  These two are adjustable to you can increase or decrease how much flex you required.  They are comfortable, padded, and very lightweight.It has rubberized tread on the bottom, so I can clump around in them, but I would caution using them indoors.  Not sure the tread is made to take pavement.
Great product that really works.  I have been using it a year and it's really made my feet nice again!

I needed a moccasin style shoe for injured foot, so saw these and got them for me, knowing men's were wide.  They were precisely what I wanted, fit exactly as promised.  Good protective sole.  Almost snug, making them easy to walk in, but plenty of room for comfort.  Inside lining is very  comfy without being hot.

Gorgeous Anuschka.  The purse sells for much more elsewhere.  You cannot beat Anuschkua's quality or style.  A little more grey than the blue of the picture, but still a great buy for a super purse.  Now own two - one for me and one for my friend.  We love them.

I wanted exterior blinds and purchased a set advertised as such at well-known home improvement story.  Within a week, they were a mess!  I called about returning them and the manager informed me they were rated for indoor use.  I said NOT according to your website.  They took them back, and then I set out to find good replacements.  I bought this and absolutely love them.  The Bamboo is such a hard word, so they are taking weather well and just getting stronger.  The sewing is triple done, sometimes more, so these blinds just take a liking and keep on looking great.  Well worth the money when you need a blind for exterior us.

Anushka handbags are amazing!  Hand-painted, the cover various motifs, but I think "Cats in Wonderland" one of their very best.  I bought this one for a friend's birthday.  She loves cats, loves Anushka, so what better thing to give.  She really wanted this purse, but I knew she wouldn't get it for herself, so I was delighted to be able to give it too her.Aside for the cats and the brand, it's a great handbag.  Not too big, not too small, it's -- as Goldilocks would say -- just right.  It has lots of pockets, for phones and whatever, and you can also purchase the matching wallet and other items.  Using Anushka protector spray from the start seems to bring out the colours even more, and stop it from wearing.  Having owned Anushka's before, they will wear, but properly cared for, the fade to a beautiful patina that see the used bags selling for more than news ones!Designer items so often don't live up to the price tag.  Anushka does.(Photo is my friend with her birthday present)
I bought this because the information in the listing said it works with "HP cameras".  Well, it might for some, but does NOT work with HP  W380t.  So I wasted my moey.

I have three top KT tapes and this is one.  It does everything a KT tape should do, but has the added bonus of being pre-trimmed and cut.  You just pull these off the roll and slap them on.  Strong support, superior adhesive.  Love my KT tape and this one lives up to what it promises.

This is my FAVORITE shoe for walking.  Have bought this brand and style for two years.  However, the shoddy workmanship this year is really turning me sour on them.  I seriously buy about six pairs a year (or more), so what I am seeing is not just one pair.  I have worn the same size for two years, have a dozen pairs.  I have purchases 5 pairs this year and each one had flaws.  One pair the heel was 1/2 inch shorter in the back causing the heel to slid up and down and rub a blister.  Two pair were too narrow, wore, the vamp of the shoe was nearly 1/2 inch or more shorter.  I bought two more pairs a half a size bigger, and they came in SHORTER than the first batch.  The padding in the front is thinner.  It hurts my metatarsal bone in my right foot, because there isn't enough shock absorbed.  And strangely enough, the show strings are too short.  You cannot tie them in a bow!!  I see so many corners cut in the quality from a pair two years ago compared to this years crop.  DO NOT buy them mail order, but go try them on.  The 'relax" fit style seems a bit better.  They are doing so many styles and so many colors.  However, they need to  maintain quality.
Birds love this ones, especially several types of woodpeckers and nuthatches.  Doesn't melt in rain or heat and the berry smell is STRONG.  They couldn't love it more.

I have been using KT tapes since last December, when my Physical Therapist used it to stabilize my kneecap injured in an accident.  I cannot say how much how it helps with stability without the problems of sports tape (allergy) or ACE bandages (too tight, too loose, wrapping slips constantly.  I am not having any allergy problems with KT.  I get superior support, easing my pain.  You DO need to learn how to apply them, cut and trim them etc.  That said, once you get the knack you will love this aid.  Gives me support, stabilization (love it more than Tommy Copper).However all KT tapes are NOT the same.  If you opt for cheaper ones, you won't get the long lasting results or the needed support.  Beast is tops, but ARES compares very well with it.  It feels slightly lighter in fabric, but I found it to be very long lasting (5-7 days easily for me - be sure to dap at the tapes after showering - do not rub).  This tape really works with your body heat to keep the saying power.  I really rate it 4 1/2 stars - it did have a little stringing to the edges, but it didn't affect the overall use.

What a blessing for knees!  My knees were in dangerous shape after injuries this past summer.  My Orthopedist started me on this.  He warned it would take 4-6 months to see full effect, but after 2 1/2 months I can really tell the difference.  It's rebuilding the joint fluid between the knees, to where it is more comfortable, almost like a pillow between the bones.  It reduces joint inflammation, helps rebuild fluid and bones, and has a joint shield.  I wish I had been on this five years ago!

I hate that I have to use a cane right now, but after knee injury this past summer I had no choice.  I bought one of the regular style ones.  Works okay, but I was constantly having to deal with it falling over when I paused and needed my hand free.  This ones has the four head bottom, so you can literally stand it up and it will stay standing when you take your hand off.  The handle is curved for palm comfort.  The handle is make of rubber material that is soft and comfortable, yet won't wear out easily.  Adjustable length.

great stretchy tape - provided you can stand latex.  Anyone with latex allergy is in trouble.  It's very rubbery feeling, stretchy, long lasting, waterproof, and compared to Kensiology tape.  It's much thicker and heavier than Kensiology tape, but in some instances such as where you have to walk on it, it proves just a bit better than Kensiology tape.  However, that is likely the only point it is better than KT.  I am allergic to latex, so had a reaction to it.

Great Cast -- Basil Rathbone, Hugh Herbert (adorable as Mr. Penny) Bela Lugosi, Broderick Crawford (in one of his rare comedic touch rolls), Gladys Cooper, Alan Ladd, and Gale Sondergaard.  An Old Dark House style of movie.  Old lady with loads of money and herds of cats gather her money-grubbing family together to hear the terms of her will.  All but one granddaughter wants grannie dead so they can get their mitts on the money, her house, and the barn load of antiques it contains, worth more than the house.  But grannie is one smart cookie -- the various children and grandchildren will inherit -- but only after all her cats are dead.  Until then, her companion will rule the roost and protect the kitties.  Needless to say grannie is in peril, and next in line on the "who done it" list is the companion.  Only, the kitties will prevail...Great fun.  So pop the popcorn, turn out the lights, and enjoy this wonderful Black and White spooky house murder mystery.

I recently bought one that is auto-pedal.  I am going through Physical Therapy and want the motion with no stress on my knee joints.  I really like it with the minor reservation of it being light to where it scoots across the floor away from me when I am sitting on the sofa.  I am used to walking 3-7 miles per day, but haven't been able to do that with the knee injuries.  My friend Candy walks with me, so she is unable to walk while I am on the side like.  She tried mine, and loved it -- same problem of it scooting though.  I decided to buy her one so she wouldn't miss out on her exercise.  However, since she didn't need the auto option, I looked at a similar model without the electric go....lol.  This one looked really good.I bought it on Amazon Prime with two day ship, but it came the next day.  It was very easy for me to put it together for her.  The pedals screw into the bar easily and had it's own wrench to tighten them down.  The bottom strands, again, were very easy to put in.  Allen wrench is provided.  Within a minute, it was done and ready to use.  It's heavier than my version, so it stays in place.  She absolutely loves it.  She can crochet and pedal at the same time to her hearts content.

I cannot believe what this tape does.  The stuff is a miracle.  My Physical Therapist has been using them on my knees and I cannot believe how good it works.  You MUST learn to apply it properly, learn to round the corners.  This company gives you an e-book with purchase.  Read it.  You simply cannot just slap it nilly willy and get the correct results.  Once you learn, and you see the immediately protection and pain relief, you will be kicking yourself for not using this before.  I am getting PT on my right leg, which they were wrapping.  Only my left began to grow even worse in pain.  So I wrapped it myself, and instantly the pain stopped.  We are talking level 9 pain, and it just quit.  The roll will give you 3-5 cushion wraps around your knee (this is double tape on each side of the knee cap.  If don't right, they generally last me 5-7 days.  You must be careful when showering (I wouldn't recommend soaking in a tub).  Pat the tap dry - do not rub.  You have no bulk or slippage as with ACE bandages.  Way better than any type of sports take out there.  Great for walkers or runners, great for people with arthritis or muscle strains.

I started on this with prescription from my doctor, but the stuff ran me nearly $100 a bottle.  Thus, I a delighted when it was released without a script.  Simply one pump in each nostril in the morning and it blocks all the allergen problems.  I haven't had to take any sinus medications in nearly a year (and I used to live on the pills...lol)
Good design, great idea, but the execution isn't quite there.  I am not satisfied how it stay (or doesn't) popped up.  Material is not really good quality.
I purchased this for one of my rental properties.  It was easy to replace, quick install and really does a good job and looks nice.

I am a lemon nut.  Love the clean fresh, non perfume scent.  It's strong.  Spray a little and wait a bit.  Where most scents disappear after spraying, this one actually gets stronger.  So adjust how much you want gradually, until you are accustomed how this works.  It's long lasting and leaves everything clear.

this really helps with my dust allergies.  I can tell after you spray that I get immediate relief from dust and dust mites.  Love it.  A nice pleasant smell that isn't overpowering.  For allergy suffers this can really help.

very lovely hat, that is stylish and warm.  Since cold weather hit, I have been wearing it and each time I received dozens of complements from strangers how much they like it.  Well, made and very reasonably priced.

I love these.  I know have several Tommie Copper items.  I am unsure how they might or might now aid in the healing so far (only been using them a month), but I know they really help block the pain and keep vulnerable joints warmer.  The other night after Physical Therapy my legs were so achy I couldn't sleep. I put these on and fell asleep and rested well.  They are extremely comfortable, no problem wearing them under clothes and sleeping in them if you need.

Absolutely love these!!  I am going through rough spot with my knees after several accidents this summer.  I have been going to Physical Therapy and part of that is heat packs for my knee.  I am having problems convincing them it's BOTH knees...lol.  So I decided to get my own heat packs.  These looked study enough.  I wanted something heavy and big that would wrap completely around my knee.  They do that, so it's a cushion for your knee plus having the heat wrapped around the whole leg.  2-3 minutes zap in the microwave will give me half hour of good solid heat.  Feels like heaven to the joints.I saw a complaint about the buckwheat shifting or not being even.  Well, it can shift.  Anyone who has had a buckwheat pillow will not what you are dealing with.  You just shake the filling back into place.  The covers come off so they can be washed.  They also can be used for cold packs, though I haven't tried this as yet.  My target is good heat.  I think they provide heat as well as the Physical Therapy ones, maybe even better.I cannot be more pleased with the results, the size, the quality of the wrap, or how they work for me.
I love this Thistle Tea.  A very mellow, full flavoured tea, no bitter after taste.  One of my favourites.  I was surprised since Thistle tends to be bitter, but the tea is anything but.

Hubby has been having eye troubles for last year and a half; rips in his retinas, causing numerous laser treatments.  The rips allowed fluid to escape into the eyeball,  It will take nearly two years for all the fluid to be absorbed.  He has "floaters" in his vision.  Since he prefers dim light, those black keyboards with faint white lettering is a strain for him to use.  I saw this and got it for him.  He loves it.  The bright eyes show the big lettering.  Soft touch so more comfortable for the fingers when writing.Unless it received direct light source to charge it, it doesn't glow.  It's like the early glow in the dark watches.  It must have strong light for long period to charge the luminous ability to work.  Even when not glowing, the keys stand out for easy vision.He's an grumpy sort who doesn't take to change, but he's finding this excellent solution to dim light and much less strain on his vision.

I run my phone down quickly taking so many pictures.  No lighter option in my vehicle so a friend brought me this.  This charges and the tip turns blue will at full charge, green where there is about half juice left and red when it's too low. So with a click I can tell how much a charge it holds.  It does my phone a full charge, and then some.  Generally better than a charge than a half.  I have the 9000 version, too.  Love them both.  Easy to use, right out of the box.  I have been using it for over four months and like both version. No problems during that period.  Having a charge plus tucked away in my pocketbook is always peace of mind.

I love all the Fabreze products, especially their seasonal pumpkin scent.  However, this allergen reductions really is good.  I used to use Lysol sprays to keep down the dust mites in pillows, throw pillows, blankets, throws and mattresses.  This seems to be a slightly better job, and has a nice clean fragrance.  Nice for curtains.  My noses loves no dust mite allergy reaction.  :-)

I discovered the lighter in my vehicle was for show (after I found the adapter charger wouldn't work...lol).  A friend brought me this one and the tube stick version and I love them.  Easy to use. When fully charged you get four blue lights.  As they power goes down the lights lessen until time to recharge.  It says it will recharge phone 4 times.  I got  5 1/2 recharges on mine.  Since I travel a lot, and use my phone for taking pictures, and don't have the car recharge option, this is perfect.  I've had it four months and it hasn't give me any trouble and I use is 4-5 times a week.  Since I travel about in the summer a lot, this is very handy for me.  When I used it to charge my laptop, I got two charges for it.  I just charge it, pop it into a pocket in my purse and I never have to worry about my phone or laptop going out on me now.  I really like it's reliability and how I can charge my toys with no problem when I'm out and about.

I struck a deal a long time ago to feed my three squirrels - Heckle, Jeckle and Mighty Mouse - peanuts and they will leave the bird feeders alone.  I was dealing with another source through amazon, but they had problems, so I was left without a bulk source for my squirrel food.  I was delighted when this one turned up.  50 pounds with reasonable shipping, so I was able to keep my three friends in nuts during this bitter winter.  Quick ship.  Very delighted with this firm.  My furry friends give it up paws up!
This song just holds it's quality and is still moving.  Buy it, turn it up and rock. One hit wonder that created perfection.

These are great to pop up anyplace you need a light and don't care to run wiring.  I have a deep linen closet.  Pop one of these under each shelf and 'let there be light'.  Great for a staircase or a safety light for when lights go out.  Last a long time on the battery and give bright white light.

My cats love catnip, and you can tell this is "good stuff"  Recreational drugs for the felines...lol.  I got a sack from the store and they liked it.  But with this they went WILD.  So Mouse and Boots give it four paws up each.

I love these style of gloves.  My hands get cold, and for the long nights when I spend at the keyboard writing they are just the think.  These however, are more for wearing for staying warm outside.  They are thicker and make it feel heavy when I used them for writing.  The colours are brilliant, the craft well done.  So if you are looking for gloves without tips for general use, these are 5 star.  I dropped it a start for they are not good for author's hands, or for someone sewing or knitting.

It's leather, which seemed rather good for the price.  Usually they are not.  You have choice of colors.  I chose the navy.  The keyboard was easy to set up for the Kindle.  I like the feel of it (and I am a Laptop baby).  I saw no real downside to this, but would have preferred the prop back, would have had some locking mechanism.  It's a bit unstable on some surfaces.  It seems to cushion the kindle, yet retain the slim feel so easy travel.

Rather light weight.  I figured it to be more "bean-bag" sense, with denser material.  Very light weight material and Styrofoam tubes on each side, so gives you a sense of being cheaply made.  Easy to install, you just slipped it under the door.  It would stop draft, so does what it says.HOWEVER, if you have cats, they will HATE this.  I mostly bought this to stop two cats from play pattycake under the door.  Mouse nearly put out Boots eye when he was peaking under, so I assumed this would be a good solution.  No one could see under the door, so no more pattycake.  WRONG.  Boots hated he couldn't see under the door and about drove me NUTS pulling it under the door.  I doubt I could tug it under the door, but muscle boy did, ruining the cover in the process.  So if you have cats, you might want to save the money.Updated as Jan 5th:I am updating this review of this because of new experience.  As of this morning it's nearly 10 below zero windchill factor.  I just got a new kitty - Loki - a foundling that I took in just before this bad weather hit. I knew he couldn't stay out and survive in this coming weather.  It is a heated carport room, but the draft was blowing like crazy.  I needed to stop the draft.  I recalled I had bought it for Boots and went to get it.  Again, it was easy to put in, and BOY was I impressed.  It totally stopped the icy blast from this sub zero temperatures.  This door is opened to the outside, and yet, the blast of cold air was totally stopped.

I fell from a ladder in my 20s and it, naturally tended to make my back a problem from them on.  Sometimes Aleve just doesn't do what I want.  Then I recall these and grab them.  They really help and have me to moving free again.  Torn my rotor cuff on my left shoulder, so I hope they work a little higher too.Aspirin free - do check with any medicines you are taking.  This has a diuretic in the mix, so might not be what you want if you are taking something along those lines already.

I am forever cold feet cursed.  Winter comes and my toes stay cold.  I ordered a vibrating/heating snuggy for them which was waste of money.  This is perfect.  You pop them in the microwave (I put them in an unsealed Glad bag - makes them really nice).  I only takes a minute or so, and then you have a good warm to really soothe those cold toes.It says something about them being aromatherapy, too - lavender scent.  I couldn't tell that, but I wasn't really going for that.

With the brand name, I expected more from this item, especially at this price.  It's basically a box with fleece lined snuggies for your feet.  The vibration is only so so.  Relaxing but little more.  The heat is where I really drop the stars.  It BARELY warms up.  I expected something nice and toasty to help cold feet.  I can tell it's "warm" but it's nearly nothing.Take my advice and do not waste your money on this pathetic excuse for vibrator/heater.  Your feet deserve better

a cat toy cats will play with.  I bought this after seeing Jackson Galaxy using them on his Cat From Hell show.  For once, it's a toy the cats LOVE.  I have bought three now and they just have so much fun with them.  The construction of the bird makes it "fly" as you spin around.  They chase it, them leap through the air...Mouse, Boots and Algie LOVE Da Bird!!

I have original hardwood floors in my home.  They were treated with Gym-set - a special vanish that is used on basketball floors, so they never turned orange as oil ploy does.  They have a glass like shine that I love and I wish to keep them that way.  I have been using Bona products and were very pleased with them.  I read some reviews that raved over Holloways, so I had to try them.  It's very good, but doesn't deliver the high gloss that Bona sealer/refresher does. I used the Holloways on my floors and was so disappointed that I cleaned them and put the Bona on again.Holloways does work on other flooring, so it might be great on tile or stone.  But not on my hardwood floors.

I bought another of the Maytex curtains when prepping my income property for rental.  The other was a bit more pleasing in design, but this one is very good, too.  Well make, inexpensive. Very pleased with Maytex.

I was doing updates for my rental property, preparing to lease it out again.  I wanted something to perk up the bathrooms.  I got this one for, and the picture doesn't do it justice.  Nicely made, it appears more costly that the very reasonable price.  I was very pleased how it freshened up the look.

I have to deal with yeast overgrowth when I take infection fighters.  Sometimes getting a head of the battle is nearly impossible.  I went through so many things that all claimed to help.  This one did.  Yeast is very hard to keep in line, but it's easily managed with this product.  I have used it for about five years.  It's never let me down.

the concept of these hoses are great.  Contract to nothing that is easily stored, expand with water pressure.  THERE the good ends.  I have bought two different sets of these - the original green ones and two of the blue ones.  Of the four, two have the inner rubber lining explode from water pressure.  One had the inner rubber lining pull away from the attachment fitting.  They never contracted as good as they said.  If they could make one that is quality that will live up to what the promise, then you will have a good hose.  Unfortunately, so far they are junk.  I really enjoyed them for the couple weeks they worked, but they are way too expensive to be replaced twice a month.

love this small flashlight.  This is handy size flashlight, you can slip into a pocket.  The end had a hook so you can snag it on something to keep track of it.  And the light is VERY BRIGHT.  Waterproof, what more can you want.  I have bought many torches over the years, but this one is tops.  Lightweight, super bright, and can be hooked on a purse strap - and at a great price.  Highly recommend this one.

I ordered this to help Algie and Boots learn to share the carport room.  Well, that was a bust.  Simply no way to get them to be pals - unless Jackson Galaxy takes pity on me and helps.  Boots inside now.  Algie is using the cage for kitty cave.  I have subzero king size sleeping back over the cage, and a second sleeping back inside. I put it close to the heater and he stays toasty.  So it's working for me - just in another fashion.Easy to put together, but really a to man job as it's nearly five foot tall.  Well done, strong, with double turn locks on each door.  Down the road at the feed store they put hammocks across them and the cats love them.  There is enough room.Easy to move around since it's on wheels.  Well worth the price.

I love the features of this pedometer.  I walk nearly every day, and love to keep track how far.  I just start this at the beginning of the walk and it tracks it, gives me distance, calories burned and how many steps.  Easy to use.  However, it seems to 'hang' giving you inaccurate readings.  I can walk the same route and get 4 different distances walked.  Sometimes it crashes or just stops working.  It was free version, so perhaps the paid version works well.  You might also want to check calories burned with some place like MapMyWalk .com because it seems to underrate calories burned.

I keep suet year around for my woodpeckers.  I have several varieties and they love the suet.  They love the berry one, and go wild over the peanut butter one, but they especially love this one.  The orange scent is strong when you open it.  The suet works well in cold weather or hot -- it doesn't 'melt' even in the highest summer heat.  The others come in a pack of 16, so it's a bit more costly with only 12.  But the birds love it.

I needed 120 V to 12V converter adapter to get my 1964 Seeburg Wallette Console to light up.  This one compared to many (and i do mean many) that I have for Kindles, phones etc.  But priced about half of the others i have purchases.  Does what it  needs to do and saves you money. So good deal.

4:04 Mins I had actually been looking for one of these and they happened to reach out to have me do a review.  I immediately liked the shape, compact design and faux wood look when I saw it in person.  The lid easily comes off to add the water and oils making it simple to refill and use.Included is a measuring cup as well as a marking on the side of the water tank itself. They make it so you cannot make a mistake there.  I added a few drops of different types of oils over the test and enjoyed the quiet function of the unit as well as the lights.  You can choose a mode to cycle through the lights, pick a specific color or even shut the lights off entirely.They built in auto shutoff capabilities when the tank runs low making this perfect for filling the room at night with a relaxing scent and falling asleep with no worries. It is also great to run after cooking and before guests arrive.We did try this is varying sized rooms and found that mid sized rooms were best.  Large open air design rooms never got enough scent pushed into them.  While small hall bathrooms it became too much. You cannot adjust how much flows out of the unit, just when it is on or off.  Bedrooms and other medium rooms benefit the best.A great little oil diffuser for the home with cool lighting effects.  See the video for even more.

2:33 Mins I was hesitant when thinking this would be useful or work as advertised.  This doorknob just makes life simpler.  The ability to work with the door when your hands are full by bumping the handle, pulling the handle or using it regularly makes you frustrated when you get to other standard doorknobs that do not have the same feature.We installed this between the kitchen and laundry room first and found carrying clothes or coming in from the garage to the kitchen with groceries was so simple.  Even normal usage of twisting the knob works great.  Installation was simple and took less than 30 minutes.  They send multiple size fitting in the box for most any door.  You just need a couple screwdrivers and you are on your way.  I changed out the knob, latch and lock portion without any other tools.When I moved this to a storage room door I found myself bumping into the door to the laundry room expecting to hit it with my hip and it not opening.  I am eager to get the other ones I ordered to place them around the house on doors where you tend to carry items.NOTE: this is not made for doors on the outside of your home. It does have interior locking but not a key feature.  See the the other models made by Brinks that are made for the outside with the same feature.- The video and the enclosed instructions make it so simple- It fits standard 1 3/8 and 1 3/4 width doors.- It fits both 2 3/8 and 2 3/4 backsets- Installs in about 30 minues- It is an interior door only with no key lock but the pin hole on other side to openSee the video for unboxing and enclosed parts.  Then see the above videos from Brinks themselves on installation and how cool it works! We didn't feel the need to recreate that!

5:09 Mins See the video for the unboxing and moreWe were eager to get a new mixer for the kitchen and this was a good option since it included a couple bowls and attachments.  The weight of the unit makes it sturdy on the counter while it operates.  We were lucky and got all the feet on the both unlike some reviewers.  We tested this with liquid and heavier fought and did find vibration on the heavier ones at medium and higher speeds.We really enjoyed the slider on the front bottom to move the bowl around so we could add ingredients. Also the rotation of the bowl also made quick work of scraping the sides as it mixed.  We do wish the power cord was a bit longer.The attachment eject button worked each time and was easy to use being located on top.  The side button that tilted the head back into a lock position made getting the bowl in and out and removing the mixer tools simple.Other features were:Variable bowl speedOff center head and beatersBowl selector12 speed control dialTwo sizes of stainless steel mixing bowlsDie-cast metal bodyChrome steel dough hooksregular beatersWhisksOverall this is worth having in the kitchen and the value. I love the bundle that gives the bowls and attachments all in one as well.  Good job Sunbeam.  See the video for more.

The first thing we noticed was the length of the rope.  At over 9ft it should be great for taller people. The ease of adjustment makes it a winner for everyone.  You can unscrew the end cap on one of the handles and simply untie the knot, resize and tie again.  You can either cut off the execs cord or  fold up extra and retie it to make it expandable again.  If you need to keep all the length then unscrew each end, untie the knots, center it to desired length and retie and tuck the cord.  That way you keep the extension as someone grows into it.We did find that it was a little light in weight compared to some others making you pull it down in the back swing part. The cord could be a bit heavier.  We cheated and placed a couple small ring weights on it between knots and that solved the issue.The foam handle was nice but I can see that wearing out eventually.  Not a huge deal for the price.Overall we will get good usage out of this. Make sure to check out all the colors.

5:32 Mins I admit to being a person that would often wear foam earplugs at loud events to be cheap and better protect my ears.  I am glad I was able to wear these. I now carry them everyday and use them at least once a day.  The DUBS help filter out that loud and harsh middle range of sound while still allowing me to hear easily.  They are wearable for long periods of time without driving my crazy like most other in ear plugs do.I successfully wore these at clubs, concerts, the office, home, outside and even a mall.  I was curious to learn how much extra noise we actually pick up everyday and it is amazingly different.  Now these definitely do not totally protect your hearing. They are not designed for that so I would not list that as a con. They are made to help filter and protect your ears while being more discreet.It was interesting on the discreet portion as they do fit well as we show in the video. Yet everyone still wanted to know what they were based on the look. I let some people sample them and they were online either bookmarking or buying right then and there after seeing the price point.CONS:- I wish they had more than one size- The carrying case could be smallerIn the video we talk more about the usage test and experiences and show the DUBS from unpacking to trying them on.

4:25 Mins We ar pleased with this car smartphone holder from Getron. they sent it over for review and we put it to use right away on the dashboard and windshield.  We prefer the windshield more than the dashboard for sure.  It stuck longer and more secure there.  WE test this live in the video with an iPhone 5S and a Samsung Galaxy S6 (with case). Both fit well and exposed the underneath ports for charging as needed.Always use the side button to one and close the ratcheting brackets.  We pulled it open once without and found that it was stuck until we played with the side button.  We show this in the video. Otherwise it held the phones securely in place, even upside down on the windshield.The suction cup worked well and help in the heat. We had minor issues on textured or dusty dashboards as expected. So we recommend not using those.See the video for how to assemble the two pieces and more thoughts.

2:06 Mins We instantly liked the weight of the neck pouch from Landing Gear.  The nylon made it breathable and easy to wear.  the strap was luckily not the thin nylon but more like a flat shoestring.  The top velcro has an inner mesh separator that helps keep documents. There is a clear front slot that I do not see anyone really putting anything in as it does not seal at the top.  There are two side zippers allowing you to easily put things in and take out with a simple sliding motion.There is really only two things we wish it had to give it a perfect 5 star.  A headphone cable slot to let me keep my phone or player fully enclosed in the zipper sides.  Also something to help close or seal the clear plastic card holder on the front.We liked how breathable the material felt and could see someone wearing this under their clothes or jacket to keep travel info or daily things close.  The RFID blocking just has to be trusted as there is no easy way to test that.See the video for more!

4:00 Mins This goes under both Mudder and ipow as the distributor and is a god selfie stick (non Bluetooth). We test the selfiestick in the video review with both an iPhone 5S and a Samsumg Galaxy S6 showing the hold and ease of getting it in and out.  Both functioned easily in taking pictures. The hold was decent but a hard shake could dislodge it.  The clip uses a spring so long term usage will also let us update this with any other issues.We wish the audio cable was a bit longer, it seemed stretched for some phone models. The button worked each time and is built into the middle of the stick.  The bracket has a twist lock to adjust to any angle that adds value instead of a single angle type model.See the video for more live demo.

(What is a British book about British job market and British laws and taxes doing on Amazon.com?)This can be short: "Break Free!" is a perfectly decent and sensibly priced book, but Dave Chaplin's "Contractors' Handbook" is a superior, more substantial product. Buy that one, or buy both, and see if you agree with my assessment.
Eric Jain's review rings true to me. There are no complaints - this is a high-quality book - but also there is no feeling that "Refactoring Databases" is a reference that I need to keep.

Oh boy, was I surprised - after ordering the shoes online - by (a) the flimsy, thin fabric, (b) the (invisible) holes in the soles, that amazing Adidas technology I had so "enjoyed" in my previous Adidas sneakers. Today was my first 5K run in Adidas Feather 4. My feet were wet before the run even started, after standing on wet grass, and then it got worse. I felt more water arriving just from running on mud, and a misjudged step into a puddle produced a flood. Not pleasant. Not a problem if you are not planning to run on wet surfaces, but I would still be concerned about the shoes' durability.

I learned of "Living the High Life in Minsk" from an October 2015 article in "Nasha Niva" newspaper, which mentioned "High Life" getting a prize as the year's best foreign book about Belarus at a Belarusian-studies conference. I googled the award's short-list and was surprised to find Per Rudling's remarkable "Rise and Fall of Belarusian Nationalism" among the non-winners. "So this book was selected over Rudling's?", I thought, and clicked "Buy".A week later, I wonder if the award committee's thinking featured a "currency premium": "High Life" was one of only two entries dealing with recent Belarusian history, vs. WWII-and-earlier. On one hand, I see a first-ever history of Belarus-Russia negotiations on oil and gas; given the crucial role they play for Belarus, this naturally comes with context about Belarusian politics, Belarusian economy and Belarus-Russia relationship in general. On the other hand, I just can't get overly excited about a translation-and-synthesis exercise based on 150-200 relatively recent Belarusian business-newspaper articles - but not, say, economic studies - with some sociology sauce poured over to make the book more "academic".... Perhaps I can't, but English-speaking scholars of Belarus can. "High Life" is a well-researched and engagingly written monograph which can greatly improve outsiders' understanding of Belarusian affairs.PS. Who did the translation, actually? How do you (twice) de-acronymize "MAZ" as "Minsk tractor plant"? Minsk Automobile Plant (MAZ) and Minsk Tractor Plant (MTZ) are Belarus's two biggest industrial brands and employers. Having a book about Belarusian economy confuse the two looks odd - "New York Red Sox", anyone? - and shows that the manuscript was not reviewed by a Belarusian peer.

Packt has published most of the QlikView books out there, starting with the de facto "QlikView bible" by Garcia and Harmsen, and following up with (a) the substantial books by Stephen Redmond and (b) the thin, richly priced books by Karl Pover [ok], Tim Floyd [bad], Diane Blackwood [bad] and Christopher Ilaqua [bad]."Creating Stunning Dashboards With QlikView" joins the (b) camp, and brings its average up. The book has an appealing informal, enthusiastic style, and talks about (i) dashboard design in general (think Tufte ultra-lite), (ii) QlikView's visual elements, and (ii) concrete QlikView tips. It is open-and-shut too sketchy for my taste - I would have gone for Garcia and Harmsen or Redmond; let me call the three authors "GHR"  - but here is a more general reservation. By choosing not to discuss data, only the front-end, CSDQV rules itself out as one's "starter" QlikView book: it has to be the second at least. It is too junior for people who had read GHR, or the Wiley-published "QlikView Your Business". Who is left then - people who had gone for the other (b) titles? A suboptimal route if you ask me, but if you must try it, choose Karl Pover's book as its first leg.

I really like the book, but want to bring up two things neglected by its author.One is acknowledgments. "Bayesian Methods For Hackers" did not appear in a vacuum. I would like to see a hat tip to the creators of PyMC, and at least a mention of BUGS, the still-very-much-alive software which brought Bayesian methods to academic masses and inspired MCMC-engine projects like PyMC. Then there are PyMC's cousins JAGS and STAN - these can be familiar to the R crowd - and people who wrote popular books on Bayesian analysis, such as John Kruschke, the author of "Doing Bayesian Data Analysis". (I should also mention James Stone, with his "Bayes' Rule". "Bayesian Modeling Using WinBUGS" by Ioannis Ntzoufras could have had more impact, but its publisher, Wiley, sabotaged the book with greedy pricing and no-frills presentation. Looking into the near future - I see that Manning have their own "probabilistic programming" book in the works, by Avi Pfeiffer). Naming those people, programs and books would provide useful pointers to aspiring "Bayesian hackers".The second reservation is about editorial effort. The very first page (when it used "ascribe" instead of "subscribe") told me that the manuscript had not been proof-read. As I went through the book, I found more unpolished passages, and a handful of lines capable of triggering a facepalm by a statistics professor. Now, this is not a book for statistics professors - they don't tend to use Python, for starters, while BMH assumes that you have Python installed - and the practical question is whether these issues are going to seriously frustrate or mislead the average reader. My answer is "not really". Chapter 3, for example, is dodgy, yet realistically a "hacker" can just skip or skim it. (Kudos on page 77, by the way - simple and effective). Classical, non-Bayesian statistics misunderstood and unfairly maligned? Only a stats prof will care. I think you can get through smaller slip-ups. For example, on page 15, you can quickly figure out that "lambda_" is a vector - unlike "lambda_1" and "lambda_2", which are scalar parameters - and understand what it's for, even though the author is just telling you that it's a function. Or, on page 142, you can figure out what loss function is implemented in stock_loss(), even though the text does not tell you what it is. Page 42 asks "Why is the gamma axis greater than 1?" You realize that it's Y, not gamma, and the question is asking whether the PDF of a continuous distribution can be above 1, and move on.I find these complaints easy to overlook. Thinking "big picture", I see the first-ever accessible, engaging, visually appealing, practical, inexpensive introduction to Bayesian methods. Echoing - now in a positive way - the beginning of my review, there is a feeling of continuity, of a long-running collective project being advanced. First, a user-friendly MCMC engine is built by the BUGS team. Then, the PyMC team incorporates their MCMC engine into a programming language popular with the "data science" crowd, sprinkling Pythonesque syntax sugar over the BUGS model definition language. Finally, after a few years, a good book on PyMC shows up. Bayesian methods are now accessible to a broad, non-academic audience.American Statistical Association - give this man a medal.

Little things like page 101's listing of Windows and .NET as distinct "platforms" (Unix, Linux and "mainframe operating systems" also feature in the list) or page 159's dodgy description of ROLAP make me question the author's hands-on experience with data warehouse implementation. If Mr. Khan has indeed "consulted for major corporations on data warehousing and business intelligence", he must have dealt with "softer" or higher-level matters. The book feels exactly like a book by a consultant or an academic:  organized (although in this case moderately padded with a number of self-repeats), methodical, big on bullet-point lists and definitions, encyclopaedic, useful to a novice, but not useful to practitioner. Add "out of date" to the list of complaints: the book's substitution of OLAP for "business intelligence" is just one of the things that make the book feel as if it were written in late nineties. Repeating myself, the book will be useful to a beginner - offering an introduction to (a) data warehouse design, (b) OLAP, (c) project management; you can easily find better books on (a), but here you get a 3-in-1 - but people who have been building databases will not lose anything if they pass.

My first encounter with the author's oeuvre was "QlikView 11 Application Development" - boasting a total of 60 pages, and priced at whopping $2.14 per page. I dismissed the book sight unseen, pointing potential readers to two superior, varied choices: the thin, popular book by Pover, and the heavy de-facto-QlikView-bible by Garcia and Harmsen. Reviewers who did give it a chance were not impressed, complaining about missing files and confusing directions.I suspect that "QlikView for Finance" will be getting more of the same: I am looking at page 5, and already (in the last line) the author is asking the reader to build a QlikView table - but is not telling how! Running through vignettes should be easy on an author: Blackwood is not doing that to a high standard, and does not aspire for anything higher-value-added. (An attempt to introduce set analysis, on pages 24-28, fails). There are not nearly enough screenshots - will a QlikView newbie get through, or get stuck?I am not going to dismiss "QlikView for Finance": let a thousand flowers bloom, the book may find a grateful reader. That said, Pover's still looks like a better deal to me - and now there is another appealing alternative, "QlikView Your Business" by Troyansky et al. Do not be swayed by the title's reference to finance - that's a marketing gimmick and a non-factor.PS. Are you sure you want to go with QlikView? Have you seen Qlik Sense? How about Tableau or PowerView?

I will side with the positive review, yet acknowledge that the negative ones are right to say that there is nothing "pro" about this book, and that it does not feel like "expert's voice". This is an introduction to SSAS multidimensional modeling, not something more advanced, like "Expert cube development with SSAS multidimensional models" by Webb, Ferrari and Russo. Moreover, as introductions go, it is not hands-on in the sense of working through specific tasks - the way "Getting started with SQL Server 2012 cube development" by Lidberg, or "Delivering business intelligence with Microsoft SQL Server 2012" by Larson do. The book's strong suit is good writing. You have to have read a bunch of IT books that feel like a run through a multitude of screenshots to take note when you come across an author who works on his text. (A negative review has alleged an inadequate discussion of dimensions - I myself noted an unusual, but not obviously wrong, choice to defer discussion of attribute relationships, and gave the author points for (almost) explaining a couple of things neglected by the other SSAS books). Where does this approach leave "Pro SQL Server 2008 Analysis Services"? It is un-usable as one's learning aid, the book you refer to when you are making your first steps with SSAS, but can be helpful before, for warm-up, or after, for review.

"Look on my works, ye mighty, and despair". Starting tinkering with databases in 2010 and mastering 20 databases by 2014 - while finding time for poetry, dancing and badminton - is an impressive accomplishment in anyone's book. Apart from Vertica (last touched in 2012; I remember the atrocious projections crafted by DBAs using Vertica's designer tool, and the database choking on "select ... where x in (select ...)" queries), SSAS and QlikView might be the only new technologies which I myself picked up over these years - and in each case, there was a good Packt-published book to help me along the way.Sadly, those books were exceptions, and the typical Packt book is a low-quality quickie that looks like a digest of a better book, written by a first-time author hailing from the Indian subcontinent. "HP Vertica Essentials" is just one more example of this quantity-over-quality approach. (And so is one of the other reviews). The book is transparently inadequate, and unnecessary, given that Vertica documentation - helpfully split into thematic volumes - is only a Google search away. ("Concepts Guide" is the best place to start if you are a beginner).

... is my measured response to the reviews entitled "Full coverage of the subject matter" and "A great reference book on SSIS 2012". It is also my warning to those considering this book as an SSIS learning aid.You have to wonder what's going on if the book gets around to building its first SSIS package in Chapter 7: if it were a book for beginners, Chapter 2 or 3 would be a more appropriate place, and if it were a book for intermediate or advanced SSIS users, this introductory material would not be needed at all. The beginner who persevered through Chapters 1-6, learning about the upgrade procedure and the new features of the 2012 release (revised syntax of XML-format SSIS package files, anyone?), gets to load a text file into a database - and then, without a single transformation explained, is asked to implement parent-child packages, and execute them with T-SQL (!) and C# (!!). With this, core SSIS training is over, and the book moves on to more advanced or niche topics like CDC, "fuzzy" transformations and DQS, administration and performance.It is only those more advanced topics, found in Part III, which can make this book worth a look. (The upgrade-and-new-features stuff of Chapters 3-5 can be found online). Although I did consider hiring an assassin to go after the author of Chapter 10 - when talking about SSIS 2012, it is very important to be clear about the differences between package deployment model and project deployment model, and that chapter fails this test like there's no tomorrow - the problem is not really with the individual chapters, but with lopsided, incomplete nature of their sum.Dial M for "Microsoft Press, you sure dropped the ball with this one".

No, it's not an "end-to-end Microsoft BI book" - it could never even be an "end-to-end SSAS Multidimensional book", considering the intentionally limited coverage of MDX - and no, it's definitely not a "complete waste of time". I'd call it a good reference on the multidimensional model - ex-MDX, as noted, although MDX is introduced and discussed - and I definitely found it useful when preparing for the 070-466 exam; my other references included books by Lidberg and DeWald et al., and I liked this one best.

Originally, I gave the book three stars, but after seeing "Microsoft SQL Server 2008 MDX Step by Step" by Smith and Clay I want to give it a zero. Frankly, I am pretty upset with the authors, who produced *this* even with the benefit of seeing *that*. I am also pretty upset with the clueless reviewers. I myself was taken in by the positive reviews, and feel pretty sore about the wasted time and effort. Don't waste a second more on this inferior product - get the book by Smith and Clay.

The title, and the "Overview" section below it, misrepresent the book and limit its audience by portraying it as a collection of "recipes" for advanced SSAS users. In fact, the book offers a comprehensive tutorial of SSAS Multidimensional, and is suited to beginner and (especially) intermediate audiences. (Beginners can also consider the lighter "Getting started with SQL Server 2012 cube development" by Simon Lidberg, and everybody's learning of MDX should start with "Microsoft SQL Server 2008 MDX Step by Step" by Smith and Clay). Originally I gave the book four stars, but after re-reading it a few months later, I am easily giving it five, recognizing both its quality and its "unique selling proposition" as "the" intermediate SSAS-Multidimensional book on the market.

My original review gave the book three stars and complained about it hastily running through SSAS tasks and examples, without stopping to think. Recently, I had another look, and got a more positive impression. One should not demand depth from an introductory book, but one should give points for an accessible, dynamic writing style. "Getting started..." could use more editing - often, the book indulges in "showing off" an intermediate-to-advanced SSAS morsel that looks out of place in the book for beginners, but forgets an essential. Despite the "cubes"of the title, it touches on SSAS Tabular as well, but this is a glance rather than a proper look. If you are starting out with SSAS cubes, I would suggest getting this book and "SQL Server Analysis Services 2012 Cube Development Cookbook" by Dewald et al., and seeing which one suits you best. A second recommendation is "Microsoft SQL Server 2008 MDX Step by Step" by Smith and Clay, which is the best available reference on MDX.
... and Apple's warranty term is one year. This one is my wife's, my own iPad cover was bought for $10 on eBay, looked better, and has not given me any problems. Thanks, Apple!

A problem with the other reviews is that they consider the book in isolation, as if no alternatives were available. "Practical data science" is not the only machine-learning-lite book on the market: Manning itself had published Harrington's Python-based "Machine learning in action", Packt offers "Machine learning with R" by Lantz, O'Reilly boasts "Doing data science" by Schutt and O'Neil, and, finally, Springer has "Introduction to statistical learning" by James, Witten, Hastie and Tibshirani. I have seen and reviewed all except Harrington's; for the purposes of this review, I'll ultra-briefly describe each contender ("Machine learning with R" - thin, average-quality, superficial, but effective at what it sets out to achieve; "Doing data science" - a mash-up of a textbook and a magazine article about kewl data scientists; below-average quality, but a lot of pop appeal; "Introduction to statistical learning" - high-quality, accessible and visually appealing textbook with R illustrations) and get to "Practical data science" - which, to me, comes across as a better-organized, earnest version of "Doing data science". The book's forte is its effort to go beyond a catalogue of R-illustrated machine-learning methods - and you have to have seen similar books to know how standard this repertoire is - and discuss practical skills useful to a budding "data scientist", from version control to presenting. I appreciate this effort, but feel that this content was not sufficiently substantial or polished to develop into a "unique selling proposition" of the kind that each of its competitors has - hence the title of my review.

Call me a grammar nazi, but when an author has trouble with English and does not bother with spell-check - here, problems start on page 1 - what is the chance that he/she has produced a quality product? No surprises here - what you get is a mash-up of an extremely basic, you-can-find-better-stuff-online introduction to R graphics and a not-very-effective introduction to D3.js.  Skip this book without a second thought, and go for a proper reference on R graphics - consider Winston Chang's "R Graphics Cookbook" or the second edition of Robert Kabacoff's "R in Action" - or a proper reference on D3.js, such as Nick Zhu's "Data Visualization with D3.js Cookbook".

This is a nice spatula. It works well for all your baking needs and as expected. The handle is strong and flexible and the silicone is sturdy yet does the job well, you can get everything out of your pan or bowl easily.The marketing for this spatula is a little different,  it is supposed to be cheeky and fun but it may turn off some customers which I would reconsider As a tool this is a great spatula and if you are looking for a spatula i would consider the ProDesign Silicone Spatula for $8 you cannot go wrong!

This is exactly what I needed. This a good quality calcium citrate at a great price. The only issue I have with these is that they are HUGE. I have to break them in order to be able to swallow them easily. They should work to make this pill in a smaller easier to swallow size.

This is a nice basic timer with a large display. The timer is always on and you cannot turn this off without removing the battery, which is not included. For another dollar in price I would pay to have the battery included. The timer works will and press the minute and second together will clear the timer. The timer counts up or down and includes a magnet which isn't very powerful. As a timer this unit works well and is fairly inexpensive. If you don't have or don't know how to use the timer on your over or microwave or phone this is good purchase and does the job well.Thank you for reading

I love these croc flip flops. I never wore flip flops very much because I always found them uncomfortable and just too flat. My feet would hurt or just be stiff after extended walking in other flip flops. These are nicely contoured with a small rise in the heal similar to a sneaker. I wore these all day walking at Walt Disney World without a blister or sore feet! They are very sturdy and my first pair lasted me two years. They would have lasted longer but I was playing soccer with my puppy and stopped too quickly pulling the strap out of the sole. After two years I really cannot complain about that happening.I really wanted another pair of these but anywhere in the store they were $30-$35 but I checked out amazon and they were $26 and I had to have them. I wear a size 9.5-10 sneaker and these fit me perfectly. They go great with anything especially khaki shorts and a t-shirt.I would recommend these to anyone looks for a comfortable all day flip flop at a good price.Thank you for reading

My puppy loves this, she is a chocolate lab and loves to chew on everything. This is perfect for her, she can chew on this without bits and pieces of stuff getting all over or cutting her gums. She will just chew on this until she falls asleep. I really like this it seems almost indestructible. Her little teeth just make grooves in the antler and even then it will take her at at least 8-12 months to get through the antler.I would recommend this to anyone with a larger breed chewer. I only saw larger breed because the antler is very hard and may be hard for smaller dogs. I received an antler that was about 8 inches long and about an inch think at the base, a good size product.Thanks for reading my review and check out my profile for a link to my puppy blog to see pictures : )

I have been looking for a product like this for a few years. I love electronics and I hate the fact that I could not easily view what is on my PC without having to hook my PC directly to my TV. A computer tied to my entertainment center just was not what I was looking for but this is. The iShare dongle is perfect, it is very easy to use once you get it going. The directions could be improved and when I hooked mine up for the first time, the language was in Chinese but with a little guess work I was able to select the right buttons to enter my wireless password. ONce that was completed a popup appeared and looked like an update screen, once this was completed, the language was changed to english and I was ready to go.I tested this using my iPhone 4s and my windows 7 pc. For both items this worked seamlessly, I installed the EzCast software and I was able to mirror my PC screen on my TV as well as mirroring my iPhone screen.I love the fact I can now watch shows I couldn't get through Netflix, hulu or my SmarTV apps on my TV.I would recommend reviewing the instructions and having a little patience but you can get this going and it was well worth the time spent. I would give this five stars if the standard language on my unit was not Chinese and if the instructions were a little clearer.I like this product a lot and I recommend it if you are looking to stream anything from your phone or PC to your HDMI equipped TV.I received this product from the vendor in exchange for the honest and unbiased review you just read.Thank you for reading

This is an interesting multi-function lamp. You first have a 3 setting touch desk lamp that works perfect as a 50 watts equivalent light source with an adjustable stand. You can change the angle of the light, move the arm to get the light right where you want it. Next, you can simply unhook the lamp from the stand and take it with you! You still have the on/off with the dimmer capability. They hook you up with a carabiner so you can clasp the light to your belt or backpack. Based on everything included with the lamp and the quality of the product this is a good value.I found the led is very bright as a emergency flash light or desk light. The 50 watts style light is not super bright but really works nice for a desk/reading lamp.I received this product as a sample from the vendor in exchange for the unbiased and honest review you just read.Thank you for reading.

These little speakers pack and impressive punch. They are not the largest of speakers but Arctic fills them full of features and sound. The sound is full and provides a nice stereo effect as the speakers can be about 32 inches apart.The speakers come with a well built protective case that will allow you to take the speakers with you without risking damaging them. Arctic also has these speakers but with Bluetooth 4.0 in the package allowing for wireless portable speakers Arctic S111 BT Mobile Bluetooth V4.0 Sound-System with 2 x 2 W RMS AAC/aptX - Retail Packaging - Pink. The design is nice as always with all Arctic products with easy to read and comprehend instructions, intuitive battery LED and great sound. I would recommend these speakers to anyone looking for compact speaker with big stereo sound.

These little speakers pack and impressive punch. They are not the largest of speakers but Arctic fills them full of features and sound. I was able to easily pair these with my iPhone 4S and play music within seconds. The sound is full and provides a nice stereo effect as the speakers can be about 32 inches apart.The speakers come with a well built protective case that will allow you to take the speakers with you without risking damaging them. This is a great song, awesome lyrics, singing and music. This just has a great message we can all relate to.  I love the slow to fast beat and the vocals are top notch. You should download this and thank me later.

I love this thermometer. It works great and takes accurate readings. The thermometer comes with button batteries and it easy to use. Simply place it in your ear and take the temperature. each time I took my temperature was within a few tenths, so the thermometer seems consistent and accurate. The thermometer does not default to Fahrenheit or I would give this 5 stars. I love the size and shape, it is not fragile so we can take it with us when we travel without worrying about it breaking and it comes in a nice zipper case.This is a nice thermometer and I would recommend this to anyone as this is a key household item.

This is a nice cover that works well in my 2013 Hyundai Elantra. We use this not only for our dog but in general to save our seats when transporting plants or just anything that could mar up our seats. It fit nicely in our smaller car but in our Silverado it only covers about 2/3 of the seat.The seat cover is easy to clean and does not suck up water and dirt, you can just brush it off. As long as you have headrest on your seat you will be able to use this seat cover. This is a well spent $16 and will save you more than that in the long run.Thanks for reading

This a great thermometer, I used this several times this weekend grilling and it worked perfectly. The thermometer has a long probe allowing you to check the temperature while not having your hand over the flames. The display is easy to read and accurate. The buttons on the thermometer are a tad hard to push and it is a two handed job to pull this out of the case.The thermometer works nice even considering the minor cons. I would recommend this thermometer for someone who likes to grill as its length is nice.

These are nice solid cables. I have reviewed Bundle of 3 Premium Certified 6.5 Feet USB Data Sync Cables for Apple iPhone 4, 4s, 3gs, iPod Touch 1, 2 ,3, 4 iPad 1, 2, 3 (NOT Lighting) (Green Pink Purple) and those cables were much thinner and less reliable than these Airtight cables. This is the third TheraPearl product I have used and each have been very beneficial. The first one I used was the THERAPEARL Neck Wrap, 1.44 Pound and that worked great and I have used the THERAPEARL Sports pack - Rectangle Bag which is similar size as the contour pack without a strap. The contour pack is an oval relief pack filled with therapearls that allow the pack to microwave or frozen depending on the type of relief you need. I know other users have complained about them leaking or not being full of beads, but I have not had that experience. I would recommend this to anyone who has kids or is prone to needing an ice pack or heat pack as this does both well.Thanks for reading.

Another masterpiece by Mark Twain. I had never read Adventures of Huck Finn or Tom Sawyer until now, in my 30's and I wish had read them as a boy. These are the classic misadventures of a young boy, reminds me of me as a child, always looking for fun, adventure and a little bit of trouble. If you realize who the characters are, what the setting of the story is and read the book, you will see that though there is a very liberal use of the N-Word, Twain writes his characters with dignity and pride, not with racism or bigotry. In today's society it may be hard for some to read the n-word and continue on without being disgusted but I ask that you do and you read the story that is there because it a well written novel.

This is the perfect travel water bowl. We use this on walks and we are out of the house. It easily folds up and you can hook it to your belt loop or bag. Just unzip, unfold and you have a water bowl.
