This is a nice BBQ cookbook with several great recipes. Each recipe includes step by step instructions with a color photo of the finished product, so you know what you are getting into. I like the book because there are some simpler recipes like Honey Mustard Chicken or Grilled Lemon Herb Pork Chops and then there are some more advanced recipes like FireCracker Grilled Alaska Salmon. Overall I like the cookbook, there could be a better mention of cooking temperature or cooking style (gas/charcoal/direct/indirect) but the recipes are top notch and I really enjoyed trying some out and can not wait to try them all.For $0.99 this is a great value and I would recommend this to anyone with a kindle and a grill!

I love this case/keyboard combination. I use with my Kindle Fire HD when ever I need to type something longer than a  few words. I also use it with my iPhone because I am a terrible typist on those little screens. I also have hooked it up to my TV to better use the web browsing capabilities on my Samsung SmartTV. The directions are a little lacking but if you have ever hooked up a Bluetooth device this is the same. If you have not, hit the connect button on the keyboard, you'll see it flash, go to your device and select the appropriate Bluetooth menu and select the keyboard. To pair the keyboard you will have to type a few numbers to verify connection, then you all set to go! There are several different hot keys for quick searching, locking the home screen, turning volume or brightness up and down.This is an excellent Bluetooth keyboard. Using this as a case for my Kindle Fire HD was nice as well. The Kindle fits well in the case and it works nicely. Sometimes it is a little difficult to get the angle I was looking for but this was a minor inconvenience.Overall this is an excellent and versatile Bluetooth keyboard case combination and an excellent value for $20.Update 6/24/14 - I found that the keyboard is attached to the case via magnets! So if you are looking to use this keyboard without the case, simply detach the case from the keyboard and you have a portable Bluetooth keyboard!I received a sample for review purposes from the manufacturer.

This OBD2 scanner will pay for itself the first time you need to use it. The scanner will work with any OBD2 compliant vehicle which is almost if not every car made from 1996 to present. All you have to do to use the tool is locate your OBD2 connection, usually under the dash near the steering column. If you cannot find your port, a quick Google search will revel its location usually with pictures. Then with the ignition OFF, plug the scan tool in and then key the key on. Press enter and start the scan. From here you will get your results, you can clear any pesky codes or find out what is wrong with your car. You will get a worst a general idea what is wrong with your car and if you handy you can fix it yourself or at least be armed with the knowledge you need not to get ripped off at the mechanics. This comes with an almost 50 page manual that is invaluable and if there is something that is not covered in there, you can find all the answers and then some on the codes on the internet. I have been able to pin point the cause of the problem with the code(s) provided and description of the problem via an internet search. This saved a lot of money repairing my 2000 Honda Accord.I would recommend this to anyone who is interested in repairing their cars, on a budget, or doesn't trust mechanics(not all are bad!) this will save you a lot of money and provide you with a great source information on your car for less than $25I was provided a sample of this product for a fair and honest review.

I used this to mount my 21" Insignia TV from Best Buy. This mount worked perfect with the 75x75 VESA pattern on the TV and it was easy to mount. The mount came with a template so you can easily drill the holes in the wall and a level to make sure it is straight. The only this I had to do was tighten the bolt where the mount pivots closest to the TV. This was easy with a pair of pliers. The mount moves both in/out and left and right so it is very versatile. This is a heavy sturdy mount and you wont go wrong for less than $15!

If you are having issues with playing the playlist, Amazon asking for credit card info etc, make sure you are logged into your Amazon Prime account before playing music. Without being logged in or having a Prime account you will not be able to use Amazon Prime Music. I hope this helps.This is a good start for a feel good country playlist. There are some great classic songs like:Its a Great Day to Be Alive - Travis TrittJust Another Day in Paradise - Phil VassarChicken Fried -  Zac brown BandThere are a lot of other songs out there they could have added to this playlist. This should be called Feel Good 90's-2000's playlist. The classic country playlist could have a few songs on this playlist as well Like Take This Job and Shove It by Johnny Paycheck as well as others.Amazon is doing a real nice job with the labels they have agreements with so far and I cant wait until they are able to add more. If they are not, I am still happy with Amazon Music!

This is a great classic country compilation with classics from the 50's 60's 70's and 80's. Songs you remember and some you forgot how good they were. This will get your feet tapping and you'll probably want to buy a few of the songs too. This is great to play at a party or just relaxing outside on the porch. If you have friends that aren't into country you can play this and bet by the time its over they will singing along and asking you for more.My favorites from this playlist are in no order:Kenny Rogers - The GamblerHighwayman - The HighwaymenGuitars, Cadillac's - Dwight YoakamFolsom Prison Blues - Johnny CashThere are many other great classics on this album and I know you'll really enjoy this playlist.

I have previously used Armorsuit protectors on all my tablets and phones, but since the Ipad Pro version was not in stock, I tried this based on the reviews. While the installation was similar, the product is not. It is thicker than armorsuit, and while all bubbles left when installing an armorsuit go away within 24 hours, this one has left some permanent ones, despite repeatedly squeegying it when installing. I will be replacing it with an Armorsuit. I am concerned about the thickness vis a vis the Apple Pencil. I wiull say the fit was perfect and the installation was fine.

Absolutely will never use one if these again. Squealed like a stuck pig, slipped. Took my corolla to Pep Boys and had them put on a regular belt and it was quiet as a whisper again. Lesson learned. Pep boys showed me both belts to confirm they were the same size.

Needed this because I added a screen enclosure to my front entryway. Signal will not make it past the screen entryway. about 18 feet between the units, including the front door and entryway screen. This would be fine if its just was by the fron door, but clearly it cannot deal with ceratin obstacle.

I purchased the "HDD not included" version of this and installed my own drive. If you are nervous about installing a drive, no worries, it is easy. I had a four camera system and wanted an eight camera one.Bottom line is it works and was very easy to set up in terms of the hardware. As far as connecting to my iphone/setting up remote viewing, it worked well using a "generic" system and a generic mobile option. This DVR uses a seperate "Media" port setting. The best apps I found for this DVR are IPcam (pro) and Meyecam. They work great.it comes with a mouse and the interface is well designed and easy to navigate. There are youtube videos that walk you through the setupHardware setup: Easy. Installed hard drive with a few screws, attached cables (included with DVR), attached cameras, booted it up and it worked. Seems like it automatically did a quick (five seconds)drive format, and started recording. It really has alot of features and settings for such an inexpensive machine. I am not using PTZ (panTiltZoom)cameras so cannot speak to that feature.I was concerned about heat given the small size of the case and lack of fans, but after running for about 7 hours it was just warm, not hot. Obviously you do not want to put this or any other component (stero, cable box, etc) on a tight space anyway. Since the case is all metal I'd say it probably dissipates heat nicely.On first turning it on it has an annoying alarm/beep system that goes off if you have a disconnected camera. I shut that feature off immediately.If you get it, here is the idiot's guide to getting started, free of Chinglish:1. remove cover and attach hard drive by screwing from the bottom. The four holes align with the bottom of the HDD.2. attach your cameras3. make sure the dvr is where you intend to keep it as the alarms go of when you wiggle the camera cables4. turn it on/plug it in, look at nice color bars for a minute, then right click on screen/camera images anywhere. This gives you the menu, which has a few layers but is easy to use.5. from here you can format the drive, though I think its automatic. Play around with the settings.6. make sure to set the video resolution to its highest (D1) as it defaults to a low res.7. configure your tablet/phone app8. Enjoy watching your cats party it up while you work!! I have seven.

This is an outstanding product that my cats cannot scratch or fray. Yes it is loose, but if you really tuck it in and tie it right it looks and works fine. Here is a trick to keep the tucked material from coming out from under the cushions: get some foam air conditioner weatherstripping M-D Building Products 02535 21/4-Inch by 21/4-Inch by 42-Inch Air Conditioner Weather-strip Open Cell  and tuck this behind the cushion...it will lock the slip cover in place.

compared to other small bone pieces I have purchased where you could clearly see bone structure, these were not really easy to discern from just an ordinary rock even when under 40x magnification. I do not want to suggest they are not real since I am not an expert, but my students were clearly unimpressed and got nothing out of them. Fortunately I had purchased some other small bones on ebay that I could see beforehand and these clearly were bone/organic at one point. It would help if the seller perhaps gave some examples of any kinds of patterns or features to look for in the samples. I will modify my review if I can get such information.
This is an incredibly cool toy. I bought the exact same one at toys r us for $60 yesterday. They had a bunch of them. Highly recommend this product....really seems like Wally!!!!

This router is blazing fast and easy to set up. Have always been a fan of Asus. Had both a Cisco and Linksys router crap out on me, and for some reason I could never get max download speed. When the Linksys started randomly losing wifi and causing latency spikes, I ordered the Asus. Took just a minute to set up, and instead of the crappy 7 or 8 Mbps I was now getting 29-40....on all my devices...laptop, iPhone, iPad, desktop, and my latency for gaming dropped from the 200's to the 70's. Once it was up I then input the settings for my video security system and it worked perfectly. Highly recommend this router. I like that it has a power button. The range is exceptional.

This awesome cover fit right away on my ancient porcelain-china throne with no adjustments needed. I love the shelf. The best part is that it is light and is easy to lift if I ever have to fish around or drop in one of those blue things. Highly recommend this without reservation. I give Home Depot zero stars because they do not even carry replacement lids...they told me to go to a junkyard....

Our church bought one of these for our hall to use with our projector, laptops, and Bluray players. Range was amazing...we mounted this about 8 feet up onto the pole that our projector is suspended on (with some plastic ties) from a crossbeam, and once my laptop connected, i walked all around the hall as far as around 40 feet away, and the signal remained connected and the video ran smoothly. When connecting to a projector, the projector becomes the audio "control" and you have to run an audio cable from the projector to your sound system. Ours had a standard 3.5 mm output, and a 100ft cable on Amazon was about ten bucks, and the sound was perfect. I also realized that you had to turn up the projector volume to a decent level first, then you can use your house system to shape the sound. I will post an addendum later to comment on whether it is still running well. So far so good.Addendum 3/24/13: system works fantastic, including with bluray player. Because we mounted it high, we also picked up a remote control power outlet on Amazon so it was not on all the time.update 6/22/15 - this device is still going very strong...works great with bluray players that have usb port.

Absolutely perfect!! Came with all necessary cables. I am shocked at how great this sounds with an acoustic guitar in my Church. I'd say i posed the ultimate challenge acoustically: a Taylor 12 string with the Expression system, played through a Fishman Loudbox 100w acoustic amp. The quality was stunning. No pops, no dropouts, no line noise, just crystal clear acoustic goodness. Bass response is excellent, and I could not tell the difference between this and when I am cabled. I also tried it in the hall and did not lose the signal, but at around 100 feet away I could start to detect a slight delay. No prob for me since I will have no reason to be that far away.-has its own volume control dial on the back..very cool as I have seen come criticism of lower end wireless rigs that reviewers said lowered the volume.-no need to even clip this anywhere..I just put it in my pocket and let the antenna hang out; it does have a belt clip though.-has a 'standby" setting on the device which I believe makes sure the signal stays connected for instant play.I highly recommend this system. I am a professional who has played live acoustic guitar in churches for 35 years. This will be great for our special services with children than require me to maybe move around without dragging a cable.

Absolutely perfect! Fits on either a microphone stand or a music stand. Holds my bottle of water, capo, picks, no wobbling, and very strong steel. Not flimsy at all. My preference is on the mic stand as I use a boom mic and this puts the shelf off to my left. Its nice not having to reach down to the floor for my bottle, and not cluttering my music stand with pics and such.

This sharpener is perfect and so far has withstood frequent use. It sharpens better than the sideways sharpener in the next room, which also cost three times as much. I suspect its because of the vertical position. Highly recommend. Have about 20+ students in an alternative suspension setting.

I always wanted a deep fryer but was scared of fires and afraid I would screw something up. I also saw alot of them with negative reviews, except this one. Got it last week and have used it a bunch of times. Amazingly easy, no smoke, so mess, and the food is not greasy!! I have made Korean chicken, called tangsuyuk using potato starch batter, catfish, and this thing is just easy to work with. Highly recommend.

I developed bursitis after stupidly switching to a cheap pair of walmart running shoes. Then, I tried an expensive Aetrex insole with some cheap walmart shoes and that did not help at all, finally after four months of heel and sole pain, I did what my podiatrist had said years ago and spent money on a good pair of shoes. Literally since putting these on I have had zero pain, because the arch support and sole are so well made. The sole is twice as thick as a walmart sneaker. I have been standing at Church, school, and walking around for days now with no pain. This is the best money I have ever spent on a shoe.

Got this to put on a stand in front of my treadmill. Nice plus is that it has two HDMI inputs, so I can attach my cable box and my Bluray player. Also works great as a computer monitor. Highly recommend. Got mine at HHGregg.One nice feature is a surround sound audio setting that works well.

I purchased the "HDD not included" version of this and installed my own drive. If you are nervouse about installing a drive, best to get one with it already installed.I was leary about the price, but my IP camera server died and I needed a low cost replacement. I ordered a 500gb sata drive from Amazon for $47 to go with this. I have four Swann Cameras connected to it. I'd say the price of the "HDD included" one here is fair, given the HDD is installed for you and is considered part of the unit and covered if it is DOA or fails.Bottom line is it works and was very easy to set up in terms of the hardware. As far as connecting to my android/setting up remote viewing, I had to resort to a youtube video...it has vonnic 1000 in the title and is easy to find. It walks you through setting up your router. This DVR uses a seperate "Media" port setting. The best apps I found for this DVR are IPcam (pro) and Meyecam. They work great.The Manual for this product is the typical Chinglish and largely useless, but fortunately it comes with a mouse and the interface is well designed and easy to navigate.Hardware setup: Easy. Installed hard drive with a few screws, attached cables (included with DVR), attached cameras, booted it up and it worked. Seems like it automatically did a quick (five seconds)drive format, and started recording. It really has alot of features and settings for such an inexpensive machine. I am not using PTZ (panTiltZoom)cameras so cannot speak to that feature.I was concerned about heat given the small size of the case and lack of fans, but after running with the case open for about 7 hours both the drive and the motherboard heatsink were just warm, not hot. Obviously you do not want to put this or any other component (stero, cable box, etc) on a tight space anyway. Since the case is all metal I'd say it probably dissipates heat nicely.On first turning it on it has an annoying alarm/beep system that goes off if you have a disconnected camera. I shut that feature off immediately.If you get it, here is the idiot's guide to getting started, free of Chinglish:1. remove cover and attach hard drive by screwing from the bottom. The four holes align with the bottom of the HDD.2. attach your cameras3. make sure the dvr is where you intend to keep it as the alarms go of when you wiggle the camera cables4. turn it on/plug it in, look at nice color bars for a minute, then right click on screen/camera images anywhere. This gives you the menu, which has a few layers but is easy to use.5. from here you can format the drive, though I think its automatic. Play around with the settings.6. make sure to set the video resolution to its highest (D1) as it defaults to a low res.7. find the "vonnic 1000" video on youtube and configure your router for remote viewing8. configure your tablet/phone app9. Enjoy watching your cats party it up while you work!! I have five.

The four holes align with the bottom of the HDD.2. attach your cameras3. make sure the dvr is where you intend to keep it as the alarms go of when you wiggle the camera cables4. turn it on/plug it in, look at nice color bars for a minute, then right click on screen/camera images anywhere. This gives you the menu, which has a few layers but is easy to use.5. from here you can format the drive, though I think its automatic. Play around with the settings.6. make sure to set the video resolution to its highest (D1) as it defaults to a low res.7. find the "vonnic 1000" video on youtube and configure your router for remote viewing8. configure your tablet/phone app9. Enjoy watching your cats party it up while you work!! I have five.I will post a follow up in a few weeks.5/5/14 addendum: system is still working great, no issues at all.

I have used the Anger Management for Youth (available on Amazon) CBT book since the 1990's, and was looking for something that would cover a broader spectrum of behaviors for an alternative suspension program. This fits the bill. It especially emphasizes the four thinking errors (blaming, awfulizing, minimizing, self-centered), and provides some nice scenarios that you can use as worksheets or as a group activity/lesson.If you are looking to actually impart a skill and have a great opportunity to interact with at-risk youth, then this is the way to go.The original EQUIP system is based it seems on having the time to develop a Positive Peer Culture, while this book as I said is more suited to working with individuals or targeted groups within a school.I do recommend purchasing Anger Management for Youth: Stemming Violence and Aggression. It has some nice summary and template sheets that can be made into a useful packet.

Okay, yes, five cats is a lot and they sort of snuck up on me. I was faced with using two "tip and sift" boxes and my litter robot, but this was NOT working. Had to clean three boxes and litter was everywhere.So, I decided to get a 36 gallon tote from walmart and make one large litterbox; thought of making some kind of giant rake to clean it, but saw this scoop at the pet store and liked the feel. It works perfectly. I can get deep in the litter with no bending over, and it only takes a minute or two to clean the box..no litter in my face, no sifting, no tipping, and no litter scattered around. Best of all no smell at all.In short, this device was the perfect addition to my multi-cat, homemade litterbox scenario. It stays extended and does not slip, the scoop is very sturdy and does not bend, and its easy to get it under the larger patches of solidified urine. Now I just use the little shopping bags I have laying around to put the clumps in and toss them out.I highly recommend this product, and I highly recommend making your own litterbox out of a plastic tote. Cats have room, you can cover it and it still has lots of room for the cat to stand, and you can easily take it outside and hose it out if necessary. I loved my LitterRobot, but two of my cats would not use it. They all use the home-made one.addendum: 7/17/14: six cats now, and I switched to the Biddy Box. This scoop is still going strong.

I bought this to go along with a Yamaha Piagerro, for use at home, but was surprised to find it worked extremely well in my medium sized church and church hall (about 300 seats). In fact we had to tun the volume down for our talent show. Very exceptional sound reproduction. I would recommend this highly for home and small to medium venues. The 2 channels are nice as you can add a vocal mic as well.

Recently rescued/fostered a stray cat, which shall we say caused some problems with marking and or missing the litterbox. My entire house has tile floors (florida), and a regular mop was not cutting it. Tried this out and it was amazing right away. Nice fresh clean smell after use, and it is easy to move and use. Also easy to clean out and maintain. It does indeed suck up the dirty water very nicely. Highly recommend this for people who have pets.

I rescued a stray male black cat, but already have 4 young cats, 3 males 1 female (big house, 3 litterboxes, not a cat hoarder). Plan to put him up for adoption. After he healed up and I gradually let him in the main house, all but my alpha-black male cat were ok with him. The alpha refused to even come into my bedroom anymore or to his cat tree once the new male was there...alpha cat would growl and warble even within 10 feet of new cat. This stuff had arrived a few days earlier so I decided to plug it in my room near the tree, and there was a response within several hours. Alpha cat not only entered the room, but he stopped making noises and fixating on the new cat, and even began playing in the room. He got within a few feet of new cat and just looked at him, no posturing or noise. This transferred to when they were out of the room together as well. They don't exactly love each other, but I am very pleased with this quick change in behavior...no way it was a fluke or accident. Curious to see how it develops. new guy is being neutered this week, and at that point I will remove the feliway and see what happens.addendum 2/13/13: well, all is well. Took the feliway away after newcat was fixed, and there have not been any major issues. I'd say it really did help with the initial acclimation.

0:29 MinsBased  on having 5 cats, only my siamese likes it as you see in my video. none of the other cats like it.however, they do play with the hanging balls and use it as a scratching post, so that is good.I would highly recommend this for a kitten or very small cat, but not for a multi-cat house or for large cats.One of the screws would not go on on the bedrail because there was a piece of metal stuck in it.it is worth it if it makes at least one cat happy. my siamese weighs around 9 pounds and is pretty slim. my 12 pound tabby cannot fit in the tube or on the bed.

I had been using a sub-$100 android tablet and really did like it, but stepped on it. The samsung has a crisper display and is faster than the 'cheap" androids, but what really shocked me is the wifi range. I can now be in my back room 50 feet away, through 5 walls and a closed door and the signal still shows more than half the bars. The cheaper tablet I had would disconnect once I got about 20 feet from the router.Other than that, I was disappointed to find no HDMI out or mini usb. Have to pay $40 for an HDMI adapter.

Picked one of these up just to try a larger screen than my 7 inch android tab. I am very pleased with this tablet. Plenty of room for apps, speed seems great compared to my little tablet and my android phone. It feels good in my hand/hands even when using it as an e-reader at night. Wifi range is fine..have had no issues connecting, and the on board lan jack is very convenient since a hard-wired lan is much faster than wifi. (I happen to keep an extra cable in my living room).The only reason I was going to ding a star is I did feel the battery life (about three hours in full use) was not the greatest, but then again it is one fourth the price of an IPAD... I have had two opportunities to use this side by side with an IPAD and frankly the differences were negligible in terms of surfing speed, loading apps, etc. Obviously an IPAD screen has higher resolution and a slightly better touch response, but the Irulu is still easy to read, very bright and videos look great. I enjoy typing on the 10 inch much more than the 7.I did order a case on EBAY that is kind of a flat leather folio case, as it did not come with one, and I like the folio cases better than the zipper cases, especially when using the tablet as an ebook at night.One issue that came up was the wifi sometimes would not come back on after sleeping. A free app called "wifi-lock" corrected this immediately so that was resolved. It also contributes to saving battery life. I also found, via experimentation, that a cheap USB wifi device works well in this tablet, and has a larger range than the on board. Did not have to run an app or install any software...ICS 4 just defaulted to the usb wifi...very cool!  However, I don't use the usb device since the on board has been just fine. Nice to have as a backup, though.Overall, I highly recommend this tablet; it had no hardware issues at all, runs great, and its nice having the lan jack feature and two usb ports. Lastly the stereo speakers are pretty nice.Now, one of the ports does not respond to USB 2 cables but does read thumb drives, but I am told that this is because it is an exclusive USB 3 port that will allow me to charge via USB. Once I check that out I will post back.I should also mention that I dropped this tablet on a hard tile floor from about 5 feet, such that the binding of the front screen popped out, yet the tablet still worked perfectly and the binding just popped back into place. So I would say this is also a very sturdy device.addendum 11/19/12: Still working great, but I discovered some nice apps that let you send files wirelessly from your pc to the tablet..pretty amazing..your tablet's folders will appear on your pc desk top and you can just drag files into them. Just activate the app and set your tablet down anywhere, and you can move files, no cables at all. Only about 2 bucks for the pro versions that have no size limits.Addendum: some people have asked about a case. This is a 10.2 inch tablet, so just search Ebay for "android 10.2 tablet case" and you will find them. They run about 10 bucks with free shipping.Addendum 2/6/13: Tablet still working fine, no issues.Adedendum 8/30/13: still working, no issues.

Been playing for 35 years, have owned about 8 Taylors. Got this to use in a small-medium church (350 seats). Stunning would be an understatement. Sounds rich and full unplugged or plugged. I had been soured before with the ES system on my jumbo Taylor 315 six string, and even replaced that with a fishman soundhole system. However, the ES system with this guitar is just mind-blowing, played through a Fishman Loudbox 100 or the native church sound system, or combined ( loudbox has a clean mic out to a soundboard). I have NEVER been happy with any 12 string plugged in until this. The ES system really works to mitigate the grating high end you often get with 12 strings. Unlike with my six string, the sound is very natural. Received several compliments.Unplugged the guitar has great action and just a sweet, balanced tone. The body style is very conducive to just sitting around and fingerpicking. I compared this directly with a similarly priced Martin, and both the feel and sound of the Taylor passed the martin, which also had plywood sides (for $1600 !!!).I have finally found the perfect guitar.Addendum 12/6/12: I am now using this guitar exclusively for church, as the ease of fingerpicking and the balanced tone when fingerpicking are just amazing. As I said before the body size contributes to that as well.
I have no idea how, but it just took over from the lesser-range built in wifi. Much faster and does not lose connection. Did not even use any app or drivers to make it work.

I buy these for my Siamese cat. For some reason, he will spend alot of time tossing it up in the air, throwing it around the room, stalking it, pouncing on it, chewing it, and carrying it around. It's his favorite toy and usually lasts about a month. Funniest thing I have ever seen. My three other cats just stare at him and wonder what he is doing.

Got this to compliment the sharp Furubushidoo Musashi Katana I have (from handmadesword.com), so as not to have four tail-less cats running around my house due to my practicing. The only difference between the two was that this practice sword had a more comfortable grip than my more expensive counterpart, and the grip was about an inch and a half shorter. The weight really feels identical. The blade is definitely dull and rounded all over, but the point was still, well, "pointy." About a minute with my Dremel and I had a nice, rounded, unpointy point.It looks VERY nice, very shiny, nice blood groove in it. Came with a nice coating of oil on the blade.NO loose parts, blade is very tight as is the tsuba.I highly recommend this as a practice sword.

It's starting to be fall weather here. When I need to be out at night, these are ideal, warm, cut the wind, breath a little.The size is as expected. I bought a size up so I can put extra thermals underneath as needed. Works fine for now with a belt.The lower pockets have dual velcro seals for secure closure. I keep a small camera in one and barely notice it.The seams are tight and well sown, not a lot of loose threads. These pants feel made to last.

The paper is high quality, soft and strong for TP. The claim of "washcloth-like texture" doesn't fit very well; it's a regular soft TP texture.These rolls are a bit over 5" in diameter, so they won't fit in a lot of dispensers.TP math: This package isn't quite equivalent to 24 regular rolls, only 22.5. The Charmin regular rolls are really small, 82 sheets; these are 308 sheets each, so 3.75 times as big. Each square is just under 4" wide, just over 4" long.

This has a clever plot, and if it were presented in a different way I might have enjoyed it. But the cleverness isn't enough to support the earnestly portrayed, disturbing emotional content relating to the death of children. The acting and direction are a little heavy-handed, maybe suitable enough for the genre.

For all its virtues, well described in other reviews here, there is an underreported aspect of this movie that ought to give pause, its implicit defense of the edges of pederasty. Hector, the teacher who is treated with the most sympathy in the film, is a pederast, one who gropes the genitals of his high-school-senior-age students for his gratification. He's presented as an innocent, a child himself, and has been explicitly defended as such by the film's author, Alan Bennett. In this way, and by making at least one of the boys he abuses uncannily adult in personality, among other devices, the film does a nice job of complexifying and muddying lines contemporary culture has tried to make simple and clear and (literally enough) puts a smiley face on the pederasty. That this is put in the context of homosexuality/bisexuality may account for the apparent reluctance of critics to address it.I won't try to sort all that out here. I just think viewers should be aware of this element of the movie, and those who have already seen it and haven't reflected on that element of it probably should. Those who would like some more context might start with Johann Hari's article "Alan Bennett and the question of innocence," easily found via Google (Amazon removes links from reviews).

This movie tries to be good, and in the end it may succeed, but on the way it crosses lines in ways that have offended some and struck others as unrealistic. Whether the reasons for crossing those lines are ultimately good enough, I don't know. The filmmaker regards this as a fable, and things happen in fables that we wouldn't accept as real, especially symbolic ones (like being bound with a chain). One thing that makes that confusing here is the otherwise realistic style, and realistic, serious themes.That aside, despite initial appearances, the movie becomes a sweet, soft-hearted tale of the triumph of love in the end, and is fairly effective at that.

Don't expect the tongue to come out of the cheek. The basic plot and moral of the play is preserved, and played earnestly enough at points to matter, but this is for kicks, not serious tragedy. The best laughs I've had for a long time, and some great very-70s music to go with. (But no Supertramp.) Tierney and Walken are perfect, the balance of deadpan and wink to the audience is perfect. And the other actors are perfect too, but some are more perfect than others.

This is a well-made film in terms of production and acting, and the plot makes sense, even if it's a little strained. It mixes some raw and somewhat graphic emotional material with the conventional requirements and trappings of a Hollywood movie, a combination that doesn't work well for me. That doesn't seem to bother most people, though, so if it doesn't bother you, you may enjoy this as an effectively done thriller.

This is a lot more fun than I expected. Coogan makes a surprisingly likable, dry smart-aleck lead in this not-silly but somewhat tongue-in-cheek, lighter Mamet-like plot of people of questionable morality. His character has elements of film noir Bogart, with less hardness and edge, and a British accent, not entirely like any other I've seen. Romijn is also appealing, obviously, and holds up the strong female character well. Selma Blair adds spice; the supporting men are colorful. You have to pay close attention, especially for the last half hour, if you want to follow the plot completely, but it all makes sense.Four stars, plus one because . . . it's underrated.

This knife is extremely sharp, so those used to ordinary knives may not like it at first. For most purposes it's sharper than it needs to be, but there are a few things it can do that other knives can't, some very fine layering for example, and cutting easily through some bones. It's a little small for heavy jobs, though.This knife should remain sharp for a very long time if properly used (on a wood or other soft cutting board). If there's ever a need to sharpen it, a sharpener designed specifically for ceramic or other extra hard blades will be needed. They cost about as much as the knife, though, and require some work to use.This is such a beautiful tool that it will add to your kitchen even when you aren't using it.

I prefer to use a mix of potting soil including some designed to conserve water, it reduces losses from forgetfulness. This soil, mixed with other potting soils, has worked well for me with both tomato starts (now planted outside) and indoor plants. The soil didn't dry out quickly, and the plants thrived.I did find the occasional pebble in it, not a big deal.

The idea of planning a day by just flipping through this guide to pick a morning, afternoon, and evening destination is nice, but in practice you'll get usable results more easily with a more conventional guide.People with a particular sense of adventure might enjoy randomly opening to a day plan.

I was in Paris a few weeks ago. This guide is helpfully divided up into eight main sections according to the part of the city, useful for consulting on the ground. Each geographical section is dominated by brief descriptions of sights and sources of food and entertainment, including shopping. Lots of alluring photos. Info is concise.It also has brief sections on practical matters like money, transportation, general advice on food, etc.It's too big for a pocket, but it will fit easily in a bag.There's a removable map at the back, detailed enough to use for walking or driving, showing metro and train stops with a smaller map showing the lines. I would have liked some more information on a map and in the little text section on the metro, a video tutorial might be more helpful to get oriented to the metro if you're not accustomed to how it works. It's the best way to get most places you can't easily walk to.The guide mentions the hop-on hop-off busses that run along several routes through the city. These are very popular, hit most of the places most people want to go. Sit on the top level for the best view if weather permits.The guide fits the hectic tourist approach of getting to as many places as possible, but it can be used for less pressed visits. You can easily spend a week at a single site like the Louvre. This guide can help you find what's around you at whatever speed you wish to go.

Doesn't slip, feels soft, washes fine, dries quickly. I'm not sure what to make of the color I got, Cobble Stone Grey. I can't decide if it hides dirt or looks dirty even when it's clean. Some of each, I think.

This has good power for ordinary needs, works well for smoothies and purees for soups, no hesitations. I haven't done much with the attachments, but the whisk makes quick work of cake mix. I like the continuous speed control.Easy to wash by hand, though the attachments can be machine washed too.The jar that comes with this is plastic. If you use it much, it's worth considering a stainless steel commercial-style container like this one. They're cheap, last forever, and you don't need to worry about beating them up.

I caught four mice in one evening with this trap. I don't even have to rebait the trap after it's been baited once. After one mouse has been caught in it, I rinse the trap out, reset it, and soon another mouse gets caught. I think they're drawn in by the scent of the previous occupant.The mice do gnaw at it inside, but apparently the mice here aren't ferocious enough to damage the trap that way, at least not so far. I try not to leave the mice in it very long, though, so that might help. It's evident that the mice are pretty miserable while inside the trap, so I keep the trap where I can hear it when a mouse is inside.

This isn't a series of biographical sketches. After an introduction, each chapter is built around one of the seven liberals referred to in the book's subtitle, but in each we encounter numerous people, ideas and events, forming a web of connections within and between chapters, showing the development of a community of American liberal thought from the eighteenth century to the mid-1930s.The seven liberals that function as vantage points for the movement are John Adams, Mary Moody Emerson, William Ellery Channing, William James, Thomas Davidson, William Mackintire Salter, and Jane Addams. A revolutionary, founder and President of the country; a maiden aunt and early example to Ralph Waldo Emerson; a leading Unitarian preacher and theologian; a key American philosopher who treated his depression with a will to believe; a Scottish-American intellectual and pluralist idealist; a post-Christian preacher of Ethics; and a local and international social activist and founder of Hull House."Liberal" here doesn't mean what it typically means in contemporary politics, though there is a connection. The author explains that the first people to call themselves liberals (in the eighteenth century) did so in reference to some religiously mediated beliefs formed in reaction against Calvinism. They held no human could have full knowledge, which was taken to imply a duty of humility, open-mindedness and pluralism. They also insisted that humans have moral agency, i.e. free will, largely on the practical ground that the denial of it encourages bad behavior. Together these beliefs established the need for liberty of conscience and a ground for belief in equality. These spiritual but practical points are the basic foundation of the liberal "Religion of Democracy" in America, democratic beliefs that were central to revolutionary politics and beyond.The author sees this original culture of liberalism as having taken a turn to ideological dogmatism, and thus away from its original foundation, when it tied itself to the principles of the New Deal. But she does see contemporary liberalism as having grown out of the older liberalism.The author is herself a contemporary liberal in some respects, as well as an aspirant to the ideals of the original liberalism. She isn't overbearing, but an occasional remark or sermonette shows a current liberal sensibility relating to, say, the unfair treatment of women or the need to admit that the Civil War was about slavery. The book is also shaped by a contemporary liberal sensibility in making the effort to include women and minorities as active agents in the conversation. The author ends the book with a brief plea for the pluralism of the older liberalism, eschewing dogmatism and prideful contempt.A point that motivates the book appears in the first sentence: "Somehow the word 'godless' got attached to the word 'liberal.'" The author is at pains to show there's no valid connection. She doesn't entirely rise to the challenge. She effectively shows that liberal heritage is rooted in religion, that a vital culture of liberal religion can and did exist (it continues today), and some of the figures in the book provide arguments and felt reasons that would tie liberalism to religion. Those are good lessons for both conservative religious critics of liberalism and liberal critics of religion.But readers may split over what the book achieves in that regard. The religion of some of the liberals in the book, consisting of little more than a commitment to the pursuit of good, and faith that something really is ultimately good, will be regarded by some as extremely attenuated, while others will see it as getting at the pure essence of true religion. The author does little to mediate that split. Despite acknowledging that there's "more than grain of truth" in conservative criticism of liberal religion (page 12), she mainly dismisses it as based on a myth of what constitutes religion. The author only rarely shows a flash of insight into the virtues and deep humanity of conservative religion, which seems to me a lacuna in her open-mindedness and pluralism.And of course many liberals have felt their liberal values led them away from religion and God entirely. For the author this view may be precluded by a belief that the pursuit of truth and virtue requires a belief in the divine (or ultimate, as she sometimes calls it), a belief taken for granted by early liberals, and argued for in some form by William James. But she doesn't ever state that belief as her own, and it would be vigorously disputed by many, possibly most contemporary liberals.Not all of the seven figures are equally developed, but all are brought to life to some degree. I don't know enough about the history to evaluate how accurate and fair the book is. It's fully annotated with endnotes. I know enough about William James to notice that the author sometimes makes him seem more of a believer than he probably was, but that's a matter of subtle shading. I don't see her getting anything I know about James definitely wrong, and I learned things that put him in a better light.Mainly the book's style is lively, the terrain often rich in detail. Some readers have complained it's difficult to read, so I've provided a brief sample in the first comment to this review. And some readers have complained about the seemingly random flow of the book, so be prepared for a less than entirely linear development. The author cares about the issues and the people she focuses on. I found the book interesting and engaging throughout.

Since it isn't raining here, I tested the waterproofing by putting the top of the cover into a large sink, running water over it, and letting the water drain off. That left a little pocket of water in a fold of the fabric, which might also happen when in use. I checked back in a couple hours, and water had seeped through at the seam that ran under the water pocket. Not necessarily a big deal. If you use this over the kind of grill it's designed for, you can probably avoid any pockets of water collecting, though I suppose prolonged rain or high wind with rain might also cause a little leaking at seams.Other than at the seam, the fabric didn't allow water in. The double-sewn seams are moderately tight and feel like they'll hold up to ordinary use with no trouble. The fabric itself appears moderately durable. The four-year warranty is only for manufacturing defects, not for wear from ordinary use.The cover had a plastic smell that I didn't want clinging to my grill, so I let the cover air out, inside-out, for a week, and it helped. It hasn't gone away completely yet, but I don't think it will be an issue. It's most noticeable when the sun warms it up.There's an elastic draw string around the lower edge that makes it easy to slip the cover over the grill without undoing the string.

Don't know why Amazon lists this as from 2002, but it's from 2008. This is the rental version of the DVD, identical to the regular retail version except for the bar code as far as I can tell.This is a David Mamet film about a jiu-jitsu master who finds his principles tested by extreme circumstance. The title refers to the honorary red belt belonging to his mentor. A few tips for enjoying this:1. It's not really a martial-arts or action movie. Mamet says, "It's a story of the journey of a man who wants to be pure and gets tempted." Though limited, what fighting is in it is well done.Mamet is a student of jiu-jitsu himself and calls this "my love letter to the world and philosophy of jiu-jitsu." He had the help of numerous world-class fighters, including five-time UFC champion Randy Couture, who has a role on screen (and accompanies Mamet on the DVD commentary track), world jiu-jitsu champion John Machado, who is the opponent in the climactic fight, and renowned jiu-jitsu teacher Renato Magno, who choreographed most of the fights. (It's fiction--depictions of shady activities aren't an attack on real MMA fighting, they're obstacles on the journey of the hero.)Mamet also sees this as a film noir, and there are elements of that to appreciate about it.2. Sometimes a coincidence is just a coincidence. That it's Mamet makes us look for a grand conspiracy at work from the start. Don't try to make the conspiracy bigger, earlier or more planned out than it needs to be. The grander you make it, the less plausible it is. Properly trimmed, it's plausible enough.3. Even if you have trouble following all the plot details--typically a risk with Mamet, though not unduly so here--the main character, played by Chiwetel Ejiofor, is worth knowing. In this role he reminds me of Laurence Fishburne in The Matrix, but not as ponderous. (There is a little philosophy in this movie, but the principles, like the hero, are simple and down to earth.)4. Mamet sees the main character as being tested and, at a crucial point, giving up. One might easily see his action as just sticking to his principles, but if you understand it as giving up, the film makes more sense, including the slap (you'll see).Also keep in mind the principle of not being distracted. The main character meets with some powerful potential distractions near the end.5. The ending is a bit incredible in a couple ways, but if you keep in mind that Samurai films are among the models Mamet's working with, it fits the genre.

This is Interview (no "the"), not that silly movie about killing a Korean dictator.This one's better than I expected, but I still felt used at the end. It struck me as ultimately more misanthropic than it needed to be to make the same dramatic trickery effective. Others won't mind that, though, and will enjoy the twists just the same, and maybe even the extra bite.

Bostrom: "This is quite possibly the most important and most daunting challenge humanity has ever faced. And--whether we succeed or fail--it is probably the last challenge we will ever face."The challenge Bostrom refers to is properly controlling the creation of superintelligence, which he believes will bring awesome superpowers and corresponding risks not only to human life but the entire portion of the universe that it's physically possible to reach (humanity's "cosmic endowment"). He gives compelling reasons to think it may be a lot harder to control than we might at first suspect. He doesn't get far in outlining solutions to the problems he raises. He's clearing space for and inviting further work.Prof. Bostrom is well suited to address this. He's widely respected as a scholar and has long been reflecting on issues of cosmic import related to foreseeable trends, particularly ones for which what humans do may have a crucial effect on the result. He's familiar with the relevant technical and philosophical points. He seems to read and write around the clock, having already published over 200 articles and a few books at the age of 41. Among the issues he's worked on over the years is whether we live in a simulation, like a cosmic computer game. May be more likely than you think! Check out his website (nickbostrom dot com) to learn more about him and the concerns in this book.The target audience, according to Bostrom, is an earlier version of himself, which would presumably be a very bright person interested in but not yet familiar with the material. But he has made it accessible to people not quite as smart as a future Oxford prof, and without a background in the technical or philosophical issues, though some familiarity with those helps. Several customers have complained it's hard to read. I'd say it's written at a college level.The urgency Bostrom feels in this book is mainly revealed at the beginning, where the above quote appears, and the end, where he likens humanity to children playing with a bomb, with no grown-up in sight. Those parts of the book have some of the qualities of a manifesto and call to arms, but the bulk of it is a lucid, measured outline of the wealth of issues involved.Though some of this book reads like science fiction, the tone is generally moderate and careful, leavened with a little mostly dry humor (e.g. the endnote explaining that not all endnotes contain useful information, or the note comparing tenured academics to a sea squirt larva that digests part of its own brain once it's served its purpose). Much of it is written in a way characteristic of how many philosophers teach philosophy, giving opposing points sometimes to the point of dizziness, but he does show his own views.The title I've given my review might give the wrong impression in one respect. Bostrom does present the likely superintelligence to come as having godlike powers and effects, and some of the ideas he covers (and some he develops more elsewhere) might make the basis for an interesting if highly speculative natural theology. But he doesn't mention God, and he mostly steers well clear of religion.He also stays away from partisan politics, but some of the ideas he advocates, or their implications, might stir up quite a hornets' nest in some political/ideological quarters, if those so inclined could be brought to take them seriously.I'm inclined to take Bostrom's ideas seriously. I may be a couple shades more pessimistic than he is, and he's far from Pollyanna. The additional pessimism is based on points he doesn't focus on in the book, probably with good reason, doubts about the limits of rationality in an existential test that appears to pit basic human motives against each other, and possible negative effects of increased rationality and knowledge on motives, something superintelligence might aggravate.In his own words from the end of the book, "In this situation, any feeling of gee-wiz exhilaration would be out of place. Consternation and fear would be closer to the mark, but the most appropriate attitude may be a bitter determination to be as competent as we can, much as if we were preparing for a difficult exam that will either realize our dreams or obliterate them." The reward for success would be "a compassionate and jubilant use of humanity's cosmic endowment." A noble goal.

Despite the closing scene, any parallels to Casablanca are loose, but if you imagine that film with grimmer ties to the darkest elements of WWII and its aftermath, with Ilsa having descended to prostitution and terrible crimes while still maintaining commitment to a small and equally morally compromised Laszlo, with far less comedy and redemption, you'll have the flavor of this film.Clooney is the Bogart in this, and while I'm a big fan, and he's not bad at all here, he doesn't have the same noir gravitas as Bogart, which the material seems to call for.It's tricky to try to combine the entertainment conventions of a love story and mystery with such morally dark material. I don't think it entirely works here, with each undermining the other. The moral complexity of the character played by Blanchett is interesting and compelling to a degree, but the gravity of how its presented is somewhat at odds with the necessarily manipulative fantasy Hollywood elements.

I put off setting this system up because in reading the manuals and the reviews it was apparent that there are a lot of details to consider in getting the most out of it, many of which require some knowledge of the technical workings. It's a flexible system with lots of options. For now I just want top use it for backup, but it can do much more.I finally went with the simplest option to start with, the basic setup with default settings and, for my Mac, a Time Machine backup. Even that had a few wrinkles, such as deciding how much space to allocate for Time Machine. (For those who use Time Machine, ReadyNAS helpfully automatically sets up a portion of the drives of the size the user specifies. By default Time Machine would use all the space available on the drives.)The setup and Time Machine backup went smoothly, no glitches. I needed to consult the ReadyNAS software manual (available online), and in some cases had to hunt a bit for the right button to click next.The fan that operates whenever the unit is on has a soft but quite noticeable sound.The two 1-TB drives that came with this system are Toshiba DT01ACA100 7200 RPM drives (from November and December 2013). User reviews at Amazon and NewEgg suggest these aren't the ultimate in reliability, though they generally perform well. They make the redundancy of the default X-RAID configuration desirable. (In that configuration, the total data that can be stored on the two 1-TB drives is only 1 TB because of the redundant storage. If one drive fails, all the data can be recovered from the other.)The Toshiba drives are supposed to be energy efficient, which is good, because the ReadyNAS keeps them spinning continually when the unit is on. You can schedule times for the unit to power up and down, and you can remotely shut it down fairly easily. Remotely powering it up is a little trickier, but can be done via Wake on LAN. NetGear says they're working on a disk spindown option for their next software update (6.2.0).Screws are included to mount 2.5" drives.The power cord is helpfully long, a little over 11 feet, in two pieces with a power brick in the middle.The construction is solid.

put on your tie-dye clothes and set the mood with the color of your choice or--my favorite--cycle gradually through all the colors on a continuous rainbow loop--what does it mean?supplement the mood with your choice of 15 sounds, natural or manmadejust turn the clock around for those moments when you want time to disappeareasy to adjust brightness of light and clock displaynot as hard to set up as some say, but you may need to look at the full manual, available onlineworks fine, no glitchesthe mood light can be turned offcord 4 and 1/2 feet long, tether to the real world

To answer a frequent question, this card will work in your camera or other device if it accepts SDHC cards (not the same as microSDHC). Just google the model name of your device with "sdhc" to check. Make sure you get a size your device can use.This is a review of the 32-GB card. Speeds are often different for different sizes of the same card. There are numerous speeds that matter for an SD card. I'll cover how various speeds of this card stack up for use in cameras and other devices too.Digital cameras: photosFor digital cameras, still or video, the card speed that matters most for shooting is the *sequential write* speed, which is how fast your images can be transferred from the camera to the card. It's usually *not* the first figure cards give for speed, and Samsung doesn't give any specific figure for it for this card.This card actually tests at from 15 to over 35 MB/s (megabytes per second) for sequential writes. (See below on where I get these numbers.)That's a lot faster than the 10 MB/s this card's Class 10 and UHS Class 1 speed ratings require, which may be what Samsung means when they say it writes "twice as fast as conventional SD cards." It isn't fast enough to write "up to 360 photos (8 MB) per minute," as Samsung also claims, though. (That would require a 48 MB/s *write* speed, which Samsung doesn't claim for this card.)Your camera manual, or online camera info, should say what speed you need, probably in terms of a speed class (see more on speed classes below). In theory you can figure out how fast your card needs to be for maximum shooting speed by multiplying how many shots per second your camera can take by the file size (in MB, not MP) of the photos. For example, if your camera can shoot 2.5 8-MB photos per second, you need a card that will write 2.5 x 8 = 20 MB/s to keep up. In practice, the speed that cards write in tests and the speeds they write for a given camera can be very different, so this can only be a rough guide. (In my own camera, a Nikon V1, doubling the tested write speed of the card doesn't even come close to doubling how fast the camera can shoot after the buffer fills.)There are other cards at similar prices that write up to twice as fast as this one, but there's usually some trade-off. For example the Transcend 32 GB High Speed Card is currently the same price and about twice as fast, but it isn't as rugged (and it lags this one in random-access transfer speeds, important for those who might use the card in something other than a camera--see below).Digital cameras: videoWith a sequential write speed that tests from 15 to over 35 MB/s, this card is plenty fast for anything short of 4K video. It's fine for 1080p HD. (For 4K video you need a consistent 30 MB/s sequential write speed, offered by some Class 10 and all UHS Class 3 cards. Currently, few consumer-level cameras shoot 4K video.)Transferring photos/video to a computerThe speed that matters when you transfer photos or video from this card to your computer is the *sequential read* speed, usually the first (or only) number cards give for speed. This card claims "up to" 48 MB/s. It tests close to that, mostly in the mid-40s, which for the 32-GB size means it will take about 12 minutes to transfer a full card.As with the sequential write speed, there are cards with faster read speeds that will transfer photos to your computer faster, some twice as fast or more for a similar price, but usually with a trade-off.Other devicesFor most devices other than cameras, including tablets, the *random-access* read and write speeds are crucial. Most cards that state speeds are giving sequential figures only, and some of the fastest cards for sequential transfers do poorly for random transfers, so if you compare card speeds for use in a computer or mobile device, be sure to include random speeds in your comparison. Random reads and writes are measured for blocks of data of different sizes; only results from the same-size blocks should be compared to each other.For *random reads* with *512-KB* blocks of data this card is just a little slower than for sequential reads, low 40s MB/s. That's a good speed, though nowhere near the fastest. For *random writes* with *512-KB* blocks this card tests at 23-35 MB/s, a very respectable range, faster than some otherwise very fast cards. For example, the SanDisk Extreme Pro 32GB 95MB/s card, one of the best available for sequential transfers, tests at only 5-9 MB/s for random 512 KB writes.Small-block read and write speeds are more a measure of how fast a card accesses a location in memory, so they're sometimes expressed in terms of input/output operations per second, IOPS. For *random reads* with *4-KB* (small) blocks, this card tests at 4.6-4.7 MB/s, over 1,100 IOPS, which seems slow compared to the other speeds but is actually quite good. For *random writes* with *4-KB* blocks, this card tests between 1 and 1.7 MB/s, 265-410 IOPS, still pretty good for what's usually the slowest spec for a card, about the same as for the SanDisk Extreme Pro.There are better cards for random-access transfers, but like the faster cards for sequential reads, there's usually a trade-off, often price. For example, the all-around excellent SanDisk Extreme Plus 32GB card has faster speeds than this card in every category, including the random 4-KB read and write speeds, which are roughly twice as fast (7.4-10.4 and 2.2-3.7 MB/s), but it's currently 75% more expensive. For comparably-priced cards that also have good sequential speeds, this Samsung card is among the best for random read and write performance.Notes on speed ratings and speed testsThere are two speed class rating systems for sequential writes. The older speed class ratings are symbolized by a C with a number inside, Class 4, Class 6, etc, with the numbers representing the minimum MB/s. Class 10 cards, the fastest under the old speed class ratings, write at a minimum of 10 MB/s. UHS or Ultra High Speed ratings refer primarily to a different speed (bus speed), but for sequential write speeds UHS ratings start where the old speed class ratings leave off: UHS Speed Class 1, symbolized by a U with a 1 in it, writes at 10 MB/s or faster and UHS Class 3 writes at 30 MB/s or faster. (UHS ratings use Roman numerals for bus-speed classes, currently I or II, and Arabic numerals for write-speed classes, currently 1 or 3.)The test results I give here are from various professional and amateur tests, using several programs for sequential speeds, and mainly CrystalDiskMark for random speeds. You can find such test results in professional reviews and posted online by actual users. For Amazon, there are sometimes screen shots of test results posted in the customer image section of the card's product page, located near the top right of the customer review section. (You have to be sure the results are from the same size card, as reviews of different sizes are often given together.)In sumThis is a high-quality, well rounded card that should perform well in most cameras and other devices. Not the fastest, but more than fast enough for most uses, with a good reputation for durability, a good deal for the price.

In most respects this is an ordinary, if fairly heavy-duty, moisturizing skin cream, with water, glycerin, and petrolatum (petroleum jelly, the ingredient in Vaseline) as the first three ingredients by weight, along with other common moisturizing ingredients like mineral oil and dimethicone.It also has an alpha hydroxy acid (AHA), lactic acid (the acid in sour milk) in this case, as the tenth ingredient by weight, which means it's not present in a high concentration. AHAs help remove dead skin cells, which can build up abnormally with certain skin conditions. Dead skin cells form the outermost layer of skin, so removing some of them removes some of the natural protection one has against sunburn. That's why those who use AHAs on skin that may be exposed to sun should also use a sunscreen.There are also other AHAs, in the form of fruit juices, in this lotion, but they're in such low concentrations as to probably have no significant effect (other than to allow them to be advertised on the front label).The lotion leaves a waxy, oily feel after it absorbs into the skin, as most moisturizing lotions do. That pretty much goes away after fifteen minutes.Though fragrance-free, it does have the slight scent of the petrolatum.The retail price of this 13-ounce size is seven bucks, if you can find it. Walmart currently has it in stock at their website for under the retail price.

This incorporates what are deemed the "essentials" of some of Zondervan's most popular Bible study aids. Some of the notes are aimed at beginners, both in level of understanding and in creating interest, and the NIV translation is in modern English, so this is well suited to new Bible readers. There are notes for more advanced readers too. The format is busier than an ordinary Bible, but not excessively so.The orientation of the commentary is broadly Protestant, but aside from not including the deuterocanonical books that the Catholic Bible includes, it's fairly ecumenical. The truth of the Bible is assumed. Controversial topics, e.g. contraception (page 739), the extent of Noah's flood (11), and gender roles (1476), are generally covered from various points of view, though some don't show up at all--the word abortion doesn't appear, for example.The type size for the main text and commentary is comfortable. Some of the textual notes are pretty tiny, but I can read all of them without reading glasses.

On the other hand, according to the experts the value of sports drinks for hydration is no greater than water for most situations, and one of these 20-ounce bottles has as much sugar, in the form of high-fructose corn syrup, as three Krispy Kreme glazed donuts, and 130 calories, about two thirds of a donut's worth, so it's not exactly a health drink or weight loss aid.

Simple. The only controls are an off switch (plugging it in turns it on), a temperature select button with three settings (high, low, warm), and two timer set buttons that scroll up or down by half hours up to 20 hours.Easy. Carefree cooking, scratch-resistant nonstick surface for easy cleaning, removable pot for easy browning if desired. Automatically switches to warm after cooking is done.Works. I've had no trouble with this pot, and the brand (Crock-Pot is owned by Sunbeam) has a decent reputation. Has a standard one-year repair-or-replace guarantee.This is very similar, apart from styling, to the crock pot recommended by America's Test Kitchen in 2013.It's not perfect. If the power goes out while in use, even for a moment, it doesn't come back on when the power does. You can't set it to turn on at a later time. The power cord is only two feet long.Made in China.A good basic, reliable crock pot with a removable pot for browning that does what it's supposed to.

This is a good lotion, but the scent is too strong for me. It's a pleasant floral scent, with some coconut in the mix, there's just more of it than I prefer. And it's persistent, lingers for hours. I see quite a range of views about the fragrance in the reviews here. Some find it just right.The lotion absorbs into the skin quickly, and leaves only a slight waxy, greasy feel, which is OK for moisturizing, but it isn't a heavy-duty moisturizing cream that can last for hours or withstand hand washing.The list of ingredients can be viewed in the second image on the Amazon product page, which shows the back label. The main ingredients are mostly natural, with water, shea butter (15%), glycerin, and coconut oil derivatives as the first four ingredients by weight, and there are numerous fruit and other plant extracts. There are also some synthetic ingredients, nothing very controversial, mostly rated low (the best rating) for health and environmental concerns by Environmental Working Group, which monitors cosmetics ingredients. A few ingredients, such as benzyl alcohol and linalool (those two happen to be naturally occurring chemicals also produced synthetically), are rated a medium concern for concentrations higher than the very small amounts in this lotion, or in regard to manufacturing issues. Some of the chemicals used, such as Lilial (butylphenyl methylpropanal), can cause irritation or allergic reaction in sensitive people (which is true of many natural ingredients as well).The front label has raised Braille lettering for "Shea Body Lotion," a nice touch.

Pretty good for individual learning. These are fun puzzles. My kids do a few per day.#27, orchestra antics, needs one more clue to solve.  Something like "at the end of the first song, all the players were on stage."
Perfect. Great details.  We are having fun making projects about the civil war.
Perfect.  We are recreating some civil war battles, and Puppet Grant is narrating developments. The kids are making films.

This is not a movie with... subtlety... nuance ... or metaphor...  Hamhanded writing and delivery.I think this group was also responsible for the Sandra Bullock movie "Blindside" made a few years later ... at least the weird-beard guy is on screen in both.  Blindside was the better show.
Fun for little hands. Like paper dolls for boys.

This used to be sold in a metal container. Recent order came in plastic rectangular containers, same sizzle and shape as the metal ones, but plastic.  Two problems: the plastic is not as rigid and can be /squeezed/. Squeezing pops the top open. Second problem is some amount of spice is getting through the plastic. You can smell it.
Pretty entertaining. Great for a kids' sleepover
Fun acting, fun to watch.

Spell it "premise," please.That's not a knock against the book, it's just my gripe about lazy spelling.T he information in the book is well presented. The illustrations don't always convey the meaning well. I bought this for a ninth grade student who has studied analogies and syllogisms already.  I think "fallacy detective" by Bluedorn and Bluedorn is going to be a more useful resource, but maybe the illustrations in t his book will help with long-term recall.Try both and see for yourself.

My son did not know this was part of a series when we purchased it on clearance at the discount book sale.  His comments:Interesting story about archeology - the supposedly ancient civiliztion is actually still inhabited.Gruesome punishments are described.The story is similar to the Underland Series by Suzanne Collins, but in this book the people underground are the bad guys.Favorite scene: noneThe book is very memorable.  Most memorable scene: the sister is NOT the sister, but a spy.Favorite character: the dog who looks like a cat.Good vocabulary words, like pallid.Some parts of the book are printed in type that is hard to read.Possibly interested in reading the rest of the series.

My son rates this a three-star book because there was not much suspense, and too much emotion.Fun fact: Ospreys are rare birds.  Seems like we saw a bunch of them in Oregon, so who knew?Most memorable scene: the girl diesBest character: none
My son laughed out loud reading this book, and re-read it several times over the course of a long car trip.  This is a great book.
This was the favorite book of my son for 1500 miles in the car.  He read it three or four times in 7 days.

My ten year old was vastly entertained by this book.Many of the riddles were already familiar.  For example, the riddles from the Hobbit were all included.Great riddles - easy to remember and retell.  Some real stumpers.
The riddles are long.My ten year old loves riddles, brain teasers, and language puzzles.  These were fun for him.  He retold many of them and stumped his listeners.
Got this to go with some Alessi ice cream spoons I gave as a gift.  Nice shape and finish.  I didn't test it out on the ice cream.  It looks like a shoehorn.
Cute.  I got these for a bridal shower.  Very nice packaging - came in a sturdy box.  Adorable spoon design, of course.
Nice roduct -  good keepsake from our travels.  Packaging problem - came in a box filled with all this shredded paper, which of course goes everywhere.  Bubblewrap... bubblewrap... bubblewrap.
Bought these for a voracious-reading teen.  Book one he read *twice* in two days.  Book two he stalled on and then stopped reading.  Books three and four he said were "ok."

I bought this because I want more books like this - anthologies of excellent writers who can craft  a vision of the near-future.  There are plenty of Dystopic Books of Doom out there - I wanted stories with more possibilities.The stories were mixed.  Some I liked pretty well, and some I didn't care anything about.  That's about normal for me - I rarely read fiction, because I can't bring myself to care about the characters or the writer.These stories almost always made sense.  Competent writing... it's sometimes enough.  Good job.More books like this, please.  Keep publishing these more interesting authors.

This toy has seriously been my almost 5 year old's favorite since Christmas.  She plays with it non-stop and makes the most interesting and different structures each time.  She also uses them with other toys (makes mazes for her hexbugs and chubby puppies, add-on units to her magna-tiles, etc.).  It's so cool how the little magnets stick to the walls -- and the quality of the tiles and the magnets is very good (very strong!).  The illustrations are adorable too.  Any boy or girl from 3-10 would love this.  I recommend getting the full three sets - you can get them for a package deal on the company's web site - because then you have so many more variations.  That's what we did and I never regretted it (in fact I keep checking out their site to see what's coming next - I think a pet salon and a fairy tale theater are in the works!).  I really love playing with these myself and I know my son (who is only 4 months) will be playing with them soon too.  (I think it's okay for younger kids as long as you take away the little magnets - the tiles themselves wouldn't be choking hazards and the magnets can't come out -- but you would want to store the actual little magnets until your child is 3).  Love this so much.  I really wish we had more! :)

My almost 5 year old loves these pups but I think her interest will be short lived. They are larger than expected and cute but overpriced. Five bucks would be a good amount.  Be careful of getting hair caught!

My almost 5 year old daughter LOVED this.  We downloaded the free app which lets you create a plan out how you'll paint your project - mixing and matching until you come to the perfect blueprint.  She then really followed what she had planned out - which was surprising to me.  She took great care at matching the colors and really created something that mirrored what she had planned out on the app.  She was so proud of the end product - and took a surprisingly long, concentrated time producing it.  I love the way it came out too.  The paint seemed really quality -- thick and brilliant.  The wood was okay quality -- strong enough to survive a high drop onto concrete (PHEW).  I want to buy her another in this series. :)

I bought the Platinum right as it first came out in June 2015 and am very disappointed.  When it's working, my daughter really does love it (and this is a child who uses an iPad and Kindle Fire way too much - bad mommy!!).  She loves that she can design her own profile, she really likes the Leapfrog apps (which I was surprised to see, as she has so many apps on the family iPad), and she enjoys taking videos and photos (which she can't really do on the iPad because it's in a heavy case).  The apps are expensive (even with the promo codes), but she does seem to really enjoy them and they are more educational than many on the android or iTunes stores.My problem? 1) there is VERY limited memory on the device and no way to supplement it with an SD card.  It comes preloaded with advertisement apps and other junk that takes up a lot of the limited memory - and it won't allow you to fill the device to the full 16 GB (or whatever it is).  When you get even remotely close, it crashes all the time.  2) It crashes all the time anyway.  Really slow and buggy. I sent it back to Leapfrog and they fixed it for a while, but a month later and it's crashing again.  I've already had to wipe the device and reload everything after it ran updates (after less than 3 months!), and now it won't let me download half the apps -- they are in some no man's land where I can't delete them and I can't download them.  It says they are installed but they aren't.  I reached out to Leapfrog (who generally seems to have great customer service - at least the first time there was an issue) yesterday and they sent me instructions for restoring a Leapfrog Ultra (which did not work).  So definitely very frustrating.  3) The apps are very expensive.  My daughter really did like the Paw Patrol Imagicards set.  I loved watching her play with that app in particular to see her go between "app world" and the real world. :)Conclusion - I would recommend buying a Kindle Fire and using their kid-safe app (which my daughter loves).  This way the device can really grow with your child and you have access to Netflix and can use the tablet as a browser yourself.  If you really want access to the Leapfrog content (which I think is really great - although maybe not exactly worth the price), I recommend waiting to purchase the Leapfrog Epic, which is supposed to come out this month (September 2015).  I hope it's not as gllitchy as its predecessor.

I was a little hesitant to buy this toy (and I bought 2 different ones and the vet set), but no regrets! This is such a great idea VTech (which I'm usually not a huge fan of) had!
