My daughter loves transformers (the robots) and the power of switching a toy into another toy...and this set has that option so she feels she has options and enjoys maneuvering the set from kitchen to ice cream shop. It makes a lot of different sounds (scooping, plopping ice cream, kitchen sounds) and the girl has a few different sayings and interacts with the other girls/other sets in this line. But honestly, I don't even think all the sounds are necessary/add too much: my daughter really just loves changing the dolls' hair, clothes, and transforming the sets themselves. While she likes the sounds too, I think VTech could have made these at a cheaper price point (and encouraged more creativity) by leaving out the sound element. (Also, if there were no sounds, we could have used these in the tub). Overall though, this is a great set. I recommend getting this one and at least one other so the "girls" have a friend to interact with. I wish they came out with some boys for this line too. Really great line of toys though!

My almost 5 year old daughter loved this so much.  The 6 posters are big and bright with all different themes and a diverse set of girls (redhead, blonde, brunette, and then three who could be from anywhere (Asian, Indian, African-American) but without seeming like it's trying to be PC - just a nice mix of happy, playful girls doing all sorts of activities (sports, dancing, cooking, being princesses, going to the beach - but sadly no girl scientists or artists, my daughter points out). It comes with a bunch of stickers (colorful) and a bunch of white/blank stickers that you can decorate with the included crayons and rubbing templates (which were pretty cool) to further design the posters.  My daughter has been quietly doing this activity on her own for 40 minutes...and she's rarely still for that long.  At twenty bucks, it may be a little overpriced - but we spent fifteen with a coupon on yoyo dot com, and I'm very happy with it at that price.  I recommend this for 4-6 year olds, although a 3 year old would enjoy it with some help.
Really delicious. My health-nut husband adds that it's super healthy, but it tastes great.  Really great price at bed bath and beyond - like four bucks.

I love this so much. It's so unique in that it has many colors at once moving on the sealing in a relaxing way with lots of variety in the music and sounds - with the moving aquarium display as an added bonus!

We have them all - Mr. Potsy, the picnic basket, the teacup set, the opposites house - but this is my favorite! The songs and sounds are not annoying at all (yet?) and the food is well made and adorable. I love the sizzling sound for the egg, the way the bread can be broken into pieces, the pizza - it's any kid's dream toy. Even though the recommended age is 2-3, my almost 5 year old loves playing with it (even though I bought it for her younger brother, who is fascinated by it too). I like that it's gender neutral too. I bet we'll see it on sale closer to Christmas, but I don't think the current non-sale price is unreasonable. We're definitely playing with it all the time! :)

I never trust the reviews where the reviewer got the item for free - but I have to say, they were true here. This game is so much fun for my almost 5 year old. It is pretty easy for her (but she is at the upper age limit) - but still reinforces numbers, shapes, sequencing, etc. She's playing it while I write this and the sounds aren't too annoying. The graphics were so much better than I expected and she loves finding and using the cards. They work really well (until we lose them all - lol). I wasn't thrilled with our leappad platinum (although Leapfrog had great customer service and fixed it for us), but I'm glad we bought it now that I see how cool these imagicards are. It's really easy for my daughter to use them and it's interesting to watch her switch between using her finger, the stylus, and the cards. It keeps her more engaged. I like watching her play too! We bought this "used" (just the packaging was damaged a little, but still new) through the amazon warehouse deals for twenty bucks. It was worth the price. And I'm cheap! :) oh - for Everest fans (the new girl pup) - she's part of the game (and is on one of the number cards), but isn't one of the "pup" cards - those are just the original dogs and Ryder.

This little dragon is so incredibly soft and cute. It's the perfect toy to help my almost-5 year old interact with her newborn brother. She uses the puppet to "talk" to him (and I pretend to do the baby's voice back) - and I know the baby will love it too, when he's a little bit older (being only 6 weeks now). So soft!! We got it new on e bay for eight bucks, but I would have paid full price for it now that I've seen it.

I hesitated when buying this as ten bucks seems steep, but now that it arrived I am totally happy with my decision. It is a big book w/ 100 unlined pages, some cute stickers, and decent crayons. The top handle is VERY sturdy and there is a sturdy flower clasp to secure the notebook closed (I think w magnets?). There is a clear plastic pouch to store the crayons which is is connected to the spirals on the top so you never lose them.  It's bigger/better than the plastic pouch you see in the photo -- that one is just to store the crayons this comes with, but the bigger pouch can fit more crayons too. This is great for car rides and restaurants. The colors are so bright and cheerful. Love it!

My almost-5 year old loves this and it was so much cuter than I expected!  The colors are really bright and vibrant - and it would be enjoyed by a wide age range (I would guess from around 2 until 6 or 7?).  At almost 5 years old, my daughter was very interested in trying to assemble the tree, castle, and carriage (which was a little tricky for her without having the picture in front of her) - but a younger child would enjoy decorating these items with the other pieces (flowers, hearts, etc.) and playing with the squirt toys.  For this reason, I think it would be a particularly good toy for a family with 2 children to play with in the bath (or pool) together.  It had more pieces than I thought from the picture too - and the bag it comes with (which suctions to the wall of the shower) is really awesome!  I see it's now fourteen bucks and I think for that price it's a really good deal.  Love it.

She did them all in one sitting in about 15 minutes and was very proud of the results. Some of them really came out great! She was sad that the one she made for me didn't fit on my wrist (but they fit her nicely). Good little project to bring to a restaurant to keep a child entertained.

This was pretty cool! So far, the glitter is contained and not all over the place - so "mess free" is right re: the glitter (although there are a bunch of the adhesive pull-away parts all over right now - but definitely not as bad as glitter!). After watching me do the first one (while I figured it out) and doing 2 together, she can now do them on her own -- but she's almost 5. She's very proud of herself that she can do them though - and I definitely think an older kid would have fun with these too (I'm having fun doing them with her). They should make sets with animals. This set feels like it's trying too hard to be a "boy" set versus the flower sets which are trying to be "girl" sets. My daughter picked this one bc she loves spaceships and dinosaurs - so all good. I'm happy with this purchase! So far it seems like it comes with enough glitter - and it's really sparkly!

These are really cute, small cardboard boxes with nice colors.  I've subtracted a star because I think the price should be around eight bucks (not fifteen) and because I wish the stickers were more varied (there's a lot of these small little ball shaped ones which are super tiny -- it looks a lot less than 450 stickers because of this) and that the stickers were divided into three separate packs - one for each box - as this would make it easier to either use each box with a different child or to pack them into three separate activities for the same child. We loved the tooth fairy box one by this same company which is an add-on for about six bucks.

My almost 5 year old had no problem doing this set and it kept her so happily busy for a good 30 minutes at least. I was happily surprised that the kit came with adorable paper, a pen, and a little pillow (for a tooth - but she has never lost a tooth so will use it for her little plastic play puppy as a puppy pillow). She's still working on it as I type this, but she loves any sort of little boxes so I know she'll play with this after the craft is completed. At six bucks, good deal.

This is the cutest set of little books which comes in a box which can also serve as a mini dollhouse.  The set contains 6 little board books - each of which is about 5 pages and is named after a different part of a home (kitchen, bedroom, garden, garage).  Each book fits into a compartment which is decorated as whatever spot in the house that particular book represents - and there is a cute little cardboard Jojo bunny which comes with the set (hidden behind the garden book) which my daughter enjoys placing in the spot of whichever book we're reading at the time.  This is also a great set to keep by the diaper changing table as the little books are the perfect size for little hands to hold (and to distract during a diaper change - haha).  The illustrations are SO CUTE and the books and outside box (which is also sort of a mini-dollhouse itself) are so colorful and high quality.  The box is decorated on the front, back, and all parts of the inside.  it secures closed  - I think by magnet?  It cost ten bucks at tar get.  It would make a great first birthday gift (but you would need to buy something else to go with it; it's a decent size, but not big enough as a stand alone present unless it's someone you don't know too well).  I'm so happy with this purchase and actually enjoying reading the short little books as the content is entertaining too - not your regular boring mini-board book. These are really so cute!

This pup is bigger than I expected - and very soft and huggable.  My 4 year old and I both love him - and she has no problem turning the light on (bright or dim modes) or off, using the pup's tail.  Ours came with batteries in it (purchased through fat brain toys).  My only disappointment was that in some of the youtube videos of this guy, I thought he made a chimey sound when you turn him on - but with ours, he makes a vibrating sound - like a cell phone would make (which gives me anxiety like someone is calling me).  I took one star off b/c at twenty seven bucks, he's kind of costly - but I really do love him and he's very useful (and loveable).

These looked really cute on the box, but were ultimately a disappointment.  They just don't stay together very well - and although my almost-5 year old daughter had fun putting them together with me, she was frustrated that she couldn't play with the animals after b/c they kept falling apart.  We tried playing "doctor" to fix them, but it was ultimately a little bit sad for her.  Also note that the eyes aren't adhesive so have some glue handy.  This was a cute idea and the creatures are adorable -- but they just don't turn out as nicely as the ones on the box and fall apart easily.  There are much better Alex Toys craft sets out there.

This is a cute little set. When I bought it here, it was eleven bucks and was well worth that. It is loud and after you press the button, it goes off on its own with barnacle's phrases for a little too long. I recommend not adding batteries - ha! I read all the reviews about the blaster setup not working. It is a bit underwhelming, but my 4 year old didn't seem to mind. Shellington is super cute in his outfit for this set. The octopus has a fun, rubbery feel. It took me 2 seconds to assemble and I'm an idiot at that stuff. Did not need to look at instructions. If you are buying the frustration-free version, it comes in just a brown box - not great for gifting unless you know the person well.
Only two bucks at tar get right now.  Smaller than it looks here but really cute and quality seems good so far.

This set is really great quality (and this brand in general has really high quality products).  There are four adorable collage projects - each one with a very sturdy cardboard base and a corresponding envelope with the materials needed to create each separate collage (so you don't need to go through the box to separate them out).  It also comes with a glue stick. I thought the set was great but my 4 year old art-loving daughter was frustrated because I (rookie mom) was trying to get her to follow the instructions to make the exact design shown, and she wanted to be more creative (bad mom!!!). She would agree with one of the other reviewers who said that this set, as adorable and well-crafted as it is, doesn't encourage creativity.  Although she's a glue-lover, she was also frustrated that the glue wasn't sticky enough to hold the (high quality cardboard) pieces - but sticky enough that the pieces kept sticking to her hand and she couldn't get them off and onto the base board. That said, the bad rookie mom enjoyed the project very much (and I'm someone who hates following instructions!). I think she will enjoy it more when she's in a different mood. We did this on New Year's Day after too many sugary snacks (again, rookie mom) and not enough sleep. :) I gave it 4 stars rather than 5 based on her reaction (not mine - I loved it!) and because even though the quality is great, the price is high. It comes in a beautiful box and looks expensive though -- makes a nice gift.

My 4 year old loves these.  She is already a huge Magna Tiles fan -- and we also have a bunch of the knock-off versions (Picasso Tiles, Metro Mags, Playmags - which all seem pretty much the same quality as Magna Tiles, but you can get so much more for the price.  The only one that had noticeably weaker magnets was the Stick & Stack brand, but they have really cool arches that none of the others do).  She likes these because they can make see-through "windows" for her creations and she likes to make cages/enclosures for her My Little Ponies, etc.  Definitely adds a whole new element to the play.  She loves to use these with Hexbug Nano (little robotic bugs - about four bucks on Amazon) -- making mazes for them to run through.  With these completely clear tiles, she can see what her creatures are doing more clearly than through the colorful ones.  When used with the other colorful tiles we already own, the "ice" clear ones make a really nice contrast - making the colorful ones seem more vibrant somehow.  It also helps that my daughter is obsessed with the movie Frozen and  likes to feel like she is making ice castles with these.  The only other brand of these types of tiles that I have seen which offer clear tiles is the Discount School Supply Building Brilliance tiles by Excellerations.  They are a hundred and fifty bucks for 150 tiles - but you can always find a promo code to get at least ten percent off. Those tiles are slightly smaller than the Magna Tiles but offer a trapezoid and rectangle shape that Magna Tiles lack.  The magnetic strength seems the same but they have more texture (and aren't quite as clear as the Magna Tile ice - but also a really cool look for less cost).

(I am writing the same review for this set and the related set, but if you can only pick one, I recommend buying this one as it's larger and more blocks = more options for creativity. I bought all three in this line as a group set directly from the company's own website). This is a cross between Magna Tiles (which has been my daughter's favorite toy since we bought these Build + Imagine sets) and those magnetic sets where you can build a scene using the magnets to tell a story. My daughter loves how some of the magnetic blocks in these sets have doors for the characters to walk through (unlike the Magna Tiles sets) and all the detail on the walls. The magnets are pretty strong - but it does take a little practice to make taller structures (and my daughter enjoys that challenge, as she does w/ the Magna Tiles). This is really easy to clean up and stores in a very compact way with all the magnetic walls sticking together. I have to admit, I enjoy playing with these sets too. (If you know your child already likes the Magna Tile/Magformer type sets (and I recommend those too - especially the cheaper knock-off versions which are just as good), I STRONGLY recommend these Build + Imagine sets for the added creative element. I love listening to my daughter make little stories for the magnetic characters and play with the sets like dollhouses - but also love seeing how proud she is of her architectural builds. I honestly think a little boy would love these sets too (which is good b/c I'm pregnant with one - lol). I'm not someone who got the set for free or anything like that, and can honestly say I'm so happy with the $ spent and look forward to playing with my daughter with these sets and don't even mind the cleanup. It's sort of fun to snap everything back together to put away (although my daughter cries when we break down her "masterpieces."). Another cool set for a younger child is the Hape Geometrics House. But I think this Build and Imagine line has more longevity as it will be more interesting to an older child. UPDATE: My daughter played with this for four hours straight yesterday!! I wish I could give it more stars.  She added magnets from other sets she had (like the Mudpuppy magnet sets) and also uses some of her dollhouse furniture in the rooms she makes with these tiles (as they are much bigger than the Magna Tiles).  I love watching the creative things she does with these sets. I really recommend getting all three because even with the three sets, she wishes she had more.  She spent such a long time looking at all the details on each wall - and she isn't one of those kids who can sit still like that for too long.  I really hope the company makes more in this line. I'll try to post photos showing how some of the walls/tiles have windows and doors which really open and close - and the beach set has a cafe window which opens down to serve customers. Too cute!

My 4 year old has been obsessed with all the magna tiles/picasso tile/metro mag type blocks for 2 years now - and I have never found any noticeable difference between magna tiles and the less expensive knock-offs until now. While this set is awesome b/c it's arches and curved blocks -- totally adds a new dimension to her builds! - it is frustrating that the magnets are so much weaker than the other three brands mentioned. I still recommend it until there is a better alternative, but I wish I hadn't spent thirty bucks on them. I guess it costs more to manufacture anything curved though?

This is a cross between Magna Tiles (which has been my daughter's favorite toy since we bought these Build + Imagine sets) and those magnetic sets where you can build a scene using the magnets to tell a story.  My 4 year old daughter loves how some of the magnetic blocks in these sets have doors for the characters to walk through (unlike the Magna Tiles sets) and all the detail on the walls. The magnets are pretty strong - but it does take a little practice to make taller structures (and my daughter enjoys that challenge, as she does w/ the Magna Tiles). This is really easy to clean up and stores in a very compact way with all the magnetic walls sticking together.  I have to admit, I enjoy playing with these sets too (we have all 3, which I bought at a discount directly from the vendor's website as a bundle deal). If you know your child already likes the Magna Tile/Magformer type sets (and I recommend those too - especially the cheaper knock-off versions which are just as good), I STRONGLY recommend these Build + Imagine sets for the added creative element. I love listening to my daughter make little stories for the magnetic characters and play with the sets like dollhouses - but also love seeing how proud she is of her architectural builds.  I honestly think a little boy would love these sets too (which is good b/c I'm pregnant with one - lol).  I'm not someone who got the set for free or anything like that, and can honestly say I'm so happy with the $ spent and look forward to playing with my daughter with these sets and don't even mind the cleanup.  It's sort of fun to snap everything back together to put away (although my daughter cries when we break down her "masterpieces.").  Another cool set for a younger child is the Hape Geometrics House.  But I think this Build and Imagine line has more longevity as it will be more interesting to an older child.  I would say the age range would be from 2 1/2 (if you take away the magnetic add-on aspect and hide them until your child is older) until the pre-teens.

My husband has been playing with this for a while tonight and seems to be having fun (!) and my 4 year old is intrigued. The quality of the cardboard is very good and the colors are bright.  Not the most exciting "toy" in the world, but something interesting to have out to mess around with. Might be good to have on a coffee table or to work on together with an older child while chatting. I think there are some people out there who would love this and others who wouldn't use it twice - and not too many people in between. I don't think mathematically, but this set was still a little bit fun for me to mess around with. I think if your kid likes puzzles and rubics cube type toys, he or she will like this. I got it on sale around xmas when BN had a buy one get one 50 percent off deal for all toys.

These are a relatively mess-free paint. The paint colors are rich and flow well from the containers through the brush. Great for 4 year old. An older child might get frustrated if trying to paint fine details since the brush isn't tiny. We love it though!

This set is so beautiful and well constructed.  The two little dolls which come with it are adorable. The colors and theme are gender neutral. I was afraid it wouldn't be sophisticated enough for my 4 year old, but she loves the unique architectural element of designing and re-designing the three separate segments of the house. I also bought the purple Hape Happy Family Modern Girl doll - and she is too big to fit with the two dolls which come with this one (although she can fit inside the house just fine - just not the same scale exactly), but my daughter explains that this is because she is their mom. (!). I like the cut out windows in the segments. There is a lot of furniture which comes with this - all of which is really sturdy and beautiful. The wood is very smooth and the paint is bright. The umbrella part is nice felt, but everything else is wood it seems.  I found this on sale for under fifty (including shipping) with a promo code on a site called giggle toys or something like that.  I would buy now because it's selling out everywhere (Dec. 2014).

In highly untechnical terms, this is a beautiful monitor.Setting it up was a wonderful experience start to finish- something I can almost never say. Assembly was extremely simple and straightforward. The stand is nice and sturdy. A swivel feature would have been a nice addition, and as a minor thing is my biggest complaint. When installing the monitor to work with my computer I was apprehensive, but my computer (running windows 7) recognized the new monitor immediately on connection. It was unnecessary to use the included cd/software, and I didn't need to change any settings.The monitor itself is wonderful. The picture is phenomenal; it has clean, crisp, vibrant color. My HD tv sits right next to it, and reflects a lot of glare from the windows, but the monitor shows minimal glare. The differences that I think I can attribute to the curve are the reduced glare (wonderful!), and that the picture is sharp and clear from any viewing angle. When viewing straight on I don't notice any difference between this or a really good HD tv; that said, that kind of viewing experience is much better than most other computer monitors I've used.

I've had success with all of the Scotts Turf Builder mixes, but the ryegrass has done particularly well for me. We have a busy house, a busy yard, and our grass needs to stand up to abuse, even during the most delicate growing phase. Although there were a few rough spots, the perrenial rygegrass mix has done that well- dogs, cats, people running, jumping, and playing, wheelbarrows, you name it- it's survived.

The most difficult of the Scotts seeds to plant, but my favorite grass. Kentucky Blue grass has a tough time standing up to our active yard- dogs, people, and uneven light and moisture. However when it grows, it grows thick, green, and soft. Hopefully a new irrigation system will improve the soil conditions, and make this grass thrive.

Since anybody that orders this bench will be starting with assembly that's where I'll begin.ASSEMBLY: I have put together numerous other exercise benches, from your standard flat bench press, to sit up benches with adjustable heights and angles, to adjustable bench presses with more moving parts than I care to recall. This was by far one of the easiest. Everything was clearly labeled and numbered, there aren't a million parts and screws that look identical so you don't know which is #1 and #8. Everything goes where it's shown to on the diagram and fits together puzzle perfect. All in all ASSEMBLY 10 out of 10.USE: Once the bench was assembled I decided to give it a go. It's relatively the same height as any flat bench you'll find in your basic gyms (NYSC, RETRO, YMCA, etc.) as well as being just lower than the standard bench for power-lifting. The cushion is great, plenty of it but not so soft that it creates an unsteady base for exercise causing you to shift around. As for wiggle, there is none, and that's saying something because out of all the exercise benches I've put together and even used in gyms they almost all have at least some wiggle to them. The weight limit also says 300 lbs but from my testing can easily go above (not a recommendation, just saying). The only complaint I do have about the bench is I wish the height were adjustable which would therefor allow for a greater range of exercises, but this is still one of the best flat benches I've ever had the pleasure of owning. All in all USE 9 out of 10.DURABILITY: I beat my exercise benches up, always have always will. Some last a year, some last 5. I can tell you I put this one through the ringer - dragging 45lbs plates off, resting dumbbells, exceeding the weight limit, testing weight placement on all the corners and edges... Not a mark on it that a wet paper towel couldn't remove, this thing is a rock solid piece of equipment that will easily last the average exerciser a lifetime and someone who really beats the crap of it will have their work cut out for them to get rid of this thing. DURABILITY 10 out of 10 (one of the best I've ever used).OVERALL: If you're looking for a basic flat exercise bench for a plethora of exercises and exercise styles with decent comfort and that will last a lifetime, then this is the one for you. Good job Adidas.

This was my first experiment with an epilator, and the results were decidedly mixed. The epilation attachment was actually the least effective, and in general I prefer shaving- it is faster, smoother, and doesn't hurt like I'm being skinned alive. The razor attachment is worse than useless. However, the bikini attachment was a revalation. It works well and easily, isn't painful, and doesn't leave me with a painful and unsightly rash as some razors do.The epilator comes with multiple pages of warnings and instructions; read carefully before using. The other note of importance is that the battery is rechargable for a certain lifespan (estimated 3 years), but then cannot be replaced by the consumer.

I have a very mixed environment lawn- full sun in some areas, full shade in others; good top soil in the front, poor clay on the side; salt exposure around the edges, minimally watering in the back; the only thing that is minimally consistent is relaively heavy traffic of playing dogs and people. I've had the most success with Scotts Turft Builder series of seeds, choosing the most appropriate seed to each area.In this case I am using the Heat Tolerant blue mix in an area in the center of the yard that is exposed to full, strong mid-day sun, is frequently played on by 2 big dogs, and is a mix of top soil and clay. I added a quarter inch of top soil when laying this seed, and have had good growth start in the last few weeks.

I needed to stake out and put a temporary fence around an area of lawn that was being reseeded. These stakes did the job well. They are strong, sturdy, tall enough, and not coated in splinters. They didn't break when hammered into the ground, and only one broke when hammered with a 100 lb dog body.

Althoguh the cotton in this rug is soft- as in not scratchy or rough in texture- it is not what I imagined. The product description says you can "sink your feet into this plush rug", which is almost the opposite of how I would describe it. It is a very firm rug with bumpy nubs of fabric. The fabric itself is relatively smooth and soft, and not scratchy or rough in any way.This is quite a nice firm bath mat, but it isn't plush by stretch of the imagination.

My dogs aren't picky eaters, and loved this food. They have relatively sensitive stomachs, and this didn't cause any problems after a slow switch (over a 2 week period). However, it is important to note that this is a *limited* ingredient food, not a single protein food- it does include chicken fat. Therefore it is not an appropriate food for dogs with true allergies.

Frankly, I think these earings are a bit tacky looking in the product photos. In person they are far more subtle and elegant looking; a very nice design which is flattering with a variety of outfits. They are lightweight and very comfortable to wear. My only complaint is that the post and latch are poorly disigned. The post is thin and feels flimsy, and the latch doesn't hook well and doesn't feel secure.I will be bringing these to a local jeweler for repair.

I am replanting an area of lawn that is partly sunny in the spring, but becomes quite shady during the summer. I've had trouble in the past getting seed established enough during that short spring period that it can survive during the summer, even other fescue and shade tolerant mixes. However this Scott's fescue mix has done well, despite the primarily overcast weather we've had, and I have high hopes for the summer season.As always, proper watering, fertilization, and lack of traffic were important factors in its growth that are not to be discounted.

I have had better success using Scotts grass seed products than any others, however this is my least favorite among those I've used. Unless you have a truly mixed area- patchy sunlight all day long, divided to the degree that it is not possible to separately seed the areas with sun or shade mix, I would recommend using a different mix. I would recommend using Scotts Turf Builder Grass Seed - Dense Shade Mix, 7-Pound (Not Sold in Louisiana) for shady areas, and Scotts Turf Builder Grass Seed - Sunny Mix, 3-Pound (Not Sold in Louisiana) for sunny areas.I am replanting large areas of lawn without using any weed killers, using minimal organic fertilizers, and using a spot sprinkler (rather than built in sprinker system). The Scotts seed sprouted in several days, and although it is still thin, there are few weeds growing, and more grass seedlings every day.

The Cuisinart CSG-515 digital thermometer is a good, inexpensive digital meat thermometer. The probe is sturdy, although a bit bigger than I'd prefer for some more delicate chicken cuts. The thermometer gets a reading within 10 seconds and is quite accurate. The bendable head is fantastic, giving you the flexibility to check the temperature of the meat in whatever area you'd like, regardless of positioning on the grill.The probe cover and magnet area also nice touches, which make use and storage easier. Although I haven't had trouble with the battery cover, I would prefer a standard AAA battery, both for the ease of use and cost of the battery.

This Oster 12-speed blender is an ok low cost blender, but it has multiple problems, and better blenders are available for a similar price.Plastic- Most blenders today are made with plastic jugs, and this one is comprably well made. However, I have found that in general glass is significantly more durable, easier to clean, and doesn't stain.Blending- The blender has 12 speeds, but I didn't find a significant difference between the different speeds, and all of them were quite loud. Blending frozen fruit and large chunks of fresh banana and peaches took significantly longer and did a poorer job in this blender than in my Oster BPCT02-BA0-000 6-Cup Glass Jar 2-Speed Toggle Beehive Blender, Brushed Stainless.The blender doesn't have a large footprint on the counter, and otherwise seems generally well made.Overall, I'm not particularly happy with this blender, and would recommend looking for another.

The Oreck floor cleaner cleans "ok"- it takes a little more time and effort than I would like or expect, but in the end does a decent job. However, it isn't a much better job than swiffer or other flat mop could do without a little additional effort, and a whole lot less expense. In addition, it doesn't clean up the water nearly as well or as easily as I'd like; I was almost tempted to get a towel and sop it up so I'd just be done.

I loved the corded version of this- a houseful of animals and people, and everyone is active outdoors, so there's no way to stay clean. Both the corded and cordless versions work great to get things shiny and clean. The cordless version eliminates the hassle of moving a cord around and getting tangled on furniture, dogs, cats, and my own legs. The battery life is great.

Fertilizer isn't magic, whatever Scotts claims. The product statement says-- "Grows new grass thicker and quicker"  - Thicker yes, quicker I'd dispute- "Accelerates root growth of new grass plants and existing lawn"  - This I would agree withIf the soil is prepared properly- 5-15 inches of good quality top soil, good grass seeds, adequate water (not drought or flood), adequate sunlight, and no foot traffic- Scotts Turf Builder will help new grass grow thicker and healthier root systems, and thus thicker and healthier grass. The Scotts itself must be applied properly (more is not better). I have seen no evidence that the grass grows more quickly due to the fertilizer, but plenty of evidence that lack of proper care in other areas will stop growth in its tracks.Additionally, I like that this product doesn't include any crabgrass or weed killer, both of which prevent germination, and I think, make fertilization of new grass far less effective.

The 5 year old and 8 year old I read this with were aware generally, of what Amnesty International is and does, so perhaps are not the typical audience. They alternated between wanting to learn about the different people quoted in the book, and making up their own stories for each illustration. Although I didn't think every illustration matched its quote very well, they seemed to enjoy the vast majority of both quotes and illustrations, and had just as much fun making up stories for the obscure ones. In the end, this is unlikely to be a frequently re-read "story" type book, but it gave us several hours of entertainment, and it's supporting a very worth cause.

These pruners are constructed of heavy duty plastic and strong steel blades. The unique design causes the handle of the cutting blade to roll along your hand as the blade is being squeezed, ensuring that pressure is not concentrated on one spot in your hand. This is intended to prevent significant pressure from being placed on one area of the hand, and to increase cutting power. Unfortunately, it means that the pruners are only designed for right-handed people. I can attest that the rolling mechanism reduces pain that would otherwise build in those with arthritis or other joint problems, although the mechanism does take some getting used to. However, I don't find these pruners any more powerful than other pruners of similar size.

I took the plunge- literally- with this case (haha), and my ipad lived to tell the tale.The lifeproof case comes with an ipad "stand in", which allows you to practice putting the case on, and to test the case for defects before subjecting your ipad to potentially destructive experiences. The case is initially difficult (bit of an understatement) to get on and off even using the provided tool, but it becomes a bit easier once you're used to it. The case is made of thick, heavy-duty plastic, and thick rubber edging, which seals the ports and seals around the edges of the screen. There is no screen cover, despite the ad copy, which says "Built-in scratch protector for total touchscreen defense". That lack gave me a few strong moments of doubt and panic, but the rubber seals so tightly against the screen it's one of the most difficult parts to remove, and is undoubtedly secure.Once locked up tight in the case I submerged my ipad in an icy snow bank, in warm/hot bath water, and in a cool sink. No leaks, and no damage. I also dropped it from about 5 ft., twice. Both times it bounced on an corner and fell flat, with no damage. The only test I didn't perform was to drop it flat on its face, or to drop it with the screen hitting an edge.Although the case definitely adds bulk, I wouldn't anticipate using this as a day to day case, so it doesn't both me. I would want to use the case in a pool or bathtub, both situations in which the lack of stand is a drawback.My number one complaint about the case is that it comes with a 1 year limited warranty, which specifies that "The LifeProof warranty only covers the LifeProof product - it does not cover any non-LifeProof product or device, and does not provide warrenty protection in all circumstances." The warranty further states, "It is your responsibility to take reasonable precautions regarding how you use your device. Expose your device to hazards at your own risk". I considered researching and selecting a LifeProof case to be a reasonable precaution against those dangers, but since the company doesn't trust their own product enough to consider it so, neither will I.

Post-it has achieved the perfect balance of adhesiveness with this package. Designed to be stuck in the back of a notebook or book, the backing is sticky enough to be secure, but not so sticky that it is permanent or leaves a residue behind.The pack comes with 25 full-sized yellow post-its (2x2 in) and 100 flags (25 each of 4 colors). The flags are the medium size and are made of waxy material- they won't get worn or tear easily like the paper flags, and can be written on with most pencils and ballpoint pens without smearing.I would prefer more full-sized post-its, but otherwise this package was wonderfully designed and was of far more use than I initially thought it would be.

Understanding wood/pine litter-Wood litter is produced as a byproduct from various types of wood manufacturing.  The wood is compressed into pellets, which break down into saw dust when urinated on. It is biodegradable, produces minimal dust, and is therefore environmentally friendly. It can be flushed down the toilet or disposed of in the garbage.Using wood litter-Unlike traditional clay litters which form a clump when the cat urinates, with wood litter the pellets break down into dry sawdust. The sawdust is sifted out of the box, using a slatted scoop, and the pellets returned to the box. If the sawdust is wet, either not enough litter was present, or the litter box should be cleaned more frequently.Smell-The wood litter smells like pine, much more pleasant than clay which I found to have an unpleasant chemical smell. I have four cats, and with the clay I often had to clean the litterbox multiple times a day during the summer because in the heat nothing got rid of the urine smell. With the wood litter I can't smell it at all. Unfortunately, because the litter doesn't clump, it doesn't adhere to feces, so if your cat doesn't like to bury, that can smell quite a bit.Duration-I find that the wood litter lasts approximately a third again as long as the clay litter did for equal weight; i.e. about the same length of time by volume.okocat Natural Pine Litter-I have tried other brands of natural wood/pellet litter, and haven't noticed a particular difference with the okocat litter. Unfortunately I haven't tried any of the other okocat types of litter (they do have a clumping wood litter) and can't comment on the differences.Price-The price is the biggest down side to the wood litter. It is prohibitively expensive compared to most clay litters. I buy in bulk and get a good discount, but without that option I wouldn't be able to afford it.

Like many other readers I selected this book because of the author's name, and in spite of the title, cover, and other marketing. And thankfully, I was right to give it a chance. Although the marketing all screams romance, this is an urban fantasy that happens to have a romantic subplot. Readers who have enjoyed Andrews' previous series- Kate Daniels, and The Edge- will also like this one, and should look to summaries of those books for a better indication of tone and genre.Magical ability was imparted several decades ago by a serum administered to create better soldiers. Different abilities and power levels are passed through genetic lines; the stronger the magic, the stronger- read wealthier and more powerful- the family. Nevada Baylor runs her family's PI firm, and when the company that owns the mortgage on the firm gives her no choice, she's pulled into an investigation that is well beyond her power, on both personal and family levels. (The story is told in first person POV from her perspective.) Her investigation soon collides with 'Mad' Rogan's, (we learn about his interest in the case through a short prologue), and they reluctantly team up. As things progress, Nevada must do her best to protect her family and herself from all of the other interests involved, including the man she is trying to capture, the company that hired her, and her questionable partner, Mad Rogan, and oh yeah, save the city.'Burn for Me' is an enjoyable read, with generally good writing, but it does have some ups and downs. The world building in particular is excellent, and that information is relayed smoothly throughout the book.Writing first person point of view is always difficult, and that I barely noticed it while reading says a lot. However, it makes character development difficult, as normal individuals only do so much self-analysis, and can only know a limited amount about other characters and their thoughts and intentions. A short prologue and epilogue were designed to impart a bit more information about 'Mad' Rogan, and the over-aching plot, but are clumsy and the epilogue ends the book on an awkward note. The need for that random info relay is unfortunately indicative of the unevenness of the plot (both substance and pacing), and is my primary complaint about the book.However the overall writing is so good it disguises many of the weaknesses. I thought that the first books of Andrews' previous series' (Kate Daniels, The Edge) were more uneven than the subsequent books, particularly in terms of character development and plot, and I'm hoping we'll see the same improvement in the next book of the Hidden Legacy series.Like Andrews' other books, 'Burn For Me' has a good mix of action, adventure, and humor. Although they've written better, it was an enjoyable, engaging read, and I'm looking forward to the next book in the series.

Measurements--2.5 quarts- This is a nice size, on the small end of medium.-8" diameter, 3" depth- Standard casserole measurement-2.5" handles, with wide flat surfaces, and a good sized hand opening- Excellent for those with dexterity problems; there is enough room to easily fit a pot holder and fingers in the handles and get a good grip.-2 lb- Very light weight, good for older adults, or those with wrist problems who can't lift 5lb+ cast ironMaterials--Aluminum- Contributes to the light weight, but the trade-off is that it doesn't feel too sturdy.-Enamel outer coating-Non-stick inner surface, PFOA free!- PFOA free is a key point; Both the pot and the inner surface of the lid are coated (an important but oft overlooked design point).Uses--Oven up to 500F-Freezer-Gas, electric, and electric radient stove tops-The box does NOT specify microwave safeAfter a handful of uses, both in the oven and on the stovetop (gas), I have no complaints although there's nothing particularly special it. The lid fits tightly onto the pot, with a slight interior lip. The non-stick coating on the lid is nice, and cleaning is very easy.I have the orange color, which matches the color in the product photo. The color and design have a vintage feel, and may be the most unique aspects to the pot.

The "Vitamix Certified Reconditioned Standard Program Blender, Black" is actually a refurbished Vitamix 5200.It comes with the following warranties--30 day guarantee- Full refund if not happy with the blender and returned within 30 days.-5 year parts and labor- Including return shipping; either like-new replacement or full refund."Certified Reconditioned" checks and standards--Base including exterior, switches, and motor- Inspected for cosmetic appearance; all functions/programs tested; motor run at least three times-Blades- Less than a year old and sanitized in high temperature wash-Blender container, lid, and tamper- All new-Cookbook pack- NewThe blender appeared in perfect condition out of the box. If it hadn't said "reconditioned" on the box, I wouldn't have known it wasn't brand new. All parts were present, in perfect condition on visual inspection, and all speeds/programs worked without a problem.For reviews of the actual blender, I recommend reading both the reviews on this page, and on the page for the Vitamix 5200 Series Blender, Black.I compared the Vitamix to my Braun MX2050 5-Speed Heavy Duty Blender, 220-240-volt (mine is 120v for the US). I use the blender almost daily to create smoothies using a combination of frozen and fresh fruit, and yogurt. I have also used it to chop cheese and ice, make milkshakes, and more.Construction-The Vitamix has a taller, heavier base, which means it doesn't fit on the counter under the cabinets. Overall feels very well made.The Braun has a slightly shorter, and definitely ligher base, but still feels well made.Container-The Vitamix jug is made of heavy plastic which feels very sturdy, but I am worried about staining over time from fruits such as blueberries and strawberries, although after a month it is cleaning well. The container holds 8.5 cups (2L), which is slightly more than the Braun. It pours easily; a trait I have learned not to undervalue.The Braun container is made of thick glass, and I love it. It is simple to clean, and even after 2 years of use, comes out sparkling new every time. The triangular shape of the container means that it also pours very well.Speeds/Functions-The Braun has a dial, and 5 speeds. When using you immediately turn to the speed you want, and at the end switch to off.The Vitamix has a 'Variable/High' switch, and 10 speeds within variable. You almost always start at variable 1, and slowly work up. Unfortunately the On/Off switch is separate, therefore you must remember to return the other switches to the starting position after each use.Noise-Both are quite noisy at higher levels, although not quite as bad as some blenders I've tried.Functionality-For my current purposes, the two work equally well; they both blend quickly, smoothly, and evenly. I have never tried to blend greens (spinach, kale), or hard vegetables (carrots, etc.), in the Braun, as is suggested in the Vitamix cookbook.For your basic, and even slightly more advanced blending needs, the Braun or a similar blender will serve you well (for significantly less). However, I suspect for serious juicing purposes the vitamix has the advantage, and if you're looking for such a blender, the Reconditioned 5200 is a good choice.

The positives--Leak-proof-As demonstrated in the product photos, the top unscrews at two levels. The wider, lower opening is easy to add ice cubes to; the narrower top level is more comfortable to drink from.-Grippy silicone sleave makes this bottle non-slip, no matter how wet it or your hands are.-Light weight-Easy to open- Tops twists off with minimal effort; excellent for those with arthritis or other motility problems.-Sturdy- I've already dropped it twice, on a hardwood floor, and on granite patio slabs. No cracks or leaks.-BPA free!-Dishwasher safeThe negatives--The silicone sleave attracts pet hair like a magnet. It rinses right off, but in the meantime is pretty grungy.-Non-insulating- This bottle is on par with other plastic bottles in terms of the level of insulation. Metal and/or glass are significantly heavier, but they insulate far better.-Doesn't fit into most car cup holders

Although set up initially seemed clear, it acutally ended up being more difficult than expected. The wireless connected easily, but the software setup didn't work smoothly or easily; it repeatedly asked to print to a folder before the printer, different settings were difficult to find, etc. In the end it took about 30 minutes. Not the worst set up I've ever done, but far from the smoothest.I have so far printed 10 black and white pages, and 10 color pages. A small number for a printer than claims 1,800 color pages per toner cartridge. However the black ink already says it is down 10% and the other colors are down between 5-8%. (It is possible that the measurements are inaccurate, and I will continue to keep track of the toner use and update this review as appropriate.)The printer does however have it's upsides. The wireless printing worked smoothly, and printed rapidly. And the print quality, both black and white and color were very good.

I was looking for a keyboard case for my ipad mini that works well, is easy to use, is a secure and protective case, and is conservative/professional looking (no neon pink). Unfortunately the Belkin universal portable keyboard only fits the bill on looks.The case is made of a conservative black leather, and appears neat and professional once set up. If that is your primary concern, this is the case for you. If not, unfortunately it's all downhill from there. The case holds the tablet in with plastic tabs that fit around each corner. They stretch easily and hold the tablet relatively securely, but there is no screen cover and all 4 sides of the tablet are left exposed to dust, dirt, etc. Fine if you're leaving the tablet and case in an office. Not great if you're transporting it anywhere. I'm not sure how secure the tablet would be if dropped.The keyboard is frustrating to say the least. I am an experienced typist and have small/medium sized hands, however have a lot of trouble using the keyboard. The keys are generally somewhat small and crowded, and I have more problems with this than other similarly sized keyboards. The spacebar in particular is awkwardly sized and positioned; 2.5 in. and right next to the internet search key. (I also have a Logitech Ultrathin Keyboard Cover Mini for iPad mini - Black- the spacebar is 3.5 in.) After hitting the search key for the 10th time I was ready to pull my hair out.An additional note that may only bother some people- there is no Delete key to allow forward deletion (vs. the more common backspace). (The Logitech does offer this feature.)The Belkin comes with no instructions, and setting up the case itself is not intuitive. It took me a while to figure out how to prop the case up, and to discover that it only props at 90 deg. and ~35 deg.; not the best angles.I didn't have any problems getting the keyboard to connect to the tablet via bluetooth, but again there were no instructions for those who may not know what to do.If you're going for looks only, and this case will be staying in one place, this may be the right case for you. But if ease of typing and protection while transporting are important, I'd keep looking elsewhere. As for me, I'm sticking with my separate  full case (far more secure and protective) and logitech keyboard (far easier to use).

A few points about the Bose SoundTrue headphones--They are among the most comfortable headphones I've ever used. They are so lightweight I forget I'm wearing them. They create no pressure against the ears or head, no matter how long they're worn. They don't overheat or become sticky or muggy, no matter how long they're worn. The leather on the ears cups is very soft and non-abrasive.-They are made of plastic, which doesn't feel particularly heavy duty (probably why they are so lightweight), but don't feel as if they'll break any second. The ear cups swivel widely, and the plastic is flexible in general.-They feature a long cord, with inline volume control and microphone that work great. They also come equiped with a study carrying case.-The sound quality is excellent for this level of headphones. As I explore different headphones more widely, I am gaining a better appreciation of the more subtle differences between different headphones and different brands. (Although my ability to describe such differences remains minimal.) These headphones generally sound great. As for more subtle differences, the Bose-lover in the family can't get enough of them, saying the sound is "stronger", while I prefer my Sennheiser Momentum Headphone - Brown, which I would describe as more "detailed".In the end, there is no better way to choose headphones than to try them out youself, especially to determine whether the size and fit are right for you.

I use the Tassimo pods in a Bosch/Tassimo pod coffee maker. I've also tried opening them and making them in Keuring (as it seemed to be a common point of confusion with other people), but I thought they tasted significantly better when made with their appropriate system.The Tassimo Medium roast is a true medium roast, with a light coffee flavor and a great smell. The flavor is light and smooth, without being watery, and doesn't have a bitter or acidic aftertaste. I often prefer dark roasts, and their more robust coffee flavor, but this has it's place too and is quite enjoyable. As with every brewing system I've tried, I've found Tasimo pods that I enjoy, and many that are horrible. The medium roast definitely goes on the keeper shelf and will be ordered again.

This review is for the Almonds w/ Cranberries, Honey, and Sea salt, one of my favorites of the Sahale Snacks line--They are healthy: 4 grams of fiber, 7 grams of protein per bag; although they do contain 17 g of fat, none is saturated fat. 220 calories is not unreasonable for a snack of this size with this much protein.-They are tasty: The almonds and cranberries are delicious, the salt is at the perfect amount to add a bit of flavor, but isn't too salty, and there is just a hint of honey and sesame seeds to finish it off. (I couldn't taste any vanilla.)-The quantity is perfect: 1.5 oz per package; The measurement doesn't mean much to me, but eating a package leaves me satisfied, rather than still hungry, or over-full.-The packaging is good: It is easy to open, but sturdy enough that it doesn't tear all the way down and spill everything.-The price is reasonable: I have seen similarly healthy snacks offered for more than twice the price; although these aren't cheap, they are reasonablly affordable.I highly recommend these, and have already ordered another box for myself.

This printer meets most of my requirements for a good printer, excels in a few areas, and leaves me with only one complaint.-Size:  The printer is small (~12 x 6 x 18"), and lightweight (~10 lbs).-Quality:  It prints excellent color, (and I'm quite picky). It also prints good black and white, and has gray scale and draft options to save ink.-Speed:  It isn't the fastest printer on the market, but at ~20-30 seconds per print (faster for B&W, slower for color), it isn't the slowest either.-Set-up:  Unlike the Epson WorkForce WF-3540 Wireless All-in-One Color Inkjet Printer, Copier, Scanner, 2-Sided Duplex, ADF, Fax. Prints from Tablet/Smartphone. AirPrint Compatible (C11CC31201), which I recently tried and found a disaster to set up and use, this Canon Pixma was a pleasure. It took less than 5 minutes to set it up on 2 laptops, a smartphone, and an iPad. Fantastic.-Warranty: There is a good 1-year warranty from Canon. (A rarity with less expensive electronics these days.)Complaint--Ink cartridges: Rather than come in individual color cartridges, they are a block of color cartridges, and a separate black cartridge. The color block costs $50 to replace, almost the same cost as the printer itself.

The most important thing to realize when selecting this product is that it is a 1 year license. In other words, you will need to repurchase Office, or at least a new subscription, in a year. There are multiple packages for Microsoft Office 2013, each slightly different, with a different cost. I recommend looking up a chart and comparing each before making a purchase. (The basic version, 1 user, no time limit is Microsoft Office Home and Business 2013 - license (T5D-01575) -.)Office 365 w/ a 1 year subscription contains a bonanza--Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Outlook, OneNote, Publisher, and Access-SkyDrive with 27 gb of storage, free for a year-Skype with 60 minutes of international calls free per month-Licenses for 5 computers (either PCs or Macs)However, there are notable exceptions for macs--OneNote, Publisher, and Access are not available for Macs.-Office 2013 is PC only; Macs receive Office 2011. (The updated mac version is produced the year after the PC version, therefore expect Office 2014 for Macs.)If you are buying for PCs there are few changes in 2013 from Office 2010, but if you have an earlier version, the update is likely worth it. Similarly, if you are buying for Macs and don't already have Office 2011 it may be worth the purchase, but otherwise wait until next year.The registration process is clear and easy to complete, registration of further computers is also simple, and adding the subscription to your skype account is as simple as putting in your password. Unfortunately the installation process is not so simple. Although the installation problems on the Mac were eventually sorted out; on the PC it eventually "failed" and could not be completed, desite entirely uninstalling previous versions and spening more than 3 hours following various instructions.

The Whirlpool Energy Star 70-Pint 2-Speed Dehumidifier is, as far as I can tell, identical to the Hisense DH-70K1SJE4 Energy Star 70-Pint 2-Speed Dehumidifier, with the single difference being that it does not have an ionizer. The Whirlpool dehumidifier comes with paperwork saying that it is manufactured by Hisense, and all contact and repair information refers to Hisense. That said, I've been relatively happy with both the Hisense and the Whirlpool.The Whirlpool meets many of the important points I look for--It is constructed of sturdy plastic and seems well made.-It weighs approximately 20 lbs, (not including water, which can add a significant amount of weight), but has wheels on the bottom that make it easily maneuverable.-It has a large water capacity.-It has an automatic draining feature, that is very easy to set up and works well.-ALthough it doesn't come with its own hose for the automatic draining, it uses a normal garden hose, rather than a proprietary size as some do, which makes it easy and cheap to buy a hose and replacements.-When manually emptying, the drawer slides out very easily, and is easy to replace. (This is a very important point, as in some humidifiers they can be almost impossible to fit back in correctly.)-The noise level is standard for this size dehumidifier. (Although I am using the unit in a basement; I'm not sure I'd want the noise in a living area, but I don't think I've ever had a dehumidifier quiet enough that it wouldn't bother me in a living area.)-It is an energy star model.-It has digital controls, which are bright and easy to see, and the buttons work well.The controls/display include current humidity and temperature, and a timer.The settings allow control of--Fan speed (low, high, and auto)-Deired humidity (continuous, normal, and auto dry)-TimerThere are several ways the humidifier can be controlled--You can set it to maintain a particular humidity, leaving it on constantly.-You can turn it on with a particular fan speed, leaving it on constantly.-You can set it on a timer to run for a certain length of time. However, unlike other humidifiers I've used, this is a one-time setting. I.e. It can be set to turn on for 2 hours, but cannot be set to automatically turn on every day for 2 hours.-You can set it to turn on at a certain time. However, when using that setting, as far as I can tell, you can't set the length of time it will run; you need to come back to turn it off.I have two main complaints about this dehumidifier--There is no warranty. This is a massive problem for a relatively expensive item. If you are considering purchasing, I would recommended learning what purchase protection is offered by your credit card.-Second is the lack of specific control of the timer; more specific controls would allow more efficient use and energy savings by allowing it to be turned off when not needed. Although it can be set to turn on at a specific time once, it cannot be set to turn off, so it will be running until you can make it back to shut it off again. Also, it is a one-time setting. I.e. It cannot be set to come on at a certain time every day. However, this seems to be fairly standard in every dehumidifier I've seen recently.Overall a solid dehumidifier; although it doesn't stand out in any way, I haven't had any problems with it after more than a month of use.

Good wraps made out of strong, supportive material. Unlike some wraps, these are not just made out of fabric, but instead are a thick, wide foam (2in x 6 mm) that is both more supportive and more comfortable than plain cloth. These are just as supportive and well made as the more expensive Schiek Black Line Heavy Duty Wrist Wraps.The wraps are well made. The metal bar provides leverage to get a tight wrap, but never bothers the wrist. The wraps are quite secure, and never come loose, even on heavy lifts. After 3 weeks of use there has been no stretching or loosening of the fabric, and the foam hasn't become compressed or weakened. These have been used for benchpress, weighted dips, and shoulder presses, and have been great for all.Although the notes say hand wash, there have been no problems machine washing on cold, and hang drying. They do absorb a little bit of sweat every week, so this is necessary. Other than that they are perfect, and highly recommended.

Coffee is one of the most difficult items to review; ask 5 people what makes good coffee and you'll get 5 different answers, and 5 different descriptions of the same cup. To offer a well known point of comparison, I would describe Starbucks' Pike Place roast as a medium/dark roast that has a strong flavor, is smooth, non-acidic, and minimally bitter. I'd describe Peet's regular similarly, albeit slightly stronger. I enjoy even stronger flavored coffee, but would describe such as extra-strong/bold.I like strong flavored coffee, with bold/full body, without bitter or burned taste, and usually drink it black. I drink decaf just as frequently as regular/caffinated, and expect there to be no difference in flavor between the two. I am always looking for new and interesting sources of coffee (my version of micro-brew beer?), and found the history of Community Coffee interesting.Unfortunately, the coffee doesn't hold up to the promise. Although smooth, I would describe the flavor as weak at best (watery at worst), with little body or aroma. I tried adjusting the grind, and brewing it extra strong (3 scoops for 1 cup) willing to accept an increase in acidity for increased flavor. Although there was little increase in acidity, there was also little increase in strength; it didn't make a notable difference. It is possible that I had a bad batch, but I had the same problem with Community Coffee Whole Bean Coffee, Cafe Special Decaffeinated, 12-Ounce Bags (Pack of 3).Although the Community Coffee half-caff didn't fit my needs, those who like lighter/mild coffee without acidity or aftertaste, may find it to their liking.

Amy Lane's writing can roughly be divided into longer, more serious and more emotionally involved novels, (ex. Dex in Blue or Sidecar), and shorter, lighter novellas, often with a bit of a suspense plot thrown in, (ex. Turkey in the Snow or Knitter in His Natural Habitat (Knitting Series)). (She also writes in genres other than contemporary.) Both groups of books are good in their own right, although I tend to prefer the former.Left on St. Truth Be Well is novella length, and unfortunately, although  has a great deal of promise- a strange and interesting setting, a funny character, and an engaging mystery- it doesn't come close to meeting it. The dialogue is smart and funny at times, but rushed, inconsistent, and confusing at others. The mystery is given little attention; although the mystery being secondary is normal for Lane's shorter books, it should be woven throughout the plot, not brought out, or ignored, when convenient. The pacing is inconsistent, both in the plot and in the prose. Overall, the book reads like a first draft of something really promising that needs some strong editing.Amy Lane is capable of so much more, and if this is your first time reading her work, try one of the other books linked above before you give up. They are more than worth it.

Think Thin Brownie Crunch Bar-Taste/texture:On the first bite it seemed powdery, but it quickly became smooth and had a pretty good taste; although taste is all relative, so certainly don't expect a great chocolate bar.Ingredients:There are lots of "health" bars out there from big named companies that are known for "health" food that have trans-fat and unhealthy oils in them; having read all the ingredients in Think Thin I don't see any such oils (ex. palm oil, etc.).There are in Think Thin, as in every food (except maybe for those you grow yourself), ingredients I am not knowledgeable about, for example "Maltitol". Although I did look those ingredients up online, and there were no red flags. Bottom line, in comparison to other protein bars the Think Thin is healthy. (Cliff Bars are other protein bar I have found with no bad oils etc. that are also reasonably priced.)Protein, Fiber, Calorie content:Protein is very high: 20g per bar (vs. Cliff bar- 9g)Fiber is ok: 2g (vs. Cliff bar- 4g)Calories: 230 per bar (vs. Cliff 250)Price-Cliff bars are often sold for ~$0.99. The Think Thin bars are usually more expensive, averaging $1.50-$1.70 per bar.

Update- 8/15/14After approximately a year of very light use (2-3 hours a day once a week or less frequently), the sensor that determines whether the bucket is full has broken and the dehumifier is completely non-functional. Because the machine thinks the bucket is full, the extractor/dehumidifier function won't work.Original review- 4 starsThe Friedrich D50BP 50 pint dehumidifier hits all of the major comparison points that I look for--It is constructed of sturdy plastic and seems well made.-It weighs approximately 40 lbs, but has wheels on the bottom that make it easily maneuverable.-It has a large water capacity.-It has an automatic draining feature, and comes with its own hose.-It has digital controls, which are bright and easy to see, and the buttons work well.  The controls/display include current humidity and temperature, and a timer.  It is possible to set the unit to maintain a specific humidity level (between 30-90%), or set the timer for a specific length of time.  I have had other dehumidifiers that also allow control of fan speed. It's not a feature that I thought made a big difference, but it might impact noise levels, so if that is a concern, it's something to think about.-The noise level is standard for this size dehumidifier. (Although I am using the unit in a basement; I'm not sure I'd want the noise in a living area, but I don't think I've ever had a dehumidifier quiet enough that it wouldn't bother me in a living area.)-It is an energy star model.I have two complaints about this dehumidifier--The drawer can be difficult to slide in and out; although not the worst I've ever used, it's not the best, and when it's holding 16 pints you want the process to be as smooth as possible.-The timer is a one-time setting. I.e. It cannot be set to come on at a certain time every day. However, this seems to be fairly standard in every dehumidifier I've seen recently.Overall a solid dehumidifier; although it doesn't stand out in any way, I haven't had any problems with it after more than a month of use.Note- Some reviewers have noted a problem with the unit shutting on and off when the unit is set to maintain a specific humidity level. I normally use the timer setting, so haven't encountered this problem. I did an hour test and didn't experience any problems, but if it occurs in the future I will update the review.

I accidentally came across this title on Amazon and decided to pick it up about a month ago. I had forgotten that I had it until I was on vacation in Los Angeles last week and it showed up on my Kindle. I wound up reading it in 2 days under an umbrella at the Malibu Beach Inn then by chance met some friends for a late night bite at the Polo Lounge.  I started to wonder so I thought Id see who I could find that would fit the descriptions in the book.  I couldnt help grinning like an idiot when a Maitre d named Mr. P showed me to my table by the bar, and I think Shakil was my server. I was seated at table 25 where the newscaster Rob Kovacik had his lip split open by a crazed Lisa Vanderpump fan. Although my waiters name wasnt really Shakil the description fit very well.  He even managed to mess up my dates order, a Pellegrino with lemon -- Shakil served lime.  Ha! Where was Pauli when I needed him?It really was so cool sitting there and remembering the details of the story as they were so fresh in my mind from just finishing the book. I felt like I knew the place from the inside out. As I looked around I saw the bartender and the barstools where some poor woman had shat herself, and the musician who was performing was the same man Pauli had described in the book.  He was playing his guitar, singing and blowing into a harmonica whilst playing bass with his feet -- simply amazing and all with fluidity and great pizazz. The story of Waiter to the Rich and Shameless came alive for me right before my very own eyes.I will not forget my visit to Los Angeles, and Paul thanks for being my tour-guide in Beverly Hills, your book topped off a great vacation.
