Mix six drops of lavender with a cup of white vinegar and use as a liquid fabric softener during your wash cycle.Additionally, I make many of my own cleaning products and an all-purpose cleaner infused with lavender oil makes the bathroom smell like a spa! To use, just mix one part water with one part vinegar and add the lavender a drop at a time until its scented to your liking. About a dozen drops will do you, so a 4 fl. oz. bottle should last for quite some time.Morning Pep bottles its essential oils in amber glass, to better keep out the sun. My order was shipped in double layers of bubble wrap for added protection.

(Full disclosure: I received a free product in exchange for an honest review.)Ive been using Brainwavz brand headphones for a while now, and am always struck by their construction, performance, and durability. Like all Brainwavs headphones, the M1 model comes with a range of different tips (S-Series foam tips; silicone ear tips in small, medium, and large; and silicone bi-flange tips), as well as a shirt clip and an attractive, black and red, hard carrying case. Ive found the cases surprisingly useful  not only are they great for travel, but when used for everyday storage, they keep my headphones organized and tangle-free.As for overall design, my favorite Brainwavz headphones have flat cords (similar in shape to a tape measure) for a truly tangle-free experience. The M1s have a silver-plated braided cable  more resistant to tangling than a traditional cord, but not quite as good as the flat design. They loop over the ear and can take a little getting used to; while those with larger ears might appreciate the flexibility, I prefer a more rigid (and stable) earpiece.I mostly use these with my iPod, usually while listening to audiobooks (currently up: Tana Frenchs THE SECRET PLACE). The sound is crisp, clear, and balanced. My favored alternative rock and folk rock sound wonderful too.These ear phones are low profile, with a sleek black and silver color scheme. You might not even notice someone wearing them on the street.

(Full disclosure: I received a free product in exchange for an honest review. This review is for the PINK PET BRUSH, not the Blue Grooming Tool Set.)I have five rescue dogs and also foster, so Ive owned my share of grooming supplies over the years. Since my dogs are all short- to medium-haired (rat terrier/fox terrier/Jack Russell terrier mixes), I usually stick to combs over brushes (shaking some of the loose fur off with my hands before I start); this is my first time using a rake.  In fact, prior to writing this review, Id never heard of a Furminator, but the Flatworld Rake looks to be a more affordable version of it.The first thing I noticed about the rake is how short the teeth are  less than half as long as those on my current comb. Thus, the brush fills with hair much more quickly, necessitating in more frequent stops. (Not a big deal, unless your dog hates to be brushed and tries to use the distraction for escape. Jayne, Im looking at you!) However, the rake does an excellent job of gathering shed and loose hair. All in all, it seems to remove a greater volume of fur than a traditional comb.I even noticed an improvement on Mags and Finnick, who have very short hair and dont shed a whole lot. Whereas I brush the other dogs once or twice a week (even more during peak shedding season), I usually skip those two altogether; there just doesnt seem to be a point, unless theyre obviously dirty or have gotten something stuck on their fur. So imagine my surprise when I tested the Flatworld rake on Mags and actually came away with a small hairball! (For her part, Mags was less than amused.)Ill probably work the Flatworld rake into my regular routine going forward, perhaps starting with it and ending with a comb. The design isnt terribly flashy and the package is written in broken English, but my dogs dont care and neither do I. The package seems to indicate that it comes in different sizes (50, 66, and 100mm), but I cant seem to find any others online.

(Full disclosure: I received a free copy of this book for review through Blogging for Books.)GO AHEAD & LIKE IT is not at all what I expected. Granted, based on the books vague and weirdly broad Amazon description, its difficult to pin down precisely; in one breath, it purports to be a scrapbook, art book, self-help book, how-to guide, etc., etc., etc. So perhaps its unfair to dislike it for failing to meet my already hazy expectations. But. When the description says that it features writing prompts, I dont think it unreasonable to assume that the book will also include blank space for me to work on said prompts. Not so much.GO AHEAD & LIKE IT isnt an interactive journal or workbook, with space for the reader to formulate her own lists, but rather an instructional guide, the bulk of which highlights Suskins own lists, photographs, and ephemera. The end result feels remarkably self-indulgent: Suskin fans aside, who wants to shell out seventeen bucks to read an assortment of a strangers random lists?What we have here is a case of good idea, poor execution: this book would have been 100% better had Suskin complemented her writing tips with one or two of her own lists (and perhaps a plethora of artwork with liberal white space), and then given her readers ample space to record their own. Theres one blank list at the very back of the book, but thats it.To add insult to injury, Suskin includes in her lists things which I find morally repugnant: hunting, fishing, and fetishizing the bodies of dead animals. One list sports this cryptic entry: disorders. I can only hope the author isnt referring to physical and/or mental disorders (the romanticization of which is entirely uncool).After skimming through GO AHEAD & LIKE IT, my knee-jerk reaction was to give it one star. But, upon a full read-through, I have to admit that some of Suskins advice is rather intriguing and evocative. Just not to the tune of $16.99. Wait for it to go on deep discount, or else just save yourself the time and Google gratitude lists.Buy it if: You want a Post-Secret style art book.Skip it if: Youre hoping for an interactive journal or workbook thats all about *you*.

My hope is that we can navigate through this world and our lives with the grace and integrity of those who need our protection. May we have the sense of humor and liveliness of the goats; may we have the maternal instincts and protective nature of the hens and the sassiness of the roosters. May we have the gentleness and strength of the cattle, and the wisdom, humility, and serenity of the donkeys. May we appreciate the need for community as do the sheep and choose our companions as carefully as do the rabbits. May we have the faithfulness and commitment to family as the geese, and adaptability and affability of the ducks. May we have the intelligence, loyalty, and affection of the pigs and the inquisitiveness, sensitivity, and playfulness of the turkeys.My hope is that we learn from the animals what it is we need to become better people.With no fewer than four cookbooks under her belt  THE 30-DAY VEGAN CHALLENGE, THE VEGAN TABLE, COLOR ME VEGAN, and THE JOY OF VEGAN BAKING, which is destined to become a classic  many of you may know Colleen Patrick-Goudreau as an accomplished vegan chef. But shes also got a masters degree in English Literature, which she puts to use as a writer and public speaker, educating the public about compassionate living and animal rights. Her exploration of the intersections between human and animal exploitation, both on the Food for Thought podcast and various short videos released on YouTube, are among my favorites.In VEGANS DAILY COMPANION, the self-described Joyful Vegan brings all her talents and avenues of interest together to create a book as unique as it is informative. Part cookbook, part self-help book, part pop culture guide, VEGANS DAILY COMPANION offers 365 days of inspiration, knowledge, and celebration to vegans, both new and experienced. From Monday through Sunday (with the weekends sharing a recipe), each day youll find a short discussion or series of tips, each tailored to a specific theme:Monday / For the Love of Food  A celebration of familiar as well as new foods to spark enthusiasm for eating healthfully.Each Monday, Patrick-Goudreau delves deep to reveal things you may not know about your favorite foods  and introduce you to some foods you might have written off completely. For example, Day 99 includes some handy tips for cooking beans from scratch (salt and acidic ingredients should be added last, since they hinder the cooking of the beans). And Day 57 gives you a handy chart for cooking grains.Also, arugula is another name for rocket! All these years tagging rocket pizzas on f*** yeah vegan pizza, and I had no idea![Insert the more you know and shooting star gif here.]Sometimes the featured food ties into a recipe featured on an adjacent weekend; more often times not. Either way, this intermediate cook found many of the tips quite handy.Tuesday / Compassionate Communication  Techniques and tactics for speaking on behalf of veganism effectively and compassionately.Similar to Joan Dunayers ANIMAL EQUALITY: LANGUAGE AND LIBERATION (call it the Cliffs Notes), Compassionate Communication explores the roots of popular terminology, offering alternatives to those promote animal exploitation, whether intentionally or not. While its time to ditch animal-unfriendly phrases like dont look a gift horse in the mouth, let the cat out of the bag, and fat pig (in what is perhaps my favorite quote in the book, Patrick-Goudreau counters this insult thusly: Theyre not fat pigs; were mad scientists.), you might be surprised, as was I, at the seemingly harmful sayings that are either sympathetic to animal suffering (an albatross around ones neck), or have nothing at all to do with nonhuman animals (more than one way to skin a cat).Compassionate Communication also offers answers to the many inane questions vegans will inevitably face (If we stop eating animals, wont cows take over the world?; What about the bugs killed in crop production?; Why do you want plants to suffer?), as well as tips for responding to them honestly, with grace and humor.Wednesday / Optimum Health for Body, Mind, and Spirit  Care and maintenance for becoming and remaining a joyful vegan.Wednesday is a bit of a mixed bag, spanning nutrition, burnout, and self-care. I especially love Patrick-Goudreaus tips for creating a gratitude list, finding peace in nature and solitude, and visiting animal sanctuaries as a sort of holy place.Thursday / Animals in the Arts: Literature and Film  Inspiration across the ages that reflects our consciousness of and relationship with nonhuman animals.Here youll find a remarkably diverse and extensive look at animal-friendly films, novels, poetry, and art. While I recognized a few titles (PLAGUE DOGS chief among them), Patrick-Goudreau grew my reading list and Netflix queue in leaps and bounds. Books and films run the gamut, from poets William Cowper and Walt Whitman, to author-activist (and mother of Mary Shelley, also featured here) Mary Wollstonecraft Goodwin, to the 1977 student film KILLER OF SHEEP  and of course that one episode of THE TWILIGHT ZONE (To Serve Man).Items high up on my radar include: Shad Clarks short story Little Boy Pig, currently free for download on Amazon; a 1973 French science fiction film called THE SAVAGE PLANET; James Agees A Mothers Tale; the Italian film UMBERTO D.; and Hayao Miyazakis PRINCESS MONONOKE.However, be warned: since many of these works address cruelty towards animals, things can get rather depressing at times.Friday / Stories of Hope, Rescue, and Transformation  Heartening stories of people who have become awakened and animals who have found sanctuary.Stories celebrates the deliverance of animals  both humans and non. Regular folks  like Itai in Tel Aviv, or Linda in San Fracisco  share their journeys to veganism in short essay format. Likewise, those who have cared for rescued animals  turkeys, burros, pigs, and chimpanzees  give voice to their exploitation, liberation, and (hopefully) eventual transformation. No doubt youll recognize many of the sanctuaries and rescue groups that helped with this project: Animal Place, Rolling Dog Ranch, Farm Sanctuary, Animals Asia, Cleveland Armory Black Beauty Ranch, Performing Animal Welfare Society, and the Sanaga-Yong Chimpanzee Rescue Center, to name a few.The personal submissions introduce an interesting element to Vegans Daily Companion, since the authors are occasionally guilty of partaking in behaviors that the author herself warns against. For instance, one contributor uses the word nag as a pejorative; a nag, of course, is one who complains a lot or makes excessive demands. A nag is also an old, inferior, or worthless horse.So, yeah. Perhaps the personal essays could have been vetted a little better? Or maybe Im just biased, since Id rather read about a cow over a person any day of the week. (I kid, but not really.)Saturday + Sunday / Healthful Recipes  Favorite recipes to use as activism and nourishment.Saturday and Sunday share an entry, which is a recipe. Many are reprints from Patrick-Goudreaus previous cookbooks  THE VEGAN TABLE, COLOR ME VEGAN, and THE JOY OF VEGAN BAKIN  so if you already own one or all three, you might be a little disappointed. But there are also a few friend/follower contributions in the mix, including a Lentil Bolognese dish I just loved.So far Ive also tried the Cream of Mushroom Soup, courtesy of Compassionate Cooks member Melissa Phillips.This was my first time drinking mushrooms in a semi-liquid form, and I was not entirely fond of the experience. My husband was a big fan though.The recipes are all over the place: salads, entrees, desserts, snacks, and breakfasts  all get a little face time.I kind of like that Saturday and Sunday share a recipe; if you read this book chronologically and in time, two days should give you plenty of time to shop for and master a recipe. And if you commit to working through the entirety of VEGANS DAILY COMPANION  recipes included, no matter what they may be  the project just might challenge you to try new foods and dishes that you might not otherwise.(Me? Im too impatient to read a page a day. I usually read a week or two per sitting.)On the downside, I kind of wish there was a dedicated recipe index for easy skimming. Recipes are listed by title and ingredients in the main index, but one big, separate list would be even handier.Overall, I quite enjoyed VEGANS DAILY COMPANION. While I could do without some of the New Age woo-woo (manifesting  thats similar to The Secret, right?), Patrick-Goudreau thankfully keeps it to a minimum. As a longtime vegan, I still learned quite a bit  especially when it comes to tips and tricks for preparing various foods. I especially enjoyed Patrick-Goudreaus knowledge of popular culture, and the many lovely animal rescue stories.Id say that VEGANS DAILY COMPANION would make the perfect gift for a vegan friend whos feeling down or at risk of experiencing burnout, except that its not entirely free of scenes of animal cruelty and abuse. The Animals in the Arts section in particular comes with a trigger warning. That said, its still a wonderful inspirational/how-to guide for newbie and old timer vegans alike.Buy it with: THE DAILY VEGAN: A GUIDED JOURNAL, adapted from VEGANS DAILY COMPANION, and/or one of the authors vegan cookbooks, for a shiny little gift set.

(Full disclosure: I received a free copy of this book for review from the publisher. Trigger warning for rape and violence.)Somehow this ruthless city is home to my sister. Where for me, it will never, ever be more than a cage.If no ones out there, then whats keeping us in?Sisters Skyler and Phoenix Miller were born and raised in Manhattan; from the wild forests of Central Park to the gleaming glass apartments in Battery Park, the island is the only home theyve ever known. But their home is also their prison. Along with several hundred fellow survivors, Sky and Phee are prisoners of war: World War III, in which the Red Allies (China, North Korea, and Russia) simultaneously attacked New York City, Washington, D.C., Los Angeles, and San Francisco, with the ultimate goal of conquering the United States. That was more than sixteen years ago, in March of 2016, and still the war rages on.When Manhattan was first attacked, a lucky few survivors found safety in the subway tunnels  including their mother, Sarah. But as the months dragged on and supplies dwindled, many of the refugees were forced to the surface, to beg the Red Allies for mercy. Though most of the men were shot on sight, the women and children were imprisoned in cages once meant for lions and tigers: the Central Park Zoo, now transformed into an internment camp.Eventually a leader emerged in the form of Rolladin, who persuaded their captors to move them to the relative comfort of the Carlyle Hotel. As the war dragged on and the soldiers combed the wreckage of NYC for holdouts  tunnel feeders and raiders  the POW camp grew. Eventually, when the Red Allies withdrew to follow the war west, Rolladin and her whorelords  warlords recruited from the prison population  were left in charge, to manage this oasis in the middle of a war zone. While no doubt an improvement over enemy occupation, Rolladin is an unyielding and oftentimes cruel warden, seemingly drunk on power. And yet she has a strange and inexplicable affinity for the Miller family.The story is told from the alternating perspectives of Sky and Phee: Sky, the older, more delicate and bookish sister, who dreams of worlds far away; and Phee, an impulsive, tough-as-nails scrapper who cannot imagine living anywhere else. When the Camps relative calm is disrupted by the arrival of four mysterious strangers, the sisters must work together to uncover the truth about the islands past, present, and future  a truth thats tangled up in their mothers past, which she keeps so closely guarded. (Luckily, Sky discovers and steals her journal, so were blessed with Sarahs voice as well!)But thats only the first half of the story. Their journey carries them all over the island; theyre pursued on the surface by Rolladin and her warlords, and hunted through the tunnels by cannibals gone mad with hunger and darkness; crushed under one dictators thumb, only to find themselves in the clutches of a creepy cult leader. Just when they  and we  think it cant get any worse, it does. Its a wild ride with a true Godzilla vs. Mothra ending. (As in SPN episode 4.10:DEAN: I got to hand it to you, Sammy. Bringing them all together all at once  angels and demons. It was a damn good plan.SAM: Yeah, well, when you got Godzilla and Mothra on youre a**, best to get out of their way and let them fight.)CITY OF SAVAGES has more of a YA feel than I expected (given the brutal title and description), but thats not a bad thing. I loved the sibling rivalry between Sky and Phee, two very different young women who share an unbreakable bond despite their dissimilarities; as the oldest of four kids, I can definitely relate. Delicate, inquisitive, and classically beautiful, in the world Before, Sky might have been a model or a writer  whereas Phee, with her big mouth and bigger fists, was all but made for this new, savage world. The juxtaposition of these opposing traits  old vs. new, then vs. now  in siblings so close theyre practically two halves of a whole is intriguing; I cant help but wonder where each girl might be had WWIII somehow been avoided.But. Once Kelly adds Ryder to the equation, things get a little annoying. Its not so much the sisters competing over a guy that bothers me  but when youre prioritizing romance over escape from a psychopath who murders and rapes in the name of G-O-D, then yeah. Thats a little over the top ridiculous.Though there doesnt seem to be much racial diversity in CITY OF SAVAGES, theres a marvelous plot line wherein the girls mom, Sarah, falls in love with her husbands sister, Mary. The two were taking Sky to the zoo when the war broke out; subsequently, they were trapped underground for seven months, during which time Mary cared for this little family. While she never knew her father, Sky is outraged on his behalf upon reading about the affair in Sarahs journal; Phee, on the other hand, adopts a more pragmatic approach  basically, its not cheating if you think hes dead. This might be the only time I took Phees side in the whole book.(To quote one of my status updates: Phees a bit of a s***, isnt she? Older sister talking.)Kellys world building is wonderful as well: from the farms in Central Park to the tiny wilderness that blossoms along the Hudson River to the use of the zoo as an internment camp/prison, she paints a world rich and vivid with detail. While I was able to correctly guess at some of the plot twists (Sarah + Mary; The Standard), others came as a complete shock (the exact nature of the relationship between Rolladin and the Millers; I thought that Phee might be Rolladins daughter, perhaps with Tom).Some of the language rubbed me the wrong way, though. For example, the word bully pops up with weird frequency, usually to describe behavior thats far beyond bullying: rape, torture, war crimes.And the story wraps up with a page from Sarahs journal, now in Sky and Phees possession licitly: I will give them a chance at a real life in this city thats been raped and left for dead. Nope. No. No thank you. Just no.A city is an insentient object  a collection of bricks and concrete and cable wires and trees  and as such cannot be raped. Its citizens can be raped, sure; and many of them were, including Sarah. (Many, but not all, which also disqualifies the use of city as shorthand for every person therein.) But lets not minimize their experiences by misusing the term in such a way that promotes rape culture, okay?Things that are rape: Rape.Things that are not rape: War. Bombing. Internment. Cannibalism. Murder. Logging. Habitat loss. Pollution. Taxes. Losing in a video game. Getting an F on a test. Someone bogarting your weed. You get the idea.

(Full disclosure: I received a free product in exchange for an honest review.)This set of cat tunnels by PetMagasin contains two collapsible tunnels. While both are 10 in diameter, ones about twice as long as the other: 35 versus 18. They ship flat, crushed into a pancake-like shape. The longer of the two pops right into shape as you unfasten the three clips holding it down (the tension is surprisingly high, so be on your toes!); the smaller tunnel requires a little pulling and primping.Both are super-lightweight and easy to store, and make a fun crinkling sound when your cat bats, swats, or moves around in it. Several times I heard a commotion from the next room and assumed that Lemmy had someone managed to get a hold of a plastic bag  the sound is very similar.  Each tunnel has a cat toy dangling in the opening, and the longer tunnel has a little peep hole situated in the middle.My cat took to them immediately, showing a clear preference for the longer tunnel. Hes not terribly large  thirteen pounds, tops  and theres plenty of extra room for him to move around. I think that some of my smaller dogs could even fit inside if they wanted to, but so far theyve only proven mildly curious.  Lemmy makes a game out of hiding  behind the couch, under his lounge, around corners  and swiping at the dogs as they pass by. Hes already figured out that the tunnels are excellent for this, at least until everyone else catches on.The colors are bright and bold and reminiscent of a carnival tent, which is kind of fun. They also stand readily on their ends, which makes cleaning around them a snap. And while its a little too soon to tell for sure  peak shedding season is still a few months away  the material doesnt seem to attract and hold fur too readily.

(Full disclosure: I received a free electronic ARC for review through NetGalley. Trigger warning for rape and violence.)I was sixteen years old, and there was something gone wrong with me. I was sixteen, and I hadnt grown right, and all my friends were no longer my friends, and instead I had people I bit and who bit back. I had a beautiful, sad father and an angry drunken man who saw me as the reincarnation of a perverse angel. There was a pretty young woman with an affection for my father who picked out jewelry for me because my mother was a fantasy told to me in a good-night stories. I was sixteen, and my name was light, and my body had been bloodied and torn and repaired. I did well in school. I drew maps. I wondered what my life would become  I tried to picture it. I was sixteen, and I was an animal. I was the wrong kind of animal.Today, Lumen Ann Fowler is a kind and devoted wife and stay-at-home mom. She brings her husband lunch at school, oversees her sons play groups, attends community improvement meetings. She goes by the name of Ann Borden (maiden name Ann Fowler). Though shes tried to leave her past in the past, she still feels the pull of a full moon, and the siren call of a dark, deserted night. On these sleepless nights, she writes: a memoir, addressed to no one and everyone, about when she ran wild  sort of  through the streets of Polikwakanda.Whether due to pollution, the unique positioning of the moon, or a punishment handed down by Satan himself, Pale Miranda is home to a strange and sinister custom: For one year (give or take), starting at puberty, the kids breach  they run wild under the full moon. They fight, they f***, they raise hell. Adults and children stay inside for their own safety; residents of surrounding towns know to steer clear of this cursed town. Breaching is a dirty and dangerous custom  yet an essential one, for only when kids breach do they grow into healthy and well-adjusted adults.Young Lumen Fowler  conscientious student, loyal friend, daddys girl  is convinced that she will never breach. Her late mother didnt, you see, and surely these things are carried in the blood? For a long while, Lumens underdeveloped body seems to be cooperating, both to her and her fathers relief. But as she watches all of her classmates breach, one by one, only to be left behind and set apart, Lumen tires of being the good girl: innocent, childlike, virginal.When she finally breaches at sixteen, its both a relief and a curse: even as she embraces the animal inside her, Lumens solitude and self-loathing continue to isolate her from her peers; meanwhile, her baser instincts threaten to consume her. As she researches the phenomenon of breaching and delves into her mothers mythos, Lumens world threatens to split apart.Every male author who laments that women are too strange and unknowable  too alien  to write convincingly needs to read WHEN WE WERE ANIMALS. Like yesterday. This is how its done, people.Gaylord has written one of the most unusual and compelling coming-of-age stories Ive ever had the pleasure of reading (plus its an interesting spin on the werewolf genre). Lumen is a complex, engaging, and conflicted protagonist; her adolescent angst (minus all the sanctioned violence) is something that many girls and women, myself included, can identify with. The self-loathing and shame especially hit home. I also had (have, present tense) a strained relationship with my father (though it began well before my teen years); Gaylords portrayal of a single father trying to raise a teen girl alone is poignant and spot-on, and gave rise to some of the most heartrending passages in the book. To wit:I thought he would tell me he loved me, but I hadnt heard that from him in a long time. When I was a little girl, he would say it routinely. He seemed compelled to say it. But the declaration had gone the way of tall tale and myth.As though the love between a father and daughter were only a childish thing. As though womanhood made obscene that which had previously been precious and perfect.And so did we all fall  and in such a way were a million Edens lost.I get more than a little choked up every time I read that.I hesitate to say much more, both because I dont want to spoil the story  and also, Im still not 100% sure what I just read. Especially disturbing is the narrators marriage of sex and violence, love and hate, depravity and purity; then again, I think were meant to be discomforted by Lumen, just as she seems to be afraid and agitated by herself  her physical body, her innermost thoughts and desires, the very essence of who she is, or thinks she is, or fears herself to be.WHEN WE WERE ANIMALS is all but screaming for a feminist analysis; even as we see Lumen forgiving Peter for a near-rape (which never comes to pass because Lumen is too good to rape), we also have wonderful gems like this, which cut right to the heart of the virgin-whore complex: My virginity, my saintliness, like the new snow you hate yourself for tromping on. And: Im like the thing you worship. The thing you put on a shelf and dust every week. Dont take Lumen down from her shelf  youre liable to get your fingerprints all over her.Or how society places the onus on its girls to make sure boys dont take things too far: I was the good girl. The girl being groped and salivated upon in the den of her own home was the good girl. You were safe with her, because she didnt allow anything to get out of control.Its a wonderful, disquieting, sometimes vulgar exploration of adolescence and sexuality; the hazards of living on the margins; relationships between fathers and daughters, educators and students, young men and young women, friends and peers; the insularity of small rural communities; humankinds relationship with nature; and the monsters we face in the dark  including the darkness that dwells within us.WHEN WE WERE ANIMALS is also surprisingly, delightfully nerdy, what with its scholar-mapmaker-junior researcher narrator and her geologist father (an engineering geologist  a person who knew how to harmonize man and nature.). As animalistic as she may be, Lumen loves learning  and she puts her thirst for knowledge to use at every turn. (Yeah, Blackhat Roy and all those f****** books fractured my heart just a bit.)Also  and last does not equal least  Gaylord possesses an uncanny knack for foreshadowing, particularly at the eleventh hour. On more than one occasion I caught a hint mere sentences before its meaning was revealed. Now thats how you keep your readers on their toes, okay. Ditto: the ending, which I didnt see coming. At all.4.5 stars, rounded down to 4 where necessary.

I tried this backpack for two weeks in order to test out its two main use cases -- as a brief case and as a travel case.  This is one nice piece of baggage.  It is stylish and functional.  But its not the only piece you will need.  Rather it is a part of a portfolio of luggage.  Here is what I mean.The backpack is intelligently laid out for work use. It has a great place to store a PC and special sleeve that is ideal for a tablet/iPad.  The front pockets are great for holding pens and other materials.  It fits well under an airline seat.  The design includes a back zipper giving easy access to both the computer storage area and the main storage area.  When there is nothing in the main storage area, the bag feels large.  It collapses easily and does not keep its shape.  It is a little too big for everyday use when there is nothing in the open pack storage part of pack.The backpack's real strength is as a backpack, more than a substitute for a brief case.  The storage area is large, well lined and easy to access with a heavy duty zipper that goes across the top and down the side.  The roll-top increases its flexibility and style.  The storage capacity is big enough to hold what is needed for an overnight trip, a little tight if you pack a pair of shoes.  This is not a field pack, there are no places for water bottles and attachments that are normally found in a back pack.So this fits somewhere in the middle.  Recommended if you work takes you on overnight trips and you are looking to collapse your luggage into a single bag.  That is where the real strengths seem to be.  So travel effortlessly in style with the Alpha Bravo

The boogie board is one of the best writing experiences on an electrical device that I have had in a long time.  I wish my tablet wrote this well.  However, the fact that I cannot save or send that writing anywhere is a limitation.  If you are looking for an electronic scratch pad that you will use one at a time then this is good.  However if you want to keep a running list of things where they go in and go out, then the boogie board has limitations.It is lightweight, great price point, well designed and even comes with magnates to put it onto the 'fridge or other metal service.  I recommend looking at the scraps of paper and lists you keep now.  If you find yourself transfering lists onto clean sheets of paper, then the boogie board may be a good solution.  If you are scratching, adding, managing multiple notes and post its, then the boogie board will probably not fit your style.

Every generation has their version of a recovering from tragedy movie.  The skeleton twins is the current version of this theme.  Think of two broken people, there crisis, shared history and resolution.This is not an uplifting movie but an interesting character study that you should be prepared for before watching.The acting is very good. Hader and wigg are good and touch their serious subject areas just the right touch.Not a date movie. Not a movie for when you need a lift. But when you want to experience and think then this is recommended.

Being a large guy finding good casual clothes is challenging.  The Oxford NY Henley seems like it will fit the bill both literally and figuratively.  Overall its OK, by that I mean that its a casual shirt, but it is not near as nice or as well fitting as offerings from the traditional retailers like Eddie Bauer or LL Bean.Overall the XX-Large size is for people who are large around the middle not necessarily tall, more like Barney Rubble than Fred Flintstone.  So if you are taller than 6 food I would pass on the shirt.  The material, while attractive, is surprisingly thin and light passes easily through the weave so I imagine it will not be durable or provide even minor warmth normally associated with a Waffle pull over.  These may be ok in smaller sizes but for a big and tall size they telegraph that this is a shirt I may be able to wear once or twice before it becomes too stretched out or simply loses its shape.The Henley pattern is common enough and the style is classic, my suggestion is to look for this type of shirt where they provide sizes that include big and tall.

I have been looking for an effective stylus ever since I purchased my first iPad mainly for note taking and to replace a paper notebook. This is the best of the different products I have tried to date, but its still not there.  First the good points about the product.Form factor -- closest to a pen or pencil which makes it easy to use.  Other blue tooth stylus's were thicker more like a sharpie marker than a real pen.  The USB charger in the end is a plus as is the cap on the stylus making it easier toLine drawing -- good with a fine tip point and pressure sensitivity.Battery life appears goodNow for some of the challenges:Works with a limited number of applications, so if you are already taking notes or drawings in some areas you will not have blue tooth connectivity.The latency and drawing separation issues remain, no one has solved this one yet, but it makes writing with a stylus not as effective as pen and paper.If you already draw with a stylus and are looking for one that is more like a pencil or pen, then this is a good choice.

This set fits in the space between high end expensive jeweler and the costume stuff that you just throw on.  Perfect for the office, dinners and anywhere where you want to look more together than casual.  The bracelets are good weight with attractive rose gold color.  These are things you can wear independently of the watch.  Unfortunately the same does not apply to the watch.  It is rather plain outside of the face and not well suited to wearing alone.Overall a great gift, nice but not too pricey and sure to make a positive impression.  Really pleased with the product, its quality as well as its looks.  Recommended.

We are not college students, but this caddie has helped organize and improve the functionality of the space under our bathroom sink.  Its recommended if you have a sink area filled with different sized bottles, tools and other items that quickly become a tumbling mess whenever you go to get something.  The caddie is flexible enough to hold bottles and items of multiple shapes and sizes, yet strong enough to hold its own against heavier items stored under the sink.  They all become accessible with a single handle and are easy to put away as well.Overall if you have a mess under the balthroom or even kitchen sink, then this can help.  BTW we also think that it could be a great caddie for things like garden tools -- the mess keeping the dirt where it belongs.

Shower curtains are shower curtains so there is not much to review.  Basically this curtain has a nice color, pattern and is very functional.  We are using it in a unisex bathroom with neutral decorations and it works perfect.  If you are looking to re-energize your bathroom and keep it neutral but not neutered, then this curtain and the others should be considered.

If you have normal sized feet, then the Diamondback is a reasonable choice.  The upper on this shoe is almost as stiff as the sole, making it difficult to wear if you have a "fat" or large foot.  I wear a 14 and had to return the largest size as there was no give in the upper to put them one.The sole is built like a stiff sneaker, good treads and could provide somewhat comfortable walking but the overall stiffness of both the top and bottom is a real issue.

OK I have a big foot and ordered the size 49 shoe.  We just came back from a week of bike touring riding about 50 miles a day and touring museums, etc along the way.  These shoes were very comfortable and worked great while peddling or walking.  The upper is made of the same kind of material as scuba suits with a lot of give to fit big feet.  The bottom is solid, with rubber sole treads that work well for gripping a pedal -- i did not get clips at this time.  They were also reasonably comfortable and provided good footing when walking.The soles are solid, as one would expect.  They run a little narrow so you have some little toe over the edge when riding, but not too much to make it a drag.Overall recommended for those looking for a good bike shoe but have big feet.

Bike Jersey's in general run small but this one seems to run particularly small.  I ordered the largest size, a size that works with other manufacturers and this one was not even close.  It is a well made jersey.  The colors and materials seem great and I really hated that it did not fit as it would be both a fun and functional part of my biking ensemble.If you are normal sized, order at least one size up.  If you are above and XL, then consider that this will not fit.BTW the return process was fine, although paying for return postage was a bit of a drag.

No battery will ever b.e 'good' for the environment.  Some will be less bad and the Go Green Power cells are one of those products.  Work just like regular batteries powering small devices.  Overall an interesting alternative to power all of your devices

Great for tailgating, small apartments or taking to the beach.  The grill is a little on the heavy side, but definitely portable thanks to a sturdy handle and locking design. This is more of a griddle, or frying surface than a grill per se. The fuel heats a solid surface rather than having flames lick up through traditional grill, so no 'smores or that flame blackened cooking you might be used to.  It features the Foreman tilt that draws grease away form the cooking surface.The overall design is innovative and attractive.  The bright red cover is not easy to miss and the fold out supports create sides that help protect your food from the wind and the weather. Set up and break down are a little complicated and takes some time to get used to.  The two front red circles are the key as they serve as both the stand and the locking mechanism.  The quality of the materials, thin in nature to save weight, make this a little tougher than they need to be.  The gas attachment easily connects with the overall grill surface but again needs to be accounted for when using.  It would have been nice if it came with a case or way to store a fuel cylinder, the gas attachment and the grease catch. It is messy when you use it outdoors so be sure to bring paper towels as you will want to clean up the cooking surface in particular before folding the grill back up.  Then there is the issue of where to store a hot grill as it cools down.  This is not a problem at a picnic so much as I can see it at a tailgate where people want to eat and then go into a game.Overall, a solid and good product one that we see using more as an apartment balcony grill that we can store easily.

S'mores are one of those treats that it takes a little planning to pull off.  Too often there is chocolate but not enough marshmallows or graham crackers so it never quite comes off.  No longer with this kit, you can have s'mores at the ready. This is a great pack not only for camping and picnics but something to have in your pantry for parties, family dinners or just whenever you need a snack.  The packaging keeps all of the ingredients fresh and ready for use. I have a personal preference for more marshmallows but overall this is one of the things that has become a must add in our pantry.

Jade Dragon Mountain represents a transformation of a traditional political thriller into a new domain -- rural china.  The result is an interesting book that is very enjoyable and engaging to read.  It is one thing to write a political/crime/thriller set in the old west where we have familiarity with the genre, clothing and culture from movies and other sources.The book's political/crime structure provides a level of plot familiarity that allows the reader to concentrate on the descriptions of imperial china.  Elsa Hart provides a right details and character development to help the reader see things differently and accelerate their imagination.  This is a particular accomplishment given that most readers will have a limited understanding of rural china at imperial times.  She has accomplished this without resorting to jingoistic stereotypes or simplifications.Hart handles the complexity of imperial china from the Jesuits, to foreign travelers, to cultural issues at the time into creating a great read.  You will not become an expert on imperial China, but you will walk away learning something.

I have hand the same ACCO brand stapler for about 10 years and it finally broke, so I was in the market for something new.  When I got the original stapler it was something that sat in a drawer, used mainly for kids projects.  Now that I am working more out of a home office wanted to get something both functional and a little fancy.The Leitz Stapler fits this bill well.  It is stylish and fits nicely in your hand both hallmarks of good design. My old stapler had a spring which broke, this stapler has a tension band which is much less likely to break.  It uses industry standard staples as well as special white staples which are kind of classy.

This is a very nice piece, pretty, dainty and ornate design.  It shows very well online giving you the impression that it is a larger piece and the heart is made of thicker material.  Both are not the case.  This piece is very small, more appropriate for a pre-teen than someone older.  The metal is paper thin, more of a stamping than a crafted piece.  The chain is among the most dainty and frail in my spouse's collection. Its so thin that it will easily bend, more like disposable jewelery than the nice necklace.If you are looking for a piece to give a child, something that is ok to have for a while but may break, become lost or bent, then this is a perfectly acceptable gift.  Our daughter would have cherished this when she was 8 or 9 years old, wore it and then kept it in her jewelery box.  Outside of that situation you leave yourself open to either an underwhelming response -- oh great, or the impression that you are cutting corners in your gift giving.

My recommendation is to pass on this book as its largely filled with hype and discussions that were more appropriate in 2005 rather than 2015.  The themes of digital and disruption have moved well beyond the assertions discussed in this book.  There are much better and more relevant books to invest your time with.If you are interested in reading about the deeper economic and structural impact of digital I suggest reading The Second Machine Age.  A more academic understanding of disruption can be found in Big Bang Disruption.  Treatments of digital in a particular industry, The Digital Doctor in healthcare is a good example.  New ways to think about the digital economy -- Zero-to-One.The topics of the chapters appear great: transformation, trust, transparency, innovation, experience, etc, but there treatment is rather shallow and oriented more like a motivational talk rather than practitioner learning and advice.  There is little new here, particularly now that we are well into the second decade of digital.

More than a back pack and less than a frame hiking pack, this is perfect for day hiking or longer trips where you need to carry more than can fit in a traditional back pack. This is a real backpack, not a consumer version of something to sling over your shoulder.This is a hiking backpack rather than one to store stuff or use as a duffel. The capacity is great for a day long or longer hike or camping trip. The back pack is amazingly light thanks to the use of flexible plastic in its frame which also makes it flexible and easily adaptive to different body types.  The materials are strong and light weight as well providing protection for your stuff.  Simply put you can put a lot of stuff in this pack and take it wherever you need to.

McKinsey seeks to pull together all of the forces that seek to pull apart business strategies.  The result is a surprisingly flat description that rehashes past McKinsey research reports than offer a new way to look at the world and the relevance of strategic choices and investments.  The four trends are below:Trend 1: The locus of economic activity is shifting to emerging markets like China, India, Asia and AfricaTrend 2: Technology's impact on the economy is acceleratingTrend 3: Demographics, the aging of the population is shifting demandsTrend 4: Connectedness as trade, capital, people and information flow across national boardersEach trend is treated in a formulaic way, following a standard structure with slavish adherence.  You can extract the books outline which should give you and idea of the limitations of the book's story telling or information value.Overall, this book is filled with factoids and other little nuggets, many previously published by McKinsey's Global Institute.  So if you are looking for new insight, you will not find it here.  The discussions of each trend are interesting in their own ways, but the prose is rather bland and expository rather than telling an engaging story that drives understanding or action.The book's prescriptions are surprisingly simple -- mostly around do better -- rather thank do things differently.Overall not recommended if you are looking for new ideas.  It may be helpful for others to re-enforce their strategic decisions, particularly if those decisions are not too radical.

Leading Digital represents the culmination of a multi-year study of digital technologies impact on the organization.  This makes Leading Digital different, in the sense that other books on the subject either concentrate on technology hype, product innovation or disruption.  By focusing on the organizational impact of digital, Westerman, Bonnet and McAfee, create a simple, clear and compelling framework for categorizing companies and their attitudes toward digital technology.Characterizing an entire company as either a Beginner, Conservative, Fashionista or Digital Master provides an executive short hand that appears highly effective on the surface, but quickly leads one to ask, ok but what do I do?  The advices provided in the book borders not the self evident, i.e.:  beginners are slow to adapt and have the basic digital capabilities while fashionistas are buying every new digital bauble.That is one of the points holding this book back from a five star review, is that it presumes a monolytic attitude toward digital in order to simplify its messages.  This treatment is appropriate for a book intended to drive client conversations for a consulting company.The books chapters encompass the range of organizational and leadership topics related to digital transformation.  The section titles reflect this:Part 1 - building digital capabilities covers the customer experience, their link to core operations (aka legacy) and the business model.Part 2 -- focuses internally on the vision, organizational engagement, governance and technology leadership.Part 3 -- concentrates on digital transformation from strategic framing through mobilization and sustaining a change program.Taken at this level, the book is rather complete in its topical treatment but the book treats each of these topics somewhat superficially.  The case studies read like a who's who of digital transformation but they are mostly stories of success, descriptions of what worked and not a deeper examination of challenges with strategies to over come them.  Reading the case studies, of which there are many and a good thing, provides little meat for the reader to chew on.The case studies, clear and simple framework and clearly written prose are among the strengths of this book.  Among its challenges are the observation that many organizations have already moved beyond an organizational characterization into transformative action so the advice is a little dated in places.  It was revolutionary when these materials first came out almost two years ago.  The clarity of the frameworks also tends toward clear but overly simply advice and actions.  Take the 12 steps to being a digital master:Build AwarenessDefine Your Starting PointCreate a Shared VisionTranslate Your Vision into ActionBuild your GovernanceFund the TransformationSignal your AmbitionsEarn the Right to EngageSet New Behaviors and Evolve CultureBuild Foundation SkillsAlign Incentives and RewardsMeasure, Monitor and IterateThese 12 points apply to any transformation not just digital.  You could say the same for implementing ERP, post merger integration or any other significant change.  This undercuts an understanding of digital's potential and its disruptive impact.  These technologies are fundamentally different than the IT technologies that came before, but its hard to tell that from this book or from the approaches it suggests.Readers who have digital scars will benefit from the reminders that this book provides.  People new to digital can easily be lulled into a false sense of security or alarm as it seems so much like what has come before or that we all must become digital masters tomorrow.  Knowing that difference and the nuance it contains is the reason for the length of this review.  By focusing on the organization, Westerman, Bonnet and McAfee have created something very accessible, but they have also accepted some limitations on explaining the reality of digital transformation.

Corkscrews are one of those things that you use just enough to make their design and functionality matter but not often enough to invest in a new product.  The rabbit wing corkscrew works just as you would expect, but the ergonomics and operation is much smoother, better looking and all around easier.First the corkscrew simply fits over the top of the bottle, with the broad black plastic bottom providing an easy and secure grip.  There is no more fumbling trying to hold open the corkscrew, stabilize the bottle and then drive the screw into the cork.Second the short 'wings' and wide horizontal screw top make it easy to uncork the wine, again with significantly less fumbling and pressure.Finally the compact size makes it easy to store, find in your drawer and use.  If you have ever had to hunt for the older style corkscrew you know what I mean.  The design is such that you could leave it out in the open as an accessory rather than a utensil.Overall, a great device, one that easily replaced my old all metal rabbit wing corkscrew and yes I am drinking more wine now because its easy to open.

I purchased the twist medallion as a spur of the moment gift.  I have been rather pleased.  Its a great accessory for business casual and casual wear.The medallion is of the right size to be attractive without being overbearing.  The twist helps the medallion sit flat on the chest giving it a definite front and back side.The one drawback is the 18" chain.  It is too short and the clasp is rather difficult to use.Other than that, its a great chain.

It is difficult to write a less than glowing review for any book.  But I found this book did not meet its marketing and expectations. Hailed as an international thriller in the Stieg Larsson tradition, it seemed like a book worth digging right into.  The Swimmer has many similarities to the Larsson book, both authors are swedish, both involve a complicated plot, a female protagonist and a decidedly non-American style of writing.  But these similarities are superficial as I found The Swimmer to be driven by a ponderous pace, a heavy focus on descriptive prose with product placement and predicable plot.  Those factors form the basis for this review.The basic plot revolves around the inter-actions of five actors who are involved in a struggle for evidence of atrocities that are part of the gulf war and attempts to keep that evidence secret.  The main character Klara is the common connection to the other four.  Child, friend, lover, etc.  It takes Zander half of the book to set up the relationships and interactions before the real plot moves forward.The book is predictable in the sense that the America Baddies are really bad, the european heroes are intelligent, honorable and dedicated to seeing the truth revealed.  The book is not an international tour deforce so much as a tour around Sweden, Brussels, Paris, Amsterdam with glimpses into the middle east.  These locations do not drive the plot as much as they could have.  Likewise the description of the products used by the characters seem more akin to paid for placements in a movie rather than giving meaning toThis is Zander's first published novel and that shows in places with standard plot twists, descriptions and predictable actions.  The result is a book that you have to push through rather than being pulled along by its pace.  Zander makes extensive use of description, internal monologue and flashbacks to set up a situation and plot that is more complex than it needs to be.  He uses each of these techniques a little too much.  The timeline changes from chapter to chapter, requiring the reader to constantly check the date when reading each chapter.I do not hate this book, but I do not like it either, particularly when it is held up as the next major type of thriller.  I am sure it is already optioned and will show up in theaters some day soon.Overall, the book is not bad, but its no where good enough to say that Zander is in line to be the next Larsson, just yet.

Feeling warm, clammy or think that you have a fever?  Too often you just grin and bear it, after all its inconvenient to retrieve a traditional thermometer, put it in your mouth and then wait for the results.  The Braun Ear Thermometer solves all of that.  Non invasive, accurate and easy to use; the combination makes for a most valuable addition to your medicine cabinet.  If you have small children, then this is a must have particularly as school and the flu seasons kick in.The device is roughly the size of an electric shaver.  It fits easily into your hand.  It is easy to store and therefore easy to find.  For those with a shallow medicine cabinet then you may need to store it elsewhere.  The device fits well in a kitchen drawer making it readily accessible throughout your busy day.So if you have ever wondered if you had a fever or needed to know if others have a fever, then this is a recommended addition to your home medicine chest.

I had a Norelco razor a long time ago and was curious to see how they have improved.  They are signficantly improved and delvier a close and consistent shave.  The re-designed the shaving head which makes it much more flexible, easier to manuever around your face and providing a smoother cut.  The variable razor speeds deliver different types of shaves.The razor charges quickly and holds a charge effectively.  The cleaning systems that comes with the razor is innovative but it takes up considerable space in the bathroom.  Those with limited space on their sink or vanity should recognize that the real estate.  This is one reason for a four star review.The shaver delivers a high quality shave, particulalry good for an electric razor.  It is comparable to shaving with a blade.  I found the best results shaving with my face dry before getting into the shower as that provides an even shave as I missed less spots than using a disposable razor in the shower.Recommended for those looking to upgade their electric shave.  Blade shavers may want to consider this option as well particularly if they frequently miss parts of their shave.

I know its a bread knife and it works well cutting bread, but it can cut much more.  We have used it for tomatoes, cucumbers and other light cutting tasks.  The blade is particularly thin and flexible which helps it take on slicing tasks. The blade is an integral part of the handle with a good rubber grip.A great addition to the kitchen and this knife is useful as it cuts more than just bread.

This knife is a great partner in your kitchen.  This knife is well made, easy to grip and it feels good in your hand.  It is a heavy knife, particularly for a paring knife.  The weight gives the knife a center of gravity feeling and tactically greater control.  This really distinguishes it from other pairing knives that are lighter but require more concentrated control.  The blade length is good for a pairing knife with a sharp tip great for coring or making the initial intention or cut.It is recommended as a great kitchen tool.

This is classic William Gibson, rich in its depiction of the near future.  Dialog driven, Gibson injects the reader directly into the action with little scaffolding or explanation that can be disconcerting, particularly to people who are not used to reading this type of book.  I can tell you that its well worth the effort as the characters reveal themselves rather than begin told about them.By just jumping in, it takes some time to get a feel for the book.  Things clear up around page 83 as you build context around the characters and the settings.  Without giving too much away, The Peripheral is a story of multiple worlds, situations and timelines creating a rich background and exploration of very interesting ideas concerning the near future.Not quite as dark as Gibson's other works but not a light work either.  Few authors can inform the reader about a possible future via character dialog rather than long descriptive prose.  Gibson is a master at this and The Peripheral reflects that mastery.It is a tough read at the start, but well worth the investment.  Something that needs to be read, every word as they all have meaning and its easy to miss something.  So don't plan to skim it, sample it or read a few pages then put it down for a week.  Take some time and enjoy.

If you core strawberries on a regular basis with a paring knife, then you know the control you get and the ability to quickly deal with any soft spots.If you core strawberries occasionally, then you know the frustration of digging out the core, cutting too much, etc.This product is perfect for those who occasionally core strawberries as it provides a quick, easy and no mess approach to accomplishing a sporadic task.  If you core strawberries on a regular basis, you may find yourself frustrated as you need two tools -- the corer and your paring knife.The action of the twist and pop takes some time to get used to, but the results are consistent.While not a must have in your kitchen, if you enjoy fresh berries in the summer, then consider this product.  If you already core strawberries with a knife without thinking, then suggest you go for a different kitchen gadget.

The title Connected by Design gives the impression of being Design Thinking.  That is misleading. Design is really not the focus of this book.  Rather the book concentrates on describing and advocating for a specific context they call  Functional Integration.This is a two star book for the following reasons:-> This is not a design book-> It is a commercial for the authors company and the authors branded idea, Functional Integration rather than an exploration of the  challenges and initiatives leaders are taking in the face of changing conditions-> The books examples are over reliant on Apple iPod and Nike+ which are good examples, but there is more to business and being like these companies.-> Limited support for B2B implications as it concentrates on B2C and consumer digital related businesses.  This book says little if your not Google, Apple, Nike, etc.-> The book is filled with assertions by the authors rather than analysis to build the readers knowledge and ability to act.There are some good ideas in this book, but they are few and far between given the amount of time the authors spend touting Functional Integration and their company.  You will need to read between the commercial messages to pick up some new ideas on horizontal vs. vertical integration, views on digital marketing, etc.DETAILED REVIEWThe authors define Functional Integration as a distinctive online platform that functions both as a hub for a brands digital services and as an invaluable portal to the brands e-commerce offerings.  The result, according to the authors, relies on the interdependent dimensions of functionality and integration within ecosystems in order to deliver growth and profits. (page 6)  The description is full of aspiration but the book is limited on explanation -- hence the two star reviewThe bulk of the book concentrates on describing Functional Integration resulting in a book that is more of a commercial for R/GA rather than an exploration of the issues and challenges facing organizations.  The remaining chapters of the book focus on one of the following principles of Functional Integration Utility is relevance Context is king Synergy captures customers Reimagine value creation Redesign value delivery Redirect toward value capture Lead like the world depends on itThese are fine principles, but the book treats these with assertions around their company and what they have done rather than building the reader's awareness and abilities.  The result is rehashing observations and arguments about how marketing and consumers have changed, with limited new light shed on the issues, for example the discussion equating personalization with experience.Strengths:The discussion of horizontal vs. vertical integration is helpful in understanding the different moves and motivations of players in the digital world.  Functional integration seeks to be the space between the two.The book uses case examples as illustrations of the ideas but not as studies regarding how leaders faced issues and challenges.Challenges:The commercial and self promotional aspects of the book get in the way of the books ideas as the reader is led to believe that Functional Integration is the only answer and R/GA the only partner undercuts the ideas in the book.The case studies are limited to companies with particular branded/stacked ecosystems like Nike+, Apple, Google, etc.  The book does include the McCormick as a case study, but the discussion is speculative and projects how McCormick with spices will need to do the same thing as Apple or Nike.The book's structure needs section breaks to help the reader digest the author's arguments

The Rise of the DEO provides a description of leadership in the design age.  It concentrates on laying out all of the positive aspects of leadership with little to no consideration of the realities and compromises reality requires.  It is an example of the type of book that everyone will agree with, publicly state that they aspire to be and then go about their normal business.  That is why its just an OK book or three stars.How to become a DEO is the one thing missing from this book. Its also the reason I bought the book and dedicated time to read it.Please read on before you condemn this review as being from a reactionary, non-innovative or someone who just does not get it.  Devotees of design, who accept the principles with little debate, will find this book foundational.  Slight skeptics on the other hand will agree that the points the authors make are interesting but they will take the descriptions with a grain of salt and suspect.Maria Giudice and Christopher Ireland provide a compressive description of a to-be vision for design principles as a model for leadership.  The aspiration is a good one, but in execution the DEO book fails to create a blueprint for future leaders.  This happens when the book concentrates on delineating a list of design principles and then describing how they apply to leadership.  The result is a list of characteristics that are all encompassing to a degree that makes it difficult to see how to become  this type of leader.  The characteristics make up the chapters of the book and include:Personal leadership characteristics -- the "ME" as the authors call them:- Change Agent- Risk Taker- System Thinker- Intuitive- Socially Intelligent- GSD-- Getting 'stuff' doneGroup leadership characteristics -- the "WE"- Co-creation- Networks and Communities- Crafting Culture- Care and Feeding- Place MattersLeadership for action -- the "DO"- Positive Passion- Expertise- Problem Solving- Permission to Fail- Playful Work- Iterate and EvolveLeadership from the inside -- the "BE" aspect- Integrity- Humility- Generosity- OriginalityTaking together these 22 characteristics define a rare individual indeed a cross between a number of famous people -- just take your pick.  That is where the book delivers and declines to take the next step -- how do you become this type of leader.  The authors include a series of Profiles who they consider DEO's which is a great part of the book.  Unfortunately much of these write ups talk about the people themselves, their experiences and innate traits which give the reader the idea that DEO's are born rather than being made.StrengthsComprehensive in its description and discussion of the manifestation of design traits in leadershipGraphic illustrations of its concepts and points as well as the paths of the profiled leadersChallengesThe book is written to a design oriented audience, people who already 'get it' so to speak, but that is not the audience who needs to understand and practice these principles.While the book features several profiles, they do not contain profiles of people who lead in more traditional organizations.  This gives the impression that DEO's can only be found in those type of companies rather than in more traditional companies.  That means that DEO traits do not matter to all of those people working in 'traditional' companies.

Being innovative and established are often assumed to be mutually exclusive.  According to conventional wisdom big companies cannot create new ideas and generate new businesses as readily as their small start-ups. This leads to books written about how big companies can act small.  While that generates a lot of jargon, it results in little actionable insight.That is where this book comes in.  Hill, Brandeau, Truelove and Lineback have created a book that clearly illustrates how large organizations can be more innovative in ways that work with their size and scale rather than against it.  This subject alone makes this an important book, their treatment of the subject differentiates this book and makes it an important management resource for every organization.The authors identify three critical aspects required for innovation: Collaboration, discovery-driven learning and integrative decision making.  These aspects sound conventional and they are, but the authors build on these ideas to bring out the nuance and necessity of thinking differently about innovation.  These differences and the contradiction they have with legacy business cultures bring out what it takes to lead innovation.  They include:Collaboration requires 'creative abrasion' looks at the tension inherent with innovation.  The authors discuss this process where potential solutions are created, explored and modified through debate and discourse.  Corporate culture, norms and behaviors are fundamentally non-confontational and often passive aggressive which needs to change by leading through accepting the creative abrasion associated with new ideas.  This is the focus of Chapter 6 of the book.Learning and discovery processes lead to 'creative agility' through a process based on pursuing new ideas quickly and proactively through multiple experiments, reflecting and analyzing on the outcomes of these experience and adjusting subsequent actions and choices based on what they learned.  This is the focus on Chapter 7 of the book.Integrative decision making requires 'creative resolution' covers the observation regarding the combinatorial aspects of innovation and the need to make the integrative decisions necessary to realize innovative results.  Chapter 8 of the book discusses the governance and organizational structures that balanced patience vs urgency and bottom up initiatives vs. top-down direction.These three areas reflect the fundamental approaches organizations can add to become more innovative.  While these approaches make sense, community and purpose are the lynchpins that hold this together.  The book devotes a portion on these two points that take the broad based issue of innovation and make it actionable.  The book's prose is occasionally academic and stilted in places, particularly when it is discussing ideas around leadership.Overall, a strong book, written from a business perspective that provides tools for executives.  The book features a number of case study companies including Pixar, HCL, Volkswagen, eBay, Google, Pfizer among others.  The cases facilitate telling the story and illustrating the ideas.

Design thinking is one of the those things that define the future of management and business and therefore it is critical to understand and apply.  This book starts out doing perhaps the best job of explaining Design Thinking in a clear and understandable way.  That makes the first first 15 pages among the best I have read on the subject.The books idea to illustrate the application of design thinking in a varied set of situations is also excellent.  Unfortunately this is where the book bogs down as the cases focus more of explaining what people people did in narrative form rather than showing how design thinking helped solve the problem.  This leads to case chapters which make up the majority of the book that are illustrative and a bit heavy without being incisive.This makes Solving Problems with Design Thinking more of a secondary book to read rather than the place to start to understanding design thinking.  I would recommend Change by Design: How Design Thinking Transforms Organizations and Inspires Innovationby Tim Brown as a good place to start.  Also Service Design: From Insight to Implementation by Andy Polaine, Lavrans Lvlie and Ben Reason is another book that is a great place to start.

This is the book we have been waiting for after having reading Freakonomics and were looking for ways to apply it.  This book not only explains the background for this way of seeing the world, but also examples and some tools to shake you out of stability and help you to think like a Freak.The book well written, easy to read and most importantly even easier to remember and apply.  Highly recommended even if you did not read Freakonomics as you can pick this book up and get immediate value to be more creative and see the world in a new life.

New technology waves are fundamentally evangelical in the sense that they paint an aspirational future where everything is great.  The age of context is very much along these lines, aspirational, general and preachy.  The book is light on details and deeper examples beyond some of the ideas that we all hear about.If you are looking for discussions about where the future of technology is going and how it will impact our lives then this book is good, but not the place that I will start with.  I would instead look at the online publications, Wired and different tech blogs to get a better idea of where things are going in such a dynamic world.  For example, the future of work is well illustrated in a book entitled "A Year without Pants." That is the reason for the 3 star revenue

Power packs are an essential element for anyone traveling with a tablet/iPad etc. The Belkin Power Pack is an able addition to my briefcase.  The product is good, but there are some things that hold it back from being a four or five star rating.  First the good points:  its size works well and does not take up a ton of real-estate in my brief case -- unlike some other batteries that are bulky.  It is well made and the rounded edges help keep the battery from snagging on the other things in my briefcase.  The battery does not come with an outlet plug charger, meaning that there is one less thing you need to carry, particularly if you have a USB/outlet for charging.Now the less than great things.  The battery reserve is relatively weak, a fully charged battery has recharged my iPad to only about 50% over night.  The main thing is that the pack is fundamentally not user friendly.  Here is an example -- there are two USB ports labeled by the voltage 2.5 and 1.0 without any guide as to which device goes where.  This is a simple thing that could have been addressed with just some silk screening to say Tablet and Smart Phone.If you looking for a new battery backup for your tablet and phone then this is as good as any.  If you are looking to provide battery back up for your smartphone only, then I would save some money and go smaller as those batteries are more than up to the task.
Sorry, I started this book but it went missing in the hotel.  Great start but you need to know the earlier books to get the most out of the book.

Digital demands finding new ways to attract and engage human attention.  Applying game mechanics to products and processes represents an interesting solution to this persistent problem.  Understanding what gamification is and how it works is the focus of Brian Burke's informative book.The book provides a primer on the topic covering the terms, applications and ideas surrounding the application of game mechanics divided into ten chapters around the core models of ramification.The first part of the book discusses the value of gamifying products and services in 5 pages:- Motivation: the Gamification End Game- Giving Meaning to Players- Changing Behavior One Step at a Time- Using Gamification to Develop Skills- Using Gamification to Drive InnovationThe second part of the book looks at this trend from the players perspective:- Player Centric Design- Designing a Gamified Solution- Common Design Pitfalls- Managing for Success- Gamification 2020: What the future HoldsThese parts, taken together, provide executives and technologists with a good view on how these technique can drive value in their organizations.

The Mongoliads first three books were great taking us into a world and a perspective that few could.  The main story ended leaving two subplots unresolved.  This book resolves one of them in terms of telling the tale of the Shield Brethren.  It is a good story filled with detailed descriptions of the Western Martial Arts  also known as how medieval knights fought in armor with swords and other weapons.The book moves its characters rapidly west as the come back from their task in the Mongol capital.  While there is much action and movement in the story, there is little in the way of character development or real story telling.  This is a weakness of the book as there are many opportunities for the characters to reflect and interact in the plot line, they just never seem to include that in the story.  This is unusual for a story started by the original authors who worked to develop richer characters.Recommended if you liked the Mongoliad books, but be aware that this book is more about plot resolution than storytelling.  If you have not read the prior books, then I would strongly suggest starting at the beginning.

Sounds very good and seems solidly built, as far as one can tell those things.  My only issue is the feel of the footswitch - it's a very hard click, and it pops when it's engaged, which often happens if a pedal is true bypass.  This pedal has plenty of delay time, and it's a great size for squeezing more onto your pedalboard.No issues, sounds great.  The repeats have a nice, grainy, analog feel to them.  I don't know if it's true analog, but it sounds like it.

Though this book is now old, in the overall scheme of things that have happened since 9/11, it's still a good read which provides a valuable and interesting perspective on the history of the Middle East and the US response to 9/11 in the region.  The author doesn't purport to adhere to any particular ideology, so I don't know that I could call this anything but neutral - of course depending on your particular political leanings, your mileage may vary.Dyer's style is very readable, he relays facts and information with little clutter and avoids the dry, bland textbook style of so many political and/or history books.  This is a pretty easy book to get through, but it still provides so much information in a very accessible manner.  Even though at the time of its writing the US invasion of Iraq was pending, I would still say that most of this book is still relevant.  I learned a lot about the Middle East and the growth of fundamentalism.I will also add that in the introduction Dyer essentially predicts the Arab Spring and the 2008 worldwide recession (more or less), which is pretty incredible.

I admit that I went into this not being a huge G&O fan.  After having watched a few episodes, I think the writing on this show is decent and the main characters are generally likeable, but to me they're trying way too hard to be "quirky".I also find that their unison-singing gets on my nerves.  But mainly the thing I can't get behind is their songs.  I just don't think they're funny.  They tend to start to sound samey to me (the unison singing thing again), and the draw seems to be how many words they can cram into each song without regard for melody.  So, for me they don't work as songs, and they don't work as humor.OF course not everyone will feel this way.  Your mileage may vary.
